There is not the slightest doubt that without any unnecessary attempt to criticise others or without waste of time and energy in borrowing from others, much profitable work could be accomplished by the utilization of our ancestral property, if only a loving and earnest aspiration is aroused for the reclamation of lost treasures.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ü‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§

Rejecting the sweet porridge at home the fool begs for alms elsewhere.
14. Before closing this introductory chapter, it is desirable to obtain a rough idea, if possible, of the general introduction found at the commencement of every Purana or Ithihasa. It begins with the unbearable burden of the mother earth caused by the multitudes of worldly sins and her prayer to be relieved of the same. The Puranas give in detail the description of her visit to the Vishnu Loka and of her complaint represented there in the form of a cow. Then comes the promise kindly given of a particular incarnation on the earth and the assurance of redressing all her grievancesby necessary actions. This little prologue is quietly introduced without giving any cause for suspicion like many other incidents, and is invariably passed over without feeling any difficulty. But with a slight waking from slumber, one is sure to find himself in the midst of a riddle. Earth in any known form such as a garden, field, hill or valley has never been seen complaining to anybody of any matter. Nor is the idea of her going away to some other Loka easily imaginable by those who are helplessly bound down to her surface. The difficulty is augmented by having to imagine in addition that her representations are made in the form of a cow. The mute cow is as unqualified for this serious purpose as the dead material with which the earth is composed. First of all how could the earthy globe itself be affected by burden or weight created by worldly sins is a fit subject for scientific enquiry. How she could easily transform herself into a cow and travel to etherial regions in that state without wings provided, are impossibilities in physical nature. The representations of grievances in human language by a cow are beyond ordinary comprehension. If she were described as having taken a woman’s form at least it would have given us some relief, but it is evident from the various Puranas that the ancient sages are not prepared to grant even that much. In these circumstances there is no other go but to resort to our venerable pundits for help who always stand unshaken like an adamantine rock to face all possible difficulties in this direction. They have their ready solution at hand which they are ever generous to offer gratis. “In olden days the Godess earth could represent her grievances wherever she likes and she is able to do this in the form of a cow”, is virtually the explanation. Blessed are those who are satisfied with this enlightened explanation. But unfortunately the majority of mankind could not afford with their poor brains to grasp the magnitude of wisdom imbedded in the explanation. However it ispractically useless to proceed with the stories narrated in thePuranas and Ithihasas without understanding the correctmeaning of this introduction here referred to, and it is certainthat until it is satisfactorily explained, no reliance canbe placed on any further interpretation of the subsequentpassages in the texts. But there is an impression prevailingin some quarters that the Vedas alone contain the purestand the oldest ideas of Hindu religion and that the Puranasand Ithihasas are subsequently added and are to a greatextent interspersed with mythical stories and rituals as wellas extraneous and sectarian matters. Their careful study istherefore considered unimportant as they do not come up to thehigh standard of the Vedas and Vedantas with which theyhave probably no concern. Much indifference is observableamong Sanskrit scholars generally in the study of this literature. The Puranas and Ithihasas do not seem to receive attheir hands even the interest usually evinced in novel reading.Detailed information shall be furnished on the subject in thesucceeding chapter but a mere reference may be made to ithere by the following quotation showing their importantrelation to the Vedas and Vedangas.

‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¨‡•É‡§Ç‡§π‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

The Ithihasas and Puranas serve the purpose of commentariesto the Vedas. Partial knowledge without a study of themis so dangerous that the Vedas themselves seem to be afraidof such ignorant scholars.

______________

CHAPTER II.

RELIGIOUS TEXTS AND PHILOSOPHY.

OUR conspectus in the last chapter, of the varietiesof mistaken notions current on the ancient andsacred literature of our mother country, creates a necessityfor proper enquiries, with a view to determine, whether afterall, there is anything worth enquiring into or worth preserving as useful and valuable knowledge for the presentand future generations. It may be necessary for this purpose to stick to some convenient order of treatment lest welose the main and important points and fail to follow theconnected links in proper succession. The subjoined classification may be found sufficient to answer the requirements,although it is impossible to have exclusively distinct logicaldivisions in matters of this nature‚Äî

(1) The classification of the Texts and the generalcharacter of the subjects treated therein.

(2) A short description of the ideals of Hindu Philosophy and Religion.

(3) Explanations of some of the Geographical details.

(4) Interpretations of a few important historical incidents and the calculations of time connected therewith.

(5) The meanings of personalities prominently figuringin these religious texts.

For the sake of convenience, the last three namely3, 4 & 5 may be dealt with in a full separate chapter.The treatment of all the above points shall be mostly byquotations from the texts themselves rather than by offeringindependent and original suggestions or explanations. Itis unnecessary to reiterate here that the modern currentinterpretations and criticisms are entirely unwarrantedand unsupported by the contents of the texts and are therefore only mere inventions according to the fancy andcaprice of each critic who often voluntarily gives out hisopinions or sometimes feels bound to express, to maintainhis acknowledged position as an authority. In either casethe value of his opinions has only to be calculated upon hispersonal importance and not upon their correctness or cogency.For, if the opinions were only perfect as we are naturallyprone to believe, they should have been capable of beingcarried right-through every page of these texts without inconsistencies and irrelevancies. That this is seldom foundpossible has been amply proved. The only choice left for us under these circumstances is to come to the inevitableconclusion that the defects observed almost at every stepare either owing to the mistakes in the texts themselves, orowing to the unauthorized misinterpretation of the so-calledauthorities. But no modern critic however biased andunsympthetic has gone to the length of denying even literarycapacities to the venerable authors of the sacred Texts.ordinary Sanskrit scholar cannot fail to admire the beautiesof ancient literature and the immense wisdom of its authors.Under these circumstances it is neither useful nor safe toaccept any opinions as correct unless they are directly supported by evidence obtained from the texts themselves.

SECTION 1.

The Classification of the Texts.

** 1.** Knowledge or Vidya in the highest sense of theword is divided into two classes, the Practical and Theoretical,the Para and the Apara. Even the most sacred and importantVedas including all other sastras fall only under theTheoretical Division called Apara. The recognition of such a clearand distinct division is the peculiar characterestic of theIndian Philosophy and Indian religion. The highest knowledge to be attained as the Summumbonum of human existencetherefore lies beyond the plains of thought and reasoning:‚Äî

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§•‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡••

‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The following is another similar logical classification ofthe subject into three divisions instead of two, namely ParaVidya and Bhranti.

‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

All perverted knowledge is Bhranti. All scientific knowledge is Vidya and the highest knowledge beyond Vidya isParom. The Vedas and all other Sastras will therefore beclassed under Vidya which is clearly defined as scientifictreatment of truth.

The following is again another classification into Paroksham and Aparoksham Nganom.

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The theoretical knowledge of the existence of theAbsolute and the Practical experience of the same are treatedas two distinct divisions of true knowledge.

The Vedas and their divisions are detailed below:‚Äî

‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•§
‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•§
‡§Ö‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡••

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The Vedas originated from the breath of Vishnu. TheVedanta is their imbedded essence. The Ric Veda has 21branches or sub-divisions. The Yajus contains 109. TheSama 1000 and the Atharva 50: Total 1180. Each branchor Sakha has an Upanishat attached.

Vidya consists of the following 14 subjects.

‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•§
‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

The chief among these the Veda is virtually single andit has also a single meaning. The Ithihasas and Puranasare its commentaries, and other texts will not be religiouslyrecognised which do not coincide with this Veda in theirapplication.

‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¨‡•É‡§Ç‡§π‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¨‡§π‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§è‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡••

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

That the Veda is but one is reiterated in various texte.Its subdivisions as well as the Puranas are only meant for theclear understanding of its meanings.

‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡§¨‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§•‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡•§

‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

The following clearly states what is really the onlymeaning of the Veda or its subdivisions.

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ï‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§® ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

“The Vedas, Smritis, Puranas, science of logic and allthe Agamas unanimously treat of the Oneness of the Supreme.The Yogis express the same opinion from their direct experience, and yet few are prepared to accept it. Some allowit to a small extent as a matter of courtesy and they are surelyfools. But there are others, who totally deny it and theyare neither human beings nor even the lowest kind of worms.They could only be treated as dead clod of earth”.

What is meant by Sruti or Veda has been already explained as the knowledge theoretically obtained from thegreat Rishis of their experience and results of experiments.The vedangas, six in number, come next. They are namedbelow‚Äî

‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§Ω‡§• ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

** ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§¶‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••**

‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‚Äî is metrical science, prosody.

**‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É‚Äî**is a sacred precept or rule, low or ordinance.

**‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ç‚Äî**is a tract on astronomy.

**‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‚Äî**is the science which teaches the proper pronunciation of words and laws of euphony.

**‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç‚Äî**is grammar, grammatical analysis.

‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç‚Äî is etymological interpretation of words, especiallyof those occurring in the Vedas and which convey inthemselves without the help of other words, the intended meaning in full.

A knowledge of these six angas or limbs of the Vedas isabsolutely necessary to understand the correct and fullmeaning of the contents of the Vedas. The last one ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Çholds the position of a chapter on ‘definition of terms used’,found in all scientific treatises, without a knowledge of whichno one will be allowed to explain the subsequent portions ofthe text. It is however extremely doubtful whether many of the modern interpreters have ever known the existence ofsuch a treatise in their voluntary and mistaken elucidationsof these sacred religious books.

The Smritis come next in the order of importance. Theyare defined as follows‚Äî

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§

‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§ú‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§á‡§π ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The authors of the Smritis are here described as endowedwith the power of bringing back to their memory, theDharmas of the previous Manwanthara and hence calledSmritis.

What is meant by a ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Çmay be examined later onin connection with ‘Time’ and the Sishtas or those thatremain after a ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Çmay be treated when speaking ofpersonalities. It is sufficient to note here the technicalmeaning of Smriti as described in the texts and as specifiedabove.

2. The next varieties of religious literature arecalled Itihasas and Puranas. The former slightly differsfrom the latter, as they deal with some specific subjects, theso-called histories such as the Ramayana and the MahaBharata; whereas the Puranas have other functions to fulfilin their treatment. The word Itihasa is commonly derivedas composed of ‡§á‡§§‡§ø-‡§π and ‡§Ü‡§∏. ‘So it has been’, history,legendary or traditional. It may be more aptly explainedas ‡§á‡§§‡§ø + ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§É, that which is narrated in the form of aninteresting or funny story; and hence not real history.

We next come to the Puranas. The word Purana is a termmost commonly used and equally abused. It therfore demands a very careful and detailed investigation to ascertainits correct meaning.

‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡••

‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The first definition somewhat conveys a double meaning ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ may be interpreted in the usual sense of geneological descent and its history; but the latter half of thecouplet requiring us to understand the gist of the subject bythe application of Niruktam, clearly refers to a more seriousinterpretation. This portion of the couplet is invariablyfound repeated wherever a technical meaning is speciallyintended, a knowledge of which is said to remove all oursins. Great religious importance is thus attributed to themere knowledge of the meaning conveyed in accordance withthe rules of Niruktam. In the Maha Bharata, Adi Parva,we find

‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

The necessity to enquire in a particular method of interpretation is thus evidently established by the contents of thetexts themselves. No clearer evidence is possible or necessaryto be adduced to convince us of the fact that the authorsof these hoary texts really meant something deeper than thecurrent and ordinary meanings that could be easily gatheredfrom their surface. Important clues furnished in thismanner, wherever found necessary, are not taken advantageof, nor are they treated with better ccnsideration than thepassages above or below them.

Definition No. 1. To come back to the words underreference, ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Çmay be broken into two, ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç and ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç; theformer referring to the supreme Brahman and the latter toMaya or Sakti. Thus a compound of ‡§™‡§∞‡§Çand ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Çwill clearlybe indicative of the combination of both.

‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

It is not difficult now to arrive at the real technicalmeaning of the term Puranom. It is meant to treat, as wehave seen, of Parom or the Supreme as combined with Mayaa treatment of the Parom in itself, by description in words,being an impossibility.

‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É

Thoughts and words are incapable of penetrating thatregion of Parom. Another definition of ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ is equallyrelevant here.

‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡•§

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

Prana or life breath is inside the physical body, manasor mind lies within the Prana, Karta or actor is withinthe mind and the Bhokta or enjoyer is still within. Thesuccessive internal cavities or guhas here described are calledthe Parampara.

Def. No. 2. from Vayupurana, clearly affirms that theterm Puranom refers to the Ultimate Entity from which thecreated Universe has first originated. There is hardly anyambiguity or uncertainty in this description. ‘Narayana isthe essence pervading every where, himself having originatedfrom Maheswara. Thus the Puranom may be briefly explained as refering distinctly to Maheswara who takes tocreation and destruction at fixed periods.

Def. No. 3. Skanda Puranom, says that, “Sruti, Smritiand Purana are the three eyes of the learned. When theyare able to see everything properly, through these eyes, theybecome part of Maheswara himself.

Puranom is recognised by Brahma as the fifth Veda.Therefore, he knows nothing who knows not the Puranom”.

Def. No. 4. Brahat Narada Purana, classifies Atmainto Para and Apara. Para is without any attributes andApara is connected with Egoism and mind. The body composed of the five elements is called the Kshetra and theAparatma located inside the body is known by the namesKshetragna, Sabda-brahma and Puranapurusha. Althoughthe Para and Apara are virtually one, the latter is distinguished from the former owing to the existence of egoismand mental functions. When these mental functions andegoism are destroyed by the proceses prescribed for the same,the knowledge of the identity of both will be acquired. Theprocesses prescribed are the rules of Yoga. The word Puranapurusha meaning the subject matter of the Puranas, gives acomplete clue to their real contents. The current interpretation therefore as pure historical treatment of the reigns of sovereigns of the Solar and Lunar dynasties in India is a sheer mistake, consequent on the outer forms of narrationsand the details of personalities and actions described in thedisguise of human stories. But every intelligent and carefulreader will be compelled to confess that there are morereasons to take them for fables than to style them histories,but for some reason or other there is a strong tendency to erron the side of history rather than on the side of fables.

It will be a matter of great advantage to examine atthis stage, the requirements of a Purana or the rules prescribed for and followed in its proper composition. These arelikely to furnish us with very useful clues for arriving atdefinite conclusions.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§â‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Quotations Nos. 1 and 2 mention the four divisionsevery Purana should consist of. First comes the descriptionsof the qualified persons privileged to study and make use ofthe instructions given in a Purana. The second divisionrefers to the real subject aimed at in its usual treatment inthe Puranic style. The third division gives the clue as tohow the narration of stories and events should be interpretedso as to apply to the object in view. The fourth that is thelast division specifies the results to be attained by a study ofthe particular Purana.

It is pretty clear from these distinct divisions themselves that the subject actually dealt with is different fromwhat would appear on the surface and that the ultimate object aimed at is something higher and more importantthan the mere knowledge to be attained by a study ofhuman history. Little or no trouble is needed to discover thatthe Puranas are unlike the histories retained by the moderncivilized nations of the West. Incongruities in shapes andforms, impossibilities in Physics and Chemistry, inconsistencies in Geography and Astronomy, irrelevancies in Arithmeticand Geometry are not wanting in any of their sacred pages.In spite of these facts however, no honest scholar of Sanskritventures to cry down the literary capacities and the practicalwisdom of the apparently crazy authors of these texts. Andyet unfortunately, few are interested in searching for theirreal significance, nor prepared to admit the possibility orprobability of finding useful and valuable materials in theirmidst.

Quotation number 3 gives the well-known classificationof the requirements or Lakshanoms to constitute a properPurana. The list of these items is in the mouth of almostevery Pundit. Except a recitation of these terms occasionallyto exhibit erudition, no trouble has ever been taken to lookinto their reference. There is generally a preconceivedopinion as to these terms applying to some well-knowncircumstances detailed in the Puranas with which all aresupposed to be very familiar. The words ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§óare sometimes explained very curiously. To state theseexplanations here would be unnecessary for our present purpose and might appear even insulting. It is sufficient if theywould now condescend to notice the clear and detailed elucidations provided in the texts themselves. A loose translation of the passage here quoted will I trust be a safer andmore effective method of explaining the ideas so vividly expressed therein. “Sarga, Pratisarga, Vamsa, Manwantaraand Vamsanucharita are the five characteristic marks of aPurana. The Eternal Supreme devoid of attributes is firsttreated as changing, and as pervading everywhere as well asthe substratum of everything. It is said to possess threesaktis are forces called Rajas, Thamas and Satwa from whichthree Godesses by name Saraswathy, Maha-Kauli and Maha-Lakshmi originated and took bodily form. An introductionof this kind is first started by the Great Sages toexplaincreation.This introduction up to this stage is styled ‘Sarga’.The further description of the origin of Brahma, Vishnu andRudra, for the purpose of explaining creation, preservationand destruction is called ‘Pratisarga’ The description ofManus from Swayambhuva downwards is called ‘Vamsa’, orfamily. The intervals of time between the various Manus is ‘Manwantara’. The description of the Manus’ families is*‘Vamsanucharita’*. The following quotations will throwfurther light on the subject.

‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡•Å‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡•Å‡•§

‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§è‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§ä‡§∞‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§≤‡•à‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§´‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§´‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

The 18 Puranas and the 18 Upapuranas refer to the36 Tatwas or categories of Philosophical analysis,representing different stages of religious development. The Puranasin all make up the important limbs of Maha Vishnu as detailed in the above quotation, meaning thereby that a knowledge of all the Puranas will bring about a complete kuowledge of the Supreme.

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Amomg the l4 Vidyas dealt with in this section, wehave yet two more left namely, ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ and ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø.

‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ or ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ and ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ are two divisionsof ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ.The former concerns itself chiefly with thecorrect interpretation of the ritual of the Veda and the latterdealing chiefly with the nature of the Supreme spirit. ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Øis the science of Logic.

**3.**The above classification into 14 Vidyas almostexhausts what is known and understood as the ancient religious literature of India. It may not here be possible tocriticise the classification itself as illogical or purposeless, asthe different texts enumerated treat of sufficiently distincttopics more or less connected with the main subject. It is notconfidently hoped however that the usual modern criticisms concerning their genuineness or antiquity will not be readilyapplied. But even the inmediate possibilities of such a contingency need not frighten us out of our wits particularly onaccount of the very low and harmless position we occupy.In our humble enterprise, we have no matters of Arch√¶ological or geological importance to establish for or againstcurrent theories of modern science. Possessing as we do theold world simplicity with which we are often sneeringlydubbed, we can safely and conveniently dive deep into thehearts of our beloved and venerable forefathers, without thedignity and pomp of modern methods. Our main object isonly to pick up useful information from the materials bequeathed to us with sympathy and mercy. That we aresomehow in possession of such relgious literature is beyondquestion or dispute. Whether they are the products of comparatively recent or ancient brains need not disturb us at thisstage. Until at least the result of the present enquiry isascertained we can well afford to take patience in followingtheir authors in their own strain, without entertaining uncharitable and unprofitable presumptions even against theircommon sense.

SECTION II.

** 1.** A brief sketch is here given of the Hindu Philosophical system, including ethics and religion. No seriousor important dissertations are meant to be attempted. The magnitude of the subject as well as the poverty of my ownknowledge will not permit of such a treatment. The philosophical view of the existence of the world is explained in thefollowing extracts.

‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§≤‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•å‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§ú‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§

‡§ï‡§†‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å ‡§ó‡§ú‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§≤‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡•É‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The philosophical theories clearly and distinctly expressed in these quotations from the Upanishads whosegenuinness and antiquity have not yet been completelydisproved, could be easily understood as nothing illogical orantiquated as compared with the conclusions arrived at bymodern philosophers. The first three passages quoted totallydeny the existence of the objective world except as the products of mental modifications. This is exactly the view ofthe ‘Pure Idealists’ of the Western schools of thought. Thesubstratum of the whole cosmological conception of the livingorganic creation is mind-stuff and nothing else.Man oranimal creates his or its own cosmology by the mind itself.All the miseries of the world are therefore self-created.The arguments generally brought forward by the materialistsand constructive idealists against Pure Idealism cannot standthe test of reason and logic.

Concerning the negative character of the Indian theory,there is no likelihood of dis-agreement from the westernphilosophers themselves. But our philosophy positivelyasserts the nature of the residue left after the philosophicalelimination of the material creation. ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ are the threeattributes of the Supreme Bramhan which eternally remainsunchanged. This Bramhan is the ultimate cause of everyexternal and ephemeral existence. Quotation number 4details the course of arguments generally followed in theIndian System. The evolution from the Bramhan is byreflection on the Maya or Prakriti. The reflected Bramhanis the almighty and all-knowing Easwara or Lord. TheMaya is endowed with two Saktis, the Vikshepa andAvarana. The former creates everything known as theuniverse, the latter conceals or veils the truth and preventsthe differentiation of subject and object, both external andinternal. A further reflection on the Intellect or Avidya isthe individual soul called Jiva. When the ideas of Mayaand Avidya, Easwara and Jiva are destroyed, the originalSupreme Bramhan is attained. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ are thefive qualities which constitute everything. The first three‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç or ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç, Eternity, Pure Intelligence andbliss, are the attributes of Bramhan, and ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç, ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç or formand name belong to everything in the created universe. Butthe three qualities assigned to the pure Bramhan devoid ofattributes should be taken to refer to it only in comparisonto the nature of the external world of form and name andalso as diametrically opposed to the same.

2. A few important points touching the subjects ofEvolution and Involution may be detailed here, especiallyas the style of Indian raciocinations is some what differentfrom the western method. The question of cause and effectmay be first taken up for consideration. The most vexedpoint at issue is clearly this. How did the material universeoriginate and how could it originate from the Supremespirit ?

‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•å‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•å ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§™‡§ü‡•å ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

The material cause or Upadana-karana may be of threevarieties. Arambha, Parinami and Vivartha. The Arambhais known as in the production of a cloth from threads. TheParinami is by a change, as curd from milk, pot from clayand ornament from gold. The Vivartha refers to an appearance of change but without any actual change, as the appearance of a snake from a rope. The material world is thus theproduct of Vivartha from the indivisible Supreme spirit, asthe idea of space and blue tint in the Akasa or firmament.

** 3.**The next point to be considered is the nature ofthis supreme spirit which is completely different from everything perceivable or imaginable.

‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•É‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§π ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•à‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡•§

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

“The pure knowledge, Intelligence or consciousness thatremains after the elimination of every possible variety ofmental modification is the supreme self or Bramhan. It isunlike the products of sensations or of imaginations. Thoughunknowable, it is not unexperienced being itself the self. Complete elimination of everything mundane does not end innon-entity, as the elimination is fully existent. Easwara andJiva produced by the reflection of the Self exist only as longas Maya and Avidya exist and receive the reflection. Easwaraand Jiva are therefore only relative terms like grand-fatherand father as related to the grandson and son.”,

4. The next important point to be necessarily considered is the possibility of identifying Jiva or individualsoul subject to all miseries and incapacities with the SupremeSpirit as required by the well-known canons ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø and‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø. I am that and Thou art that.

‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§É ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ü‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ω‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§à‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§®‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

A very clear and distinct differentiation is here given inthe most colloquial terms, of subjectivity and objectivity, of theperceiver and the perceived, the knower and the known, thethinker and the thought. Everything known or perceived isobjective or not-self, including one’s own body, the senses,mind and intellect, as they are all subject to change and destruction. The objective world and the Ego are not confounded even by the lunatic. The self or knower without objectiveattributes is therefore the real meaning conveyed by theword Ahom or I. The well known Maha Vakya ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øis thus easily explained in the above quotation. The following is on the same point.

‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

“The eternal and universal spirit standing aloof witnessing even the intellect and styling itself I or Ahom, is understood by the term Brahman. The identification of that Ahomand Brahman is the use and aim of the Maha-Vakya”.

Another important Maha-Vakya namely ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø issimilarly explained.

‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ω‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§†‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•å‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§∏‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

“The individual soul residing in the body called Kutastastands aloof as a witness, unconnected with the sensationalintellectual or material functions that constitute a body, andforms the very foundation on which all these hallucinationsare built up. The Thou or ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç in reality is this Kutastaitself. Similarly the Eternal Brahman serves as the foundation for all the cosmological conceptions of this varigatedUniverse. Thus the Kutasta and the Brahman when analysed ultimately resolve into one and the same substance.The ideas of Eswara, Jiva or Jagat are postulated and introduced in the Sruti not with the object of establishing theirreality but only for the purpose of explaining Brahmanwhose conception transcends the sphere of thought andwords.’

** 5.** We have now seen how the I or ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç and theThou or ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç are explained as coinciding with the Brahmanwhen all the extraneous circumstances are rejected as irrelevant and ephemeral. A natural but naughty question wouldarise at this stage as to the very starting point from whichall the existing mistaken notions of the world have originated, and equally important is the question how and whythey did originate. Neither philosophically nor scientificallycould proper answers to these questions be easily obtained.

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§É ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§® ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ò‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ò‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§≤‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∑‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§π‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§• ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§® ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•É‡§Ç‡§π‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•É‡§Ç‡§π‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡§ö ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Quotation No. I. “Manas or mind which is at thebottom of all creation is technically styled ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç. Itsmodifications or thoughts arise one after another and create alldistinctions as Atma, body &c. When this flow of thoughtsis stopped, the universe the product of such thoughts isannihilated. Thus it is clear that the incessant current ofthoughts is necessary not only for creation but also forsustinance. This rising of thoughts of their own accord iscalled Avidya which literally means non-existence, and thewhole universe which appears solidified like adamant is thecreation of this non-entity and therefore worthless. Theunreality of this Maya or Avidya will become evident bysternly looking at its face, as it would then immediatelyvanish. There is no need for wasting time in enquiringabout its origin, but it is highly necessary to seek the meansfor its destruction. The successive transformations from theBrahman caused by vasana or past impressions or experienceare into Kshetragna, Ahankara, Intellect, mind, senses andmaterial body. Like the cacoon the Jiva gets itself entangledin its own meshes. It is only the mind that is known bydifferent names in its various aspects and conditions.
