Sometimes it assumes the form of ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, sometimes ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø,‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ or **‡§á‡§õ‡§æ.**The mind itself createsand takes the form of the five elements by processes of evolution. The creator. Bramha is the form of this mind and whenit is destroyed, its creation namely the universe is also annihilated. The gist of the whole theory of the above evolutionis that there is actually neither creation nor destruction.There is naught but selfimposed trouble.”

Quotation No. II. from Vayupurana speaks in thesame strain. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§É, ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É, ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É,‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡§µ‡§É, ‡§ï‡§É, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§É are all synonymous terms with slight differences of meaning in theirspecial applications. This manas, Bramha or Easwara is saidto be the creator of the universe.

The word manas as technically used here has thereforeto be clearly defined to avoid misunderstanding.

‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§Æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§∂‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§® ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç already quoted.

These definitions clearly point out that the referenceis to that pure substratum called Manas freed from all drossusually attached to it by worldly and impure associations.In that pure state called Satva, it is endowed with the powersof creation attributed to Bramha or Eswara: words synonymously used in these religious and philosophical texts.

6. Further question likely to start up in this connection is concerning the varieties of creation and the variousconditions of happiness and misery existing in the world,All these differences are attributed to the Vasanas or impressions caused by previous Karma or actions.This argument more or less reduces the whole matter to the rigorouslaws of nature and virtually removes the necessity for postulating an Eswara or Lord of the Universe as specified above.This common view is criticised as unphilosophical and irreligious in our texts for the following reasons.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•• ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡••

‡§®‡§ö‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

The creation and destruction of this universe cannot beexplained by Nature alone, without supplementing itby time, space &c. In the same manner, neither Karmaitself nor Easwara himself could be said to be the sole cause,as Sruti and Smriti establish otherwise. But that a combination of Easwara and Karma carries on creation, preservation and destruction is what is really meant by nature or‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. And this is exactly the gist of explanations offeredin the Vedas. The laws of nature are in themselves the enforcement of the Lord. The passages quoted here establisha very important fact in philosophy which is seldom noticed,namely that the ideas of creation, preservation and destruction of the universe are themselves different for each individual. That the cosmological conceptions differ accordingto the nature capacity and environments of the individualsis an admitted theory among the philosophers of the West.The cosmological conception of the cottager is not the sameas that of the Townsman; that of the illiterate varies fromthat of a scientist or philosopher. Nay every new fact experienced affects or alters the conception in the same individual from time to time. This special fact conclusivelyestablishes the wisdom of our ancients in having answeredsuch questions in various ways and prescribed several methodsof religious practice. The modern mania for generalisationsand unifications of religious matters for the benefit of themasses is therefore only unphilosophical and unscientific.

7. This almighty and all-knowing Easwara has allalong been described as only the reflection of the SupremeSpirit on Maya. The supposition of such an Easwara may beargued as illogical and unnecessary, as it is not perceptible. In such matters is it not sufficient to stop with Reason orIntellect lying within our own knowledge and experience ?The following passages meet arguments of this nature.

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡§ó‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

(1) ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§

( 2 ) ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ω‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡••

( 3 ) ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

‡§Ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§ò‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡§ü ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡••

(4) ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

Quotation No. I. “In addressing the ordinary peopleSruti takes up the world as it exists for them and explains itas the product of Maya, with a view to establish the necessityof annihilating it for the purpose of getting over the miseriesof the world. In dealing with the wise and the learned.Sruti affirms that everything is Brahman itself and deniesthe real existence of Jagat, Vidya or Avidya”.

Q. No. II. “The Sastras should be understood like themedical science whose main topics are the diseases andtheir remedy. The senses are incapable of grasping thenature of Easwara relating to his powers of creation anddestruction. The Sruti should therefore be entirely dependedupon as authority, meaning thereby that the instructionsof the sages who have directly experienced the facts detailed,should be believed in”.

Q. No. III. “The intellect without the reflection of theSupreme Spirit is as dull as a clod of earth. The perceptionof an object like a pot is with the help and blessing of thisreflection called Easwara and the knowledge of the objectis with the help of the supreme Brahman itself”. This distinction in the process of preception and knowledge is recognised throughout the Theistic philosophy of the East andthe Indian Ontology is entirely based upon this philosophy.Even with the help of the reflected Easwara the Intellect canonly perform the act of perception, but not accomplish theact of knowledge. Its materiality or objectivity has beenalready noticed in the previous quotations.

‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡••

The intellect also has its birth and death like any othermaterial object. It is only an instrument of perception thathas to be used by something more spiritual and superior innature. The knowledge referred to should not be understoodin its ordinary sense. It specifies the real knowledge of thefalsity of objective existence.

‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

The complete removal of the objective world from themind by a clear understanding of the unreality of its objectivecharacter, brings about Nirvana or freedom from bondage.What is meant by the removal of the world’s objectivity isexplained below.

‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§É‡••

It is the knowledge of the immateriality of the objectiveworld by a proper scientific analysis that is demanded for theattainment of Nirvana and not its non-perception in thewaking state of life. Otherwise, the attainment of salvationwould be a very easy affair within the reach of everybody bya simple loss of memory as in sleep, giddiness or intoxicationduring which states neither the objectivity nor subjectivityof the world is known.

The idea of knowledge here detailed is exactly the pivoton which the practical philosophy or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø the exclusiveprivilege of the Hindu system hinges. The Hindu Theologywith its various branches and apparent inconsistencies amongthemselves is built upon this fundamental, philosophical andscientific foundation. All systems which stop with Reasonor ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç cannot therefore appreciate or sympathise withthis Higher system of scientific Theology. This has virtuallybeen the fight between Hinduism and Bhudism in Indiaitself. There is thus no possibility of mincing matters without seriously attacking this special system in an acknowledgedscientific method. The modern attempt to commingle allpossible varieties of religion, science and philosophy in theworld, with the hope of producing an eclectic system congenialto all mankind without distinctions of any kind, is surely alogical impossibility demanding no arguments for its refutation. I refer to the new and curious creed styled Theosophywhich preaches Hinduism, admires Bhudism, believes in someother isms and probably practises none of them.To comeback to quotation No. 3. The meaning of reflection isexplained in detail. In the reflected figure an exact appearance of the original is observable without any of its qualities.Similarly the Atma is reflected in Maya producing a brightappearance but the reflected Easwara differs from the original,being subject to changes. If the idea of reflection is arguedas a product of the Intellect being conceieved by itself andtherefore not different from the Intellect, the Intellect itself may similarly be identified with the material body. Buteven after the death of the material body, the Intellect hasto reappear with its Vasana in accordance with the Karmictheory and therefore it cannot be reasonably identified withthe physical body. If Sruti is quoted as authority to establishthis separate existence of this Intellect, the existence of thereflection in question as distinct from the Intellect is equallyestablished by the very same Sruti. The Iteraya Upanishadclearly describes the constant transmigration of the Atmaaccompanied by the Intellect. If the Atma destitute of allattributes cannot reasonably be supposed to enter any physical body as described in the Sruti, it is equally unreasonableto maintain the usual presumption that this Atma is thecreator of this material world. At the end of a scientificanalysis, both of these presumptions may become false, butuntil that stage is reached by proper prescribed methodsthese distinct facts cannot be ignored.

** 8.** The following quotation from Panchadasi givesfurther elucidation of the distinctions of Maya, Easwara,Intellect &c.

‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•É‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•É‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§£‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡•§
‡§ò‡§ü‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•É‡§õ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

‡§§‡•Å‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§§‡§Ø‡•å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§® ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§® ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú ‡§á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§µ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ß‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ñ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡•å‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡•å‡•§
‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§ï ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§à‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§π‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡•Ä‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§ü‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§ü‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ü‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§® ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•å ‡§Æ‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∑ ‡§™‡§†‡•ã‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§ü‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

Maya is of three varieties according to the differentaspects in which it is observed. As treated in Sruti, it isinsignificant. As for as Reason goes it is inexplicable, asexperienced by the world it is true. It may be said to beindependent as it is unlike the Bramhan without attributesBut as it cannot act without the help of the Bramhan it isnot independent. The objective world is sufficiently clearto all but its real nature or origin is not easily discovered.Maya therefore is a falsity like the appearances in magic andthe attempts to find its nature by the greatest scientistsnecessarily end in Agnosticism. The power of producingthese appearances lies latent in sleep and it is called Maya.All the Vasanas or effects of Karmas of the waking anddreaming states lie latent in sleep like a tree in the seed.The Vasana or impressions unconciously left on the Intellect by good and bad Karmas, acts and thoughts, are lighted upby the Easwara or lord of every thing. He seats himselfwithin the Intellect of every creature commanding andcontrolling in accordance with the merit or demerit of respectiveKarmas. He is therefore almighty, being the efficient causefor creation, preservation and destruction. He is Himself thematerial cause of everything and is therefore everywhere. Thesefacts are most clearly expressed all over the Sruti.Whathe does is in accordance with the strictest laws prescribed byHim. None can nullify or modify, and he is therefore theEaswara or lord of all. The ideas of creation, presrvationand destruction naturally imply considerations of time. Butthis should not be misunderstood as establishing the realexistence of time, while Philosophical analysis denies italtogether. It is only allowed to be introduced in discussingwith students who have all along grown up in the trammelsof time. The question of free will and necessity need notinterfere with the facts detailed here. The Srutis and Smritisare His own enactments which cannot be disobeyed withimpunity. Easwara the lord of creation. preservation anddestruction in accordance with the Vasanas specified above,is thus not a poetical idea or a convenient theory, but a sternfact which cannot be ignored by any ingeneous tricks orscientific discoveries. He is all powerful, all-wise and allpervading. His laws will therefore be carried out to thevery letter.His orders inust be obeyal for fear of penalty.But at the same time, He is all-merciful towards his childrenbeing the Father of all. He has also most kindly prescribedlaws and procedure in the Srutia and Smritis for atonementand redemption. The reconciliation of the antagonistic theories of Free-will and necessity is easily arranged by a cleardistinction between enforcement of laws and freedom ofaction as two different facts altogether. In spite of unavoidable and complete dependence of a peculiar character, the willis allowed full freedom for its display

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡•§

“Depending generally on the Atma, the Intellect, mindsenses and body all act.freely according to their own inclinations, as the people in the world take to their own respectiveworks when the sun shines during the day”. Thus accordingto the description given here, free will and necessity are notcontrary subjects. Every one is personally responsible forhis own actions and the rigorous law to enjoy or sufferaccording to the merit or demerit of his Karmas must beobeyed. The law is enforced by Easwara and concessionsare given by His own law when the Karmas ordained for thesame are properly performed. But the general rule is,

‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The results of every Karma good or bad will be metedout without fail. Here the question recurs as to the life ofthe gnanis who have virtually crossed the ocean of Karmasin this life itself. It is generally believed that Prarabdha orthe commenced life can only end by enjoying or suffering theeffects of all the Karmas, be he gnani or otherwise. Thetexts however have a different version of the theory.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§´‡§≤‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§®‡•á‡§π ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§

‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§® !‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡••

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Quotation No. I. No Prarabda can be attributed tothe gnani enjoying the bliss of Brahman by its knowledgeand experience. He is not affected by the effects of Karmasafterwards, if he is, he is no real gnani but & hypocrite.When the ideas of pleasure and pain are relinquishedPrarabdha becomes meaningless. As dreams vanish when thewaking stage commences, the effects of all the past Karmasvanish when true knowledge is attained. To satisfy theunwise by assigning a reason for the existence of bodies,Sruti gives an explanation by tangible facts. But it is notdone with the object of making the wise believe in theirreal existence. There is but one Brahman and nothing else.All knowledge and experience is of the self and self alone.

Q. No. II. The Gita clearly affirms that as cart loadsof fuel are destroyed by a spark of fire, all Karmas are destroyed by a spark of true kowledge.

Q. No III. Prarabdham means the effects of Karmasin the previous lives. After the attainment of true knowledge births and deaths become false like dreams in the waking state. A rope is mistaken for a serpent through ignoranceand the serpent vanishes when the real nature of the rope isunderstood. Similarly when the unreality of the world isknown along with its real onuse the Brauman, the idea of thebody included in the physical world, vanishes and Prarabdhamgets destroyed.

9. The next point for consideration is the natureand origin of Jiva or individual life and its relation toEaswara the lord of creation, preservation and destruction.

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•å‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡§∏‡§π ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•å ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡§°‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•§
‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡§°‡•ã‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§õ‡•§
‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ö‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ò‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§§‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑ ‡§®‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§õ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•á
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ-
‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•å
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§•‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•å ‡§ö ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡•à‡§ï‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡•á‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§¨‡•É‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡•§

‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§

‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§à‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É‡••

‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç
‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§ß‡•Ä‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ç‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§®‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§

(8) ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

Quotation No. I. Two birds namely Jiva and Easwaraare seated together in this body, the former alone enjoyingthe fruits of action and the latter remaining unattached as awitness. The apparent differences among the Brahman,Easwara and Jiva are created by Maya through differencesin the material environments of Easwara and Jiva. Virtuallythere is no difference in their real nature, as the Akasas within a pot and a house, are the same as the Akasa found everywhere. The sinless Rishis experience this fact within theirown body but not those veiled by the effects of Maya.

Q. No. II. The Physical body is really the temple ofEaswara who is identical with Jiva. When husk is removedfrom paddy it is known as rice, similarly Jiva becomes Easwara when it is not bound by the effects of Karma.

Q. No. III. Jiva is more minute than the minutestatom. It is neither masculine, nor feminine nor neutral. Itgoes by the names of the varieties of bodies it takes.

Q. No. IV. Jiva is the effect and Easwara the cause.Eliminating both of them, the supreme Brahman is attained.There are two meanings for the words ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç and ‡§§‡§§‡•ç, the Thouand the That. The one is known as ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Çand the other‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç . The ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç of Thon is associated with the physicalbody, senses &c; and that of That or ‡§§‡§§‡•ç is the AlmightyEaswara. The ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç of both Jiva and Easwara is theSupreme Spirit itself. In accordance with the logical syllogism ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É, eliminating all the unimportant accessoriesof time, place &c., the ultimate conclusion arrived at is thesupreme Brahman common to both existing at all time.

Q. No. V. The Brahman is the supreme spirit unaffected by Maya, but contains within itself all imaginablepowers or Saktis and appears as extending and filling everywhere through the Intellect, Egoism and the Elements. Itis described as pure, peaceful, blissful &c. and yet indescribable.

Prakriti or Maya is the force or Sakti emanating fromthe Brahman in the form of Intellect capable of producingall varieties of creation.

The Easwara is Bramhan itself as working throughMaya and becoming both the material and efficient cause ofeverything.

Jiva is emersed in the ideas of form and name constituting the material world, on account of ignorance. Althoughit is virtually single, it became many owing to its takingseveral physical bodies.

By the above definitions it is clear that Jiva and Easwara are not in reality different from the supreme Brahman,but are only different stages of existence in the transformation of the Brahman through Maya.

Q. No. VI. “In this world filled with living creatures,the Easwara that enters the bodies and leaves them, takingwith him the mind and the senses, is himself a part of myown self”.

Q. No. VII. The following words are used as synonyms in ancient literature. Budhi, Manas, Linga, Mahan,Akshara, Jiva, Prana and Karana. There is ample scope formisinterpretation without a knowledge of this fact.

Q. No. VIII. Maya is Prakriti and Easwara is thereflection of Brahman in it, called Mayina. He creates andenters different bodies in the form of Jiva. These facts are repeatedly affirmed in the Sruti. A combination of theLinga or subtle body and the reflected Easwara seated insidethe same, together with the Supreme Brahman which is anindispensible basis, is known by the term Jiva. The Mayawhich is endowed with the power of creating everything isalso capable of veiling truth and misleading Jiva What theEaswara creates, the Jiva enjoys according to the merits ofhis Karmas and capacity of his understanding, as a woman isthe creation of the father and the object of enjoyment for thehusband. Operating through Maya Easwara creates andoperating through mind Jiva enjoys. Easwara’s creationsare definite but the ways of enjoyments by the Jivas areindefinite according to the varieties of mental modifications.A gem for instance, is a creation of Easwara. The Jivas areconnected with it in different manner. He rejoices who getsit. He is annoyed who gets it not. He who has relinquishedall desires of the world is indifferent. One and the samewoman is known to different relatives by different namessuch as mother, wife, sister, daughter &c. Having heardthe false news of the death of a son gone to a distant country,there is mourning, and without knowing the news of actualdeath there is no mourning. Thus it is clear that mind aloneis the cause of bondage for every Jiva.

The substance of all the above philosophical analysis issummarised below.

‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•å ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§æ‡•§

(1) ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

(2) ‡§ï‡§†‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§†‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§π ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡•á ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

(3) ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•å‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§≠‡•å‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡••

(1) ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

Quotation No. I. There is no bondage, no salvation,no existence, no non-existence, no creation, no destruction.These are only relative terms for ideas created by the Intellect. The Brahman is pure and free from these.

Q. No. II. The essence of all the Vedantas is this:‚ÄîCreation, destruction and freedom from both are all the workof the self.

Q. No. III. The Easwara and Jiva are only part andparcel of the Self, and are the creations of Maya. Thecreation of the universe forming both its efficient and material cause is the work of Eswara from the waking stateup to the state of Salvation, all the worldy affairs andmiseries are the work of Jiva. The several systems ofYoga and Sankhya are based upon the mistaken theories ofthe real existence of Eswara or Jiva. Until however thetrue knowledge of Brahman is obtained all these theorists areonly raving. they get neither bliss nor salvation. Differencein their degrees of importance is of no avail, like that of abeggar or king as seen in a dream. When the Intellect isdrowned in ignorance it is called Sleep. But there is no sleepfor the Self where ignorance itself is drowned. Full andvigorous display or modifications of the Intellect is calledthe Waking state which cannot be attributed to the Bramhanfree from modifications of every kind. The working of theIntellect in the internal organs or nervous systems or itsmotion through them is known by the name of Dream. TheBramhan destitute of motion altogether has therefore nodream. It enjoys bliss in sleep free from all worldly affairs,but he who sees everything without distinction or differnceby the help of Bramhan is himself Vishnu, Siva or Bramha.The Samsara with all its miseries is but a dream of longduration and the length of the duration itself is but theweakness or perversity of the mind.

Q. No. IV. Maya is like the Kama-Dhenu or the cowthat is endowed with the power of creating everything. TheEswara and Jiva are its calves, you may milk and drink anyamount of duality through them, but Unity or Advita aloneis the truth. The Akasa in the pot is nothing different fromthe Akasa proper. The knowledge of the fundamentalBramhan alone, is the way to Salvation.

The fundamental principles of Indian Philosophy havebeen dealt with already here, by a more lengthy treatmentthan the scope and object of this little volume could permit.In the interest of profitable knowledge, it is useless to criticisethese priniciples by Arch√¶ological or geological methods.The theories expressed are so philosophical and cosmopolitanin character that they deserve serious consideration at thehands of all the civilized nations. They refer to pure philosophy and Psychology, supplemented by discoveries of definite practical methods yet unknown to western philosophers.The necessary foundations are here laid, for all moral, social,legal and other conducts of action in the practical world,without distinctions of caste or cread, age or sex. Thestandard by which any human actions or conduct should bejudged as right or wrong is sufficiently simple and strictlylogical as the only matter for consideration is to see how farthey tend to the advancement in the scale of progress to theultimate end, through definitely prescribed and defined stages.The ethical philosophy which gave so much scope for discussion in the west is more practically and conveniently dealtwith in India. The universal application of the principleslaid down will completely remove all possibilities of unsympathetic attacks on the score of sectarianism or exclusivenessconstantly attributed to the Hindu religion consequent onthe preservation of caste and social restrictions, which entirely belongs to the physical region. The human body itselfis often described in a sircastic style in religious texts, butalso in a most sympathetic and unsectarian fashion.

‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

( 1 ) ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡•å‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••

(2) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Quotation No. I. The physical body is very dirty andunholy. It originates in dirt and pollutions and ends withpollution. Every one happening to touch the same shouldbathe, meaning thereby that the identification of the selfwith it is very bad.

Q. No. 11. Siva is everywhere and all the gods are in the physical body of even the illiterate. None could therefore be treated with contempt on any account. The violation of this rule is a sin and its strict observance by recognising the existence of gods in the human body leads to salvation. Such are the broad unsectarian principles of Ethicsenunciated in these religious texts.

10. Having examined to some extent the outlineof the Indian Philosophy and of Ethics, it is necessary nowto see how religion is deduced from them. We have alreadyseen that mind is at the bottom of both good and evil. Themost essential object to be attained is therefore to obtaincomplete control over the same.

‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡•§
‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡••

( 1 ) ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∑‡§°‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ù‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡§É‡••

(2) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§® ‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•§

‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§Ø ! ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•§

‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§Æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø! ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡•§
‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•à‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠ !
‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§π‡§ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

(3) ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡••

‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§π‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§Æ‡§É‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•á‡••

(4) ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ !‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡••

( 5 ) ‡§∂‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ! ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡•§
‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ‡••

(6) ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

(7) ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

(8) ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡•§

(9) ‡§™‡§§‡§Ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

Quotation No. I. The root of the Samsara tree withits multitudes of branches, is the mind. This root has therefore to be first dried up for the destruction of the tree. Theprocess for effecting this is not restricted in any manner.Either by squeezing the hands or biting the teeth or by anyother rough means, the mind must be somehow conquered.It matters not how it is done. But the most feasible andsensible methods are these. The study of philosophy, association with the wise and pious, to control the propensities ofthe mind, to control breathing &c. The propensities ofthe mind are of two kinds, holy and unholy, the formertends to destroy future births and the latter to increase them.These cannot be slighted as they are the net results of theexperience of hundreds of past births and lives. They willnot easily die out without long and constant efforts.

Q No. II. No salvation is obtainable without the knowledge of the self, and this knowledge cannot be procured without long practice of Yoga. The Brahman is knowable only byoneself and only when properly qualified through Yoga practice. To an unqualified the Brahman is like colours to theblind. The Chitha or mind stuff is like water whose surfaceis ever ruffled by the wind. It cannot therefore be trusted inthat state. As long as it is intent upon various worldlymatters, it cannot be usefully worked for the purpose ofobtaining the knowledge of the Brahman. The practice ofYoga is therefore prescribed with the object of rendering themind calm and fit for superior work. But those who alreadypossess serene minds and are merely ignorant, need only theSankya Yoga or process of philosophical analysis.

Q. No. III. There are two paths for attaining salvation. Gnana-yoga for the Sankhyas and Karƒ±na Yogya forthe Yogis. Arjuna asks,‚ÄîWhat prompts sinful actionsforcibly even when one is not so inclined. Srikrishna says‚ÄîDesire and anger are two inveterate enemies who obstructthe path to true knowledge and they are seated in the senses,mind and Intellect. Therefore you should control the sensesfirst and then overcome these two sinners.

Q. No. 1V. The dwita of Jiva or the life in duality orrelativity is of two kinds, the Sastric and its opposite. Allthat pertains to the enquiry of the Brahman is sastric whichshall be relinquished only after the Brahman is known. Thenon-sastric is sub-divided into weak and strong. Those pertaining to desire or anger are strong and those arising fromfancies of the mind are weak. Both of these require to becurbed before and until the true knowledge is attained. Definite processes beginning with Sama are prescribed for thispurpose in the Sruti. They should also be relinquished afterprocuring the knowledge of the Brahman. Every piousKarma is superior to the action of the worldly. Sagunopasana or worship in some concrete form is superior to Karma.Nirgunopasara or worship in more abstract form is superiorstill. In fact, the more you approach the ultimate goal, themore valuable.

Q. N. V. Two methods are prescribed for subduingthe mind, called Yoga and gnana, the former removesobstructions to real knowledge and the latter aids in correctperception. When the mind is subdued the Samsara orworldly miseries cease, as the worldly transactions cease withthe setting of the sun.

Q. No. VI. Yoga is divided into two, Karma-yoga andGnana-yoga. Both are meant only for those possessing calmand undisturbed minds. The determination to do ordainedKarmas is Karma.yoga; to meditate upon the supreme Brahman is Gnana-yoga. The practice of both together will leadto salvation.

  • Q. No. VII.* The proper possesses for controlling themind is called Yoga.

Q. No. VIII. The real extinction of the working ofthe mind is Yoga.

Q. No. IX. Stopping the working of the mind is Yoga.

Thus we see clearly that in the development of religiouspractice, the fundamental and established philosophical factsare kept as the bases and gradual transitions are prescribedfrom the highest to the lowest stages, bearing always inmind the different grades of Intellect ever found in the practical world. No serious considerations appear to have beenbestowed in this matter in the direction of Archaeological andGeological researches or discoveries, but all importance isattached to the most scientific and practical Psychology,√âthics and physiology of man. Unless we remember thisfact throughout the enquiry of our subject we are sure to fallinto modern pit-falls in the elucidation of Hindu religion.All reasonable criticisms on moral, mental or physiologicalquestions connected with the subject may prove useful atleast to clear any doubts regarding the knowledge ourancients possessed. But all other attempts to pick holes byirrelevant methods will only fall out of the mark and proveunprofitable and uncharitable undertaking.

The very first principle in Hindu Religion here enunciated is this Yoga which is classified into Gnana-yoga andKarma-yoga. It is absolutely necessary to form very clear ideasof these terms to avoid mistakes later on. We have alreadyhad several definitions of them in the previous quotations.The following passages may furnish additional explanations.

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É‡••
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡••

(1) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§π ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ! ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§¨ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§π ‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡••

(2) ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ê‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
