Thevenerable Rishis will not stoop to describe ‘unworthy sights’,under which the whole of the cosmology of the worldlyise man inevitably falls. The Dwipa under reference is.

the devotional sphere which is mentioned as capable of beingseen only like a reflection in the mirror. The perception ofthe geographical divisions of our mother earth, has certainlyno such restrictions or limitations, and it does not stand inneed of the Pandit’s or Critic’s help.

Q. No. III.

“Creation itself is of two kinds, the Dyva and theAsura, the former being that which is accompanied by devotion to Hari, and the latter without it. The seven Dwipasnamely, Jambu, Plaksha, Salmala, Kusa, Krouncha, Sakaand Pushkara are Devabhumis or devine earths, belongingto the Dyva creation.”

The distinction here pointed out settles the whole question. The word Asura is here used, in its ordinary technicalsense. Asu is life and ra is addicted to, referring thereby tothis material world with all its paraphernalia of humanvanities and miseries. It is therefore evident that the religious texts have left it out of consideration altogether. Theworldly-wise Pandit, the modern enlightened historian andarch√¶ologist as well as the mistaken Theosophist, may nowvery well retire from this field, without discredit to theirprofessions and without any loss to the general public.

Q. No. IV.

“The Karma-bhumi refers to the cow known as theVedas. He who rules over it is called a Gopa. This specified Bhumi, no doubt is ever eternal. The Meru, the Dwipasand the Khandas such as Elavrita &c. have in reality noseparate existence”.

The Go or cow, the Karma-bhumi or region of actionand the Vedas are thus synonymous terms used in our religious literature with their specific applications. Withoutunderstanding these simple technicalities of the subject, what

√ó

a funny state of affairs now prevails in the identification ofthe Vedas practically with the geographical earth! ThePandit further believes that this earthy globe is also literallya beautiful cow of the Nellore or Bombay breed. Withthese egregious mistakes for the foundation caused by unalloyed ignorance, ingenious interpretations of the sacredtexts are now-a-days offered from all quarters of the globefor the religious benefit of the indifferent and lazy Hindu,who there by feels exceptionally lucky, as he seldom thinksof finding out anything for himself in this matter. The fallof the modern Hindu having been from a great height, consciously or otherwise, it must certainly have injured himvery seriously. The deterioration is however a real fact,whatever might be the causes attributed. There are differentvarieties of this fallen class among us, some of which maybe styled the orthodox and others the heterodox or moreplainly heretical. The former varieties ordinarily fall underthe uneducated classes and are invariably found to be farinferior even to our veritable pandits. The latter varietiesmake up the majority and include a great portion of themodern educated gentlemen, as well as the indifferent, lowand wicked among the uneducated. The chief object of thisessay is only to appeal to the educated, and the remainingclasses may be conveniently omitted for the present. It isindeed a pity that the majority of this educated class couldbe practically identified with the foreign critic, minus ofcourse, his laudable spirit of enquiry. False, apish andmeaningless imitation is doubtless the ruling fashion of theday with its disgraceful and dangerous consequence of de-nationalisation. Civilization, education or progress, as understood in modern or ancient times, never demands this pernicious tendency. Its dangers are immensely augmented bythe special fact that everything prescribed for a Hindu is

based upon well established fundamental principles of religion, which he has now long forgotten. The possibility ofrediscovering these valuable principles, now or hereafter, fromthese externalforms, is virtually being destroyed by thecurrent mania for foreign imitation. It is humbly hopedthat this will not be misunderstood as preaching superstitionor obstructing progress. Unsuited, unnecessary and extremely inartistic imitations, positive vices, obstinate andignorant indifference to one’s own religion, hardly add toprogress of any known description. The attempt of theeducated gentleman, to conceal his wanton mistake or toexcuse himself on the ground of enlightenment, is as futileas that of the orthodox and the Pandit, and his educationonly holds him all the more responsible. As long as humanreason ordinarily continues to command its due respect, nofalse conduct on the plea of civilization could pass off for atrue coin in any part of the civilized world.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡••

5. It is confidently hoped that the passages quotedall along with regard to the 14 Lokas, the seven islandedearth, the Meru and the Jambu, will be understood as explaining religious matters clearly and unambiguously in thestrongest and plainest terms the Sanskrit language is capableof expressing. The current ideas about them as representingmaterial or physical entities like geographical continentsand mountains are entirely irrelevant. Although it is noteasy to understand them fully, with our very limited knowledge of the subject at present, yet the general classificationsand descriptions are sufficiently comprehensible. The termspoint to some divine matters to be experienced in the progressive advancement of yogic and devotional practicesw

There will no doubt be a good deal of Psychological andphysiological principles underlying them, and the whole of itis some serious science and sacred religion, which could notbe played with in the present fashion. It will be more safeand honourable to leave it alone, if no interest is forthcomingor no knowledge is procurable. It makes no differenee withwhat motive it is misinterpreted. In any case, the process isa mistake and the consequent result is unwholesome in everyway. The terms under reference belong to the Sanskritlanguage, and it would be sheer weakness of the brain toexpect to find their meanings in the dictionaries of alienlanguages. Equally so, is to hope for their explanationsfromforeign creeds like Theosophy preached in the land,especially when they fetch no appreciation in their owncountries. The simple mistake lying at the root of all thisconfusion is in having unnecessarily picked up some religiousterms from the sacred texts, without looking backwards andforwards, a single inch beyond. Opinions are easily andimmediately formed, commentaries and criticisms followedin quick succession, and all possible perversities are inventedto establish the mistaken ideas promulgated. In the longrun, as ir…îny of fate would have it, the mistaken explanations given by these self-constituted interpreters, graduallyled to the present indifference and contempt for the subjecton the whole, being virtually reckoned as old-world superstitions and worthless compilations.

The central island Jambu-Dwipa is described as dividedinto 9 Varshas or continents, the Bharata-Varsha being thesouthernmost one which is now understood as representingIndia. It is this vexed Bharata-Varsha that is at the bottomof all the existing geographical confusion. Detail descriptions of these Varshas are found in most of the Puranas, butnothing more than bare outlines and faint suggestions can

be attempted here. Those who desire to take deeper interestin the matter may apply directly to the texts themselves.But it may be noted here that Bharata-Varsha is to someextent distinctly different in character from the remaining8 Varshas said to be contained in the Jambu-Dwipa. Thefollowing quotations will, it is hoped furnish the requiredexplanations and clues for the correct understanding of thesubject.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§è‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§á‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡§∏‡•å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§É‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É‡•• ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§µ ‡§è‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§Ø‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡••‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ß‡•ã ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§ß‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡•• ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§ï‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§µ ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§™ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§É‡•• ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§® ‡§â‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡••‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‡§è‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§®‡§® ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•Å‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ω‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ω‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§á‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡••

‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. IV.

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ã‡§∑‡§≠‡§É ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡••

‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. V.

‡§ã‡§∑‡§≠‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ã‡§∑‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. VI.

‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VII.

‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. VIII.

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠ ‡§´‡§≤‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§® ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§µ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§π ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§É ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§π ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¢‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. IX

‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Quotation. No. I.

“In the midst of which is Ilavrita with its centreMeru. To the north of Ilavrita are, Ramyaka, Hiranmayaand Kuru Varshas or continents with their respectivemountains, Nila, Sweta, and Sringavan extending to thesaline ocean. To the south are, Hari, Kimpurusha andBharata Varshas, with their mountains Nishadha, Hemakutaand Himalaya, all ten thousand Yojanas in height. To theeast and west of Ilavrita are Ketumal and Bhadraswa. Onthe four sides of Meru are four mountains, Mandara, Meru-mandara, Suparswa and Kumuda. In these there are fourtrees, Chuta, Jambu, Kadamba and Nyegrodha, each onethousand Yojanas in height. There are four ponds filled withmilk. honey, sugarcane juice and water respectively, themere touch of these gives the glorious powers of Yoga.There are also four divine gardens, Nandana, ChithrarathaVybhrajaka and Sarvathobhadra.

Among the nine Varshas, Bharata is Karmakshetra orregion of action. The remaining eight Varshas are theregions of the heavenly beings for the enjoyment of theeffects of the good Karmas performed. The residents ofthese eight Varshas live happily for ten thousand years withtheir wives who beget but one child each at the end. In allthese nine Varshas, Narayana is ever present with hiscollection of Atma-tatwas for bestowing blessings upon theirresidents”.

We have here a detail description of the ever confounded Bharata-varsha. It is one of the nine Varshas in Jambu-Dwipa and is specially known as the region of action. Theremaining eight Varshas are said to be regions of enjoyment.We have already seen that Jambu-Dwipa is a name given tothe devotional sphere. Its nine divisions cannot thereforerefer to anything different from the same. Never mind.What does the Pandit or the critic want to establish withregard to the Bharata-varsha here? If they identify it withIndia, they must be prepared to take the natural consequences. The remaining eight Varshas must then represent theremaining lands on the surface of the earth. Taking theirgeography as given here, where is the Meru in the centre,where are the four mountains round Meru, where the four.trees of one thousand Yojanas in height, the four pondsfilled with milk, honey &c. and where the four celebratedgardens? All these are perhaps myths except Bnarata-varsha. How? Because the critic affirms and the Panditblinks. Where are again the remaining eight Varshas.whose inhabitants continue to live for ten thousand yearsand leave a single child at the end of their term ? This isperhaps mere exaggeration. How is Bharata-varsha theregion of action and how the remaining Varshas places ofenjoyment? This is also perhaps simple nonsense. Is there

any sense after all anywhere in the lengthy descriptionabove given? Have the Pandit and critic reflected uponthe amount of sense they have displayed in having misunderstood divine matters as earthly? Probably they are acquainted with the science of converting heaven into earth,but not vice versa. Let them be assured once for all thatthe regions dealt with here are too far from their reach andthat no amunt of fighting in their unreasonable style couldsecure for them an inch of that sacred ground.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡••

Q. No. II.

“Men and women residing in Bharata-varsha are ofdifferent colours and they worship different gods. Theirlongivity extends only to one hundred years. This Bharatavarsha is nine thousand yojanas in extent. It is the regionof action for the duly qualified. There are four Yugas inthis Bharata-varsha, namely, Krita, Treta, Dwapara andKali, which are not found elsewhere. In the remainingeight varshas, all are youthful and happy, there is no hunger,no grief, no weakness”.

This quotation does not in any way contradict the previous one.If the Pandit still wishes to stick on to his interpretation of Bharata-varsha as applying to India, he willfind that he is the most unfortunate and short lived beingin human creation, as all the people outside Bharata-varshaare said to live happy for a long period of ten thousandyears, without hunger, without grief. His boasted Punnya-bhumi or holy land is alone the most wretched spot, asevery inch of ground outside its boundary on the surface ofthe earth is extremely blessed. Further, his poor Bharata-varsha is subject to the rigour of the four Yugas. Time isfree everywhere else without being limited by the Yugas.

These are doubtless the absurd conclusions to which hisinterpretation inevitably leads, without an atom of useful orsensible meaning, and yet it is almost impossible to convince the Pandit of his mistaken and suicidal obstinacy.

Q. No. III.

“The Bharata-varsha lies to the north of the salineocean and to the south of the Himavat. It is the regionwhere all acts produce their good and bad effects which haveto be enjoyed elsewhere. The Devas even to this day wishto be born in this Bharata-bhumi”.

Here the northern and southern boundaries alone ofBharata-varsha are given. The saline ocean to the south isnot specified by any name. The Pandit may perhaps comeforward here with his perverse ingenuity. Has he anythingto say as to why the effects of acts performed in Bharata-varsha should be enjoyed elsewhere, and why should theDevas who are already in heaven desire to be born here?The saline ocean and the Himavat will be subsequently explained. The Devas here refer to the senses of man in theirpure Satwic nature. They can enjoy divine bliss only bydevotional acts. The worldy transactions procure themonly miseries in the long run.

‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•á‡••

What a serious philosophical fact is here explained inthe Puranic style and what a silly and shameless explanationis presumptuously volunteered by the Pandit?

Quotations No. IV, V, VI & VII.

“Bharata is the son of Rishabha by Meru Devi. Heruled over Mahat-Bharata-Varsha to the south of the Himavat and Bharata-varsha took its name from him. His son

√ó

is named Sumati. Vydyuta, lightning or electricity knownas Lowkik fire is the first son of Bramha. His son is Bramhodana-agni known as Bharata from whom Bharata-varshatook its name. Bharata is the son of Dushyanta bySakuntala from whom Bharata-varsha took its name”.

We have here three different origins of Bharata fromwhom Bharata-varsha took its name. Probably the Pandit,critic and Theosophist have never heard two of these, althoughthe quotations are from recognised Puranas. In QuotationVI Bharata is plainly said to be the son of lightning orelectricity. How can these self-imposed interpreters hopeto understand the highly philosophical and scientific religionwithout its study, and still worse to explain the same withthe preposterous idea that it is human history? The termsRishabha and Meru Devi, Bharata and Sumati, Dushyanthaand Sakuntala, Vydyuta and Bramhodana-agni are alltechnically significant. The Agni here specified can beclearly understood only by knowing the formulas underlyingthe various religious Agni-hotras prescribed by the Vedas.The Theosophist however might anxiously pounce upon thisVydyuta or electricity with his occultism, but unfortunatelyit is now too late. He has long joined the Pandit in hisidentification of Bharata-varsha with India, and the Panditcertainly has no electricity to lend him. If he could condescend to read patiently the subsequent pages of this essay,he would he plainly informed that our religious texts do notdeal with his electricities produced by Hobgoblins and narcotics.

Q. No. VIII.

“Bharata refers to the governing of the subjects according to its root meaning. It is the middle and only regionof action, lying between the ocean and the Himavat. It isthe region of human action prescribed for the attainment of

heaven and emancipation. This Bharata-varsha is dividedinto nine islands surrounded by the sea and inaccessiblefrom one to the other. The nineth island is horizonital inlength. He who conquers it is called a Samraud; and thisLoka itself is known as Samraud, the firmament is Viratand above it is Swaraut”. There is plenty of funny geography here for thePandit and critic to ponder on. TheirIndia is cut up into nine inaccessible islands. Perhaps thesea has since receded in some century A. D. although noGeology has yet established the fact. Anyhow Bharata-varsha is particularly marked as the region of human actionleading to heaven and salvation.

‡§á‡§π ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä‡•§

It would nevertheless be quixotic to plead that all themodern transactions in India lead to heaven. Further, hewho conquers this island becomes a Samraud, above him isVirat, higher still is Swaraut. Can we hope for any sortof enlightenment on these points from our learned interpreters, excepting humbug and abuse? Have they any ideaof the significance of the terms Samraud, Virat and Swarat? It may not be entirely profitless in this connection toexamine the import of these technical terms, as far as couldbe gathered from the religious literature.

‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡••‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡•• ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡••

“The Easwara viewed as the basis of the totality of theeffects of gross creation, is known as Virat; considered as thebasis of the Linga-body made up of the seventeen tatwas,the total effects of subtle creation, He is Swaraut; viewedagain as the basis of Avyakrita which is the cause of boththe above creation, is Samraud”.

We have here obtained fully scientific explanations ofthe technical terms used. The Pandit I fear will still attempt in his usual shameless mood to explain Samraud asreferring to the status of an Emperor who conquers one ofthe nine islands into which India is geographically dividedeven at present. Comments on such persistence would betiresome indeed !!.

Q. No. IX.

“O, king, the Bharata-khanda originally took its namefrom Bharata, son of Rishabha. You must understand thatwhat is made of clay will at last be reduced to clay. Therefore, what is gained by karmas performed with transient materials, such as Kusa grass, ghee &c, can only be impermanent. The wise people consequently look for eternaleffects, which in my opinion could be produced only byDhyana or meditation of the Atman”.

In the above passage, Bharata and Bharata-khandacertainly allude to the devotional karmas as a whole, amongwhich the eternal effects of Dhyana are specially extolled.The name Rishabha constantly mentioned as referring to thefather of Bharata, signifies Dharma usually described as abull in the Puranas. Bharata alluding to the devotionalkarmas must therefore originate from or depend uponDharma. All acts which do not fall within the province ofDharma will not therefore be admitted in Bharata-varsha.

These are the plain facts clearly expressed in the ancientliterature. To the peculiarly developed intellect of themodern day in India, the whole of this however appearsmythic, superstitious and unreasonable. Where are we toseek for the origin of this local tendency for such recklesscriticisms? It would indeed be gross ingratitude to attribute it to the influence of western civilization in India.

√ó

Earnest enquiry combined with deep and thorough studyalways precedes criticisms upon serious subjects in all partsof the civilized world. It has doubtless become a rare exception in India at present. This is certainly one of themost glaring instances of disgraceful and purely apish imitation complained about in this essay.

6. From the above passages, it may be safelyunderstood that Bharata varsha clearly refers to the variouskarmas prescribed by the Vedas, differing in quality andnature so as to suit the capacities and qualifications of thepersons concerned. Variations in the origins of Bharatafrom whom Bharata-varsha is said to have taken its name,point to the differences in the karmas themselves. Similarlythe differences in the times during which the Bharatas aresaid to have ruled refer to the same thing.

** ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§É** (vide ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç.) ‘One whosaves himself from perdition by good acts’. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ signifiesan actor even in the ordinary Dictionary meaning. Theremaining 8 Varshas in the Jambu-Dwipa represent the ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øor 8 Sidhis, the acquisition of extraordinary powersalready described in the preceding pages.

Himalaya the northern boundary of Bharata-varashaprobably represents misty region within which Karmasreside. Beyond Karmas is Gnana on the other side, passingover the Himalayas.

The saline ocean forming the southern boundary ofBharata-varsha and lying round the whole of Jambu-Dwiparepresents the ocean of worldly miseries.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•à‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡••

‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡•å‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§°‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•§
**‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡§≠‡§É‡•• **

**‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ **

***Q. No. IV. ***

‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§®‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§É‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á‡•§
‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ü‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Quotations. No. I& II.

‚ÄúThe lotus-earth with its eight Dic-palas originatedfrom the ocean of Samsara. The ocean in the Jagat described, is the ocean of worldly miseries".

Ideas cannot be clearer and language cannot be plainer,but it is beneath the dignity of the indigenous Pandit tocare for either. He is ever far above the plains of truthand human reason. His ignorance of ordinary geography isan additional misfortune to the religious literature whichhas fallen within his clutches.

Q. No. III.

The poetical description of the analogical details of theocean of Samsara in this quotation is worth reading in theoriginal. A few of the apt analogies given may be noticed.The ocean of grief: The saline waters of tears: The depth

of Karma: The mire of desire: The aquatic animals consisting of ignorance, disease, fear, sorrow &c. This oceancontains an island to be reached by Vedanta on its bank ofAhimsa and truth. The Rishis and Sidhas cross this oceanby the boat of Gnana and reach the pure Akasa. The objectof such descriptions and their significance are easily understood by all mankind excepting perhaps our learned Pandit.The ideas conveyed refer to no strange matters exclusivelyfound in the Sanskrit language.

Q. No. IV.

Samsara is here described as a wild forest instead of thedeep ocean. “The worldly man enters this thick forest, onaccount of his desires to procure wealth, and falls headlonginto a well overgrown with shrubs. He sticks on in thatpainful position to a branch of the Jambu-tree grown inside.He keeps on eating day after day, the fruits of the tree andnever gets satiated. Here the Jambu-tree described is mortality and its fruits are the effects of Karmas performed by man”.

From the above quotations we can more or less understand the ideas conveyed by the oceans, forests and Jambu-trees ordinarily introduced in religious literature.

The saline ocean above described aptly refers to theamount of misery and grief man is subject to in worldlyaffairs. The Jambu-tree represents mortality and its attractive fruits and beautiful creepers entwining it are described as the allurements in this transcient existence. Although the eight Sidhis appear magnificent in comparisonwith the enjoyments of ordinary man, still they fall withinthe bounds of mortality, the desire for them as such leadingonly to re-births and consequent miseries.

We can now clearly understand that Jambu-Dwipa is ageneral term for devotional sphere lying within the privi-

leges of mortal man and that Bharata-varsha specifies theprocesses and scope of devotional Karmas. The remainingeight Varshas of the Jambu-Dwipa represent the blissfuleffects of such good acts, before they fully qualify for finalemancipation. The tangible effects of devotional acts andthe different varieties of status attained by their means aredefinitely established in our ancient religion. Every item ofdescription given is a specific valuable instruction, which ifcorrectly understood and properly acted out, undoubtedlysecures the serious and beneficial results detailed. Call it ascience if you please, but it is a religious science far superiorto the sciences dealing with dead matter. It matters littlewhether the Pandit misinterprets the whole subject as hisvillage geography or the critic stigmatises everything byopprobrious epithets. It makes no difference either, even ifno body believes in it or takes to its practice.

‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•Å‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

**7.**In the apparent geography hitherto examiner,the object of Upasana or worship of God and of His Gloriesin some specific form is described, and also its necessity; itbeing the only means of preparing oneself to be qualified forthe attainment of true knowledge. The various stages inthe philosophical analysis of divine creation are taken intoaccount for this purpose and several methods suitable to thecapacities of the individual are prescribed, with a view to getover the mania for worldly enjoyments. Man’s incapacityto soar high all at once, is an admitted and undisputed factin every religion. He is generally well-known as a Samsari,a sinner or a fallen man. The sphere of Karma or action insome form, high or low, is therefore his natural atmosphere.His actions directed towards God become religious and thosetowards worldly enjoyments especially by objectionable pro-

cesses become irreligious and immoral. By Upasana orworship of God’s glories, man in course of time learns andfeels the insignificance of his own little personality with itslimited desires extending within its trifle existence, and ultimately qualifies himself for the attainment of the highestbliss. The following quotations will doubtless bear testimony to the above facts.

Q. No. I.

‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É‡••

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡•§
‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••

√ó

Q. No. III.

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§£‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç

Q. No. IV.

‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‡§â‡§≠‡•å ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ω‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡•Ç‡§É‡•§
‡§ê‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ó‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ñ‡§†‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡•å‡§∏‡§≤‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ê‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§ó‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q No. V.

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡••

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VI.

‡§∏‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§É‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§®‡•ã ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§¶‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡•á ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ö‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•§
‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§∑‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§®‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡••

Q. No. VII.

‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ \‡•§
‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§É‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§® ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ã ‡§® ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. VIII.

‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§® ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∞‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§™‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Quotation. No. I.

“None can afford to remain a single second without doing something. He is ever compelled by the force ofnature”.

The idea of action here includes everything done bymind and word also. This is an important maxim in ourreligious psychology which is invariably overlooked. Thefalse and presumptuous Vedantism of the stupid, immoralaud wicked, exhibits the total ignorance of this fundamentalprinciple. We have already noticed in the last Chapterthat for a successful march in the right path, there must bethe combined practice of Mano-nasa, Vasana-kshaya andVignana It requires no spectacles to see that the currentVedantism is entirely free from the items specified but thatit is often combined with strictly prohibited ones. The sheerignorance of the necessity of these items, emboldens thehypocrite to preach his so-called Vedantism and lead an ignominious life with ipmunity; and the very same ignorance onthe part of the Hindu public becomes the source, of toleration for the existence of such miscreants and even of theirveneration at times.

Q. No. II.

“The Apara or secondary form of Mukti which leads tothe ultimate emancipation is obtained by Karma or actiononly. It is external by acts of word or deed and internalby meditation of Brahman as constituting everything.There is no doubt that Gnana as opposed to Karma is virtually the highest form of worship, but it cannot suit thegenerality of mankind who are sinners. All forms of worship prescribed in the Vedas and Tantras as well as thosepractised by Budhists, Jains or others, with devotional spirit,

are all beneficial to mankind and are recognised as fallingunder religious Karmas‚Äù.

What a cosmopolitan view is here proclaimed in ourreligion, and why does any critic venture to cry it down assectarian? When a scientific necessity for worship in someform is clearly established in these passages, why is it criticised as superstitious? The critic is probably ashamed toconfess that he is a sinner as pointed out here. No one,however, dares to question his real merits, but let him satisfyhis own conscience first on this point, before he attempts tocondemn or ignore the rigorous religious maxim here enunciated.

Q. No. III.

“The different Karmas leading to heaven and otherblissful states which are comparatively insignificant andtransient, are prescribed by the wise, in consideration of thedefective qualifications of mankind for the highest goal.The devotional processes are therefore divided into Karmaand Gnana dealing with the Atman as Murthis or forms andas Sabda-bramhan, for the benefit of mankind”.

The cogent reason for the secondary step adopted ishere clearly explained. The venerable Rishis are not therefore ignorant of the higher philosophical stage, nor are theyunaware of the limited qualifications of the masses. Theyknew very well the capacities of the Pandit and the critic,but only they are not known correctly by our modernauthorities.

Q. No. IV.

“There are two varieties of the Lord’s glory, the Bhogaand the Lila. The former is eternal and refers to the Nirguna and the three-quarter lying above the latter, which is

the remaining quarter, referring to the existing universe,treated as ephemeral in philosophy and as originating fromPrakriti. When this Lila or display of Prakriti is annihilated, the Bhoga is attained. The boundary between thesetwo regions is the Viraja river whose waters are producedby the sweat of knowledge and devotion. Beyond thisriver lies the Para-vyoma or three-quarter glory known bythe synonyms, Akshara, Parama, Dhama, Vykuntha, Saswataand Pada. Between this region and the river is calledKevals, the special region intended for those meditatingupon Avyakta-Bramhan or Bramhan in the form of infinity.In the middle of this region is the divine town calledAyodhya known as Yoga-pittha and made up of all theholy letters. In the centre of this there is a lotus of eightpetals,. the pericarp of which is Savithri in which Easwararesides with his Saktis, namely, Vimalotkarshini, Gnana,Kriya, Yoga, Prahwi, Satya and Esana. The Lokas, thevarious surrounding enclosures and the equipages in theregion of higher glory are detailed below. The eight cardinal points beginning with the East respectively contains Vaikuntha, the region of Vasudeva, then that of Lekshmi, Sankarshana, Saraswati, Pradyumna, Reti, Anirudha and Santi.This completes the first enclosure. The second enclosurecontains the lokas of Prahlada and other great devotees, thethird, those of Matsya, Kurma &c., the fourth those ofSatya, Achuta, Ananta, Durga, Vishwaksena, Ganesa, andcontains also the valuable mines known as Sankha, Padma& c. The fifth consists of the lokas of the Vedas, Savithri,Geruda, Dharma and Makha. The sixth refers to the lokasof the weapons such as chakra, sword & c. The seventh isthe region of the eight Dik-palas, Sadhyas, Maruths, Viswedevas and other Devas. The Devas in the heaven of Prakriti are not similarly eternal. The incarnations of the Lord,

√ó

such as Matsya, Kurma etc, are the forms of His gloriesprescribe for religious worship.”

We have here a general geography in detail. TheLord’s glory is divided into two parts, one quarter below,subject to the laws of Prakriti and three quarters abovebeyond the reach of Prakriti. The boundary river separatingthe two regions is called Viraja on the other bank of whichis the town of Ayodhya. Is the Pandit here going to identify this river with the modern Sarayu in Upper India ? TheViraja however is the boundary between ephemeral andeternal existence and its waters are made up of the sweat ofdevotional emotions. The word Viraja clearly denotesSatwa, beyond Rejas and Tamas. Who compells any Panditto talk nonsense if he does not know the subject? If hedoes not create unnecessary confusion, others have bettercommon sense to find out the correct application of thesedescriptions without much difficulty. It is clearly explainedin the texts themselves, and none need fear the existence ofany occultisms placed around it. The remaini g details ofgeography given are clearly mentioned as prescribed forreligious worship. The proper scientific reasons assigned forthem could be discovered by a study of the subject as in allother worldly matters, but never by a contemptuous rejection of the subject altogether. Its importance is not a whit diminished by such irreligious vandalism, and the modernpreponderance of the materialistic tendency at the verybottom has alone to be pitied. The most useful and valuablestudy long provided for the real benefit of man is being nowneglected not only by sheer ignorance, but curiously enough,on the pretext of having discovered its worthlessness by theforce of modern civilization. It is verily one of the greatestwonders of this lucky twentieth century, if all our religiousliterature has become so transparent that modern civilization

can see through it all its serious defects, even without aglance of the same.

Q. No. V

“The Atma divided itself into four parts, three partsof which reinained in the Paramom-vyoma or pure Akasa.The remaining quarter known as Anirudha originatedPrakriti for the purpose of creating the Jagat. This description of creation must be understood as explaining the wayfor emancipation by the union of Jivatma and Paramatma.In whatever form the Bramhan is worshipped, the devoteeattains that form, therefore Bramhan should be worshippedas the Purusha by meditating that the self is Bramhan”.

The creation here specified is required to be understoodas Srishti-yegna, or a process of worship for the attainmentof Salvation. Could the Pandit, critic or Theosophist pointout a single word here which refers to their India, Tibet orthe submerged islands of the Atlantic ocean? The originaltext wants us to understand the description as an Yegna orworship and the modern interpreters insist on overruling theauthors themselves by explaining it as their earthly geography. This is indeed a novel and funny method of writingcommentaries on a subject. The enlightened interepreterscould more wisely have taken to the production of valuableoriginal texts themselves, without losing their self-respectby such demeaning task. They would have been veneratedas the modern Rishis of the twentieth century far wiser thanthe useless fossils of the time-barred old world. They mighthowever have to retire to the forest before they can think ofsuch a work, and the idea of leaving this happy and progressing material world is certainly opposed to modern taste andfashion. The best method of evading all these unnecessary

difficulties is by bidding farewell to this troublesome literature under reference. By so doing, they would of course beconferring a great boon on the poor religious Hindu. Thesubject on the whole is not to their temperament or taste andtheir present interference is only a frightful assistance.

‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VI.

“In the Puranas, the five subtle elements are describedin their separate individual states. The last element, theearth is said to be only one-tenth in extent as compared withwater. Fire is ten times greater than water, but is only one-tenth of air. The Akasa is ten times greater than air. Thesubtle element earth is ten times greater than the Bramhandawithin it which contains the 14 Lokas. Akasa, the greatestelement is itself nonexistent, as the eternal substance orBramhan can have no Akasa, hole or vacuum. Withoutphilosophical enquiry, this Akasa might appear as true, thatis the force of Maya; but even after its non-existence isknown, we are prone to feel otherwise at times on accountof doubts and absense of concentration of thought. Byrepeatedly reading philosophy, thinking and meditating, wewill become certain of its nonexistence. The next elementair is only one-tenth of this Akasa and is therefore equallyfalse. In this manner, comingdown to the lowest and themost insignificant cosmology of man, the immensity of theglory of Bramhan will be known. This is the way to become a Jivan-mukta”.

The above is practically the real commentary upon thePuranic descriptions of the apparent geography detailed.The Brainhanda itself is measured out as only one-tenth ofthe subtle earth, the other elements above being ten timesguester in succession. These representthe glories of Bram-

han. The modern Pandit however can measure the grandphilosophical religion of his venerable forefathers, only withhis village geography. He would be doing great good tohimself, if he only finds out first his own real position inour religious geography. He is not even a man of thisworld, much less of the one beyond. He has virtuallyreduced himself to one of the inutilities of a nation at present, and let him understand as soon as possible, that inthese days of rapid progress, standing still means immenseretrogression. Let him take the following warning in goodparts, lest his species soon become extinct.

“If of life you keep a care
Shake off slumber and beware”.

Q. No. VII.

“That nothing could be obtained by man without theblessing of the perfect and infinite Lord, is the settled opinion of the wise. Man is ever dependent and wants theblessings of the Lord, whose real nature as Nishkala orformless is known to him only through the Sastras. TheMoorthi or form of the Lord is therefore important as it is his real sign or mark, whose worship soon leads to hisformless nature. Whenever fire is required, it is availableonly as combined with a burning piece of wood and forthat reason it is not uncared for. Similarly the Lord shouldbe worshiped in his form or moorthi’.

The use of Upasana or worship of the glories of God ishere explained, and all propogators of iconoclasm may takenote of this passage. To approach the perfect and infiniteGod with the impure and finite mind of man, is a psycholological impossibility. To secure fire free from wood or othermaterials, is a physical impossibility. How does the modernscience propose to solve the problem? Throw the whole case into the waste-paper basket or light a match and

dispose of it in a minute. These are perhaps the easiestmetho ls of getting over the difficulty. The natural presumption here is, that either something rotten lies at the bottomof the boasted science of the modern day or something iswrong in the brain of its professor. The scientist generallydevises means to take refuge in the terminus of science, onthe plea that questions of this kind do not fall within theprovince of his professed subject. So far however he maybe reckoned as honest and honourable, but his occasionalattempts to corrodo religion by the use of his science whichhe has admitted to be inapplicable, are surely inexplicable.Science is not irreligion, and he may be prepared to meet hisown science one day dictating unpalatable lessons to himconcerning his iconoclastic theory. Ordinary miseries ofeveryday occurrence in this material world, often succeedin overthrowing the fondest theories of the scientist, moreeasily and more quickly than his own science.

‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡••

Q. No. VIII.

“The wise say that it is not practicable to display ourlove towards the formless and to proceed without a hold onsomething. The Lord in some form can be served withgreat pleasure and such worship will doubtless lead to theknowledge of his formless nature. The meditation of theLord in form produces unbounded joy, and emancipation orMukti must dance attendance before the devotional ecstasy,Besides, how is man going to expiate his sins committedthrough mind, word and deed except by such worship? Bypraying to God and by praising His glories, the sins accumulated by talk would be annihilated. Mental sins would bedestroyed by meditating on his glories. Sins by acts would

be removed by perforining the various religions and ethicalduties prescribed Karma or religious action has been longordained by God for the benefit of mankind”.

The utility and necessity of idolatry in some form arehere reiterated. The devotional acts by mind, word anddeed are said to expiate the sins committed by the respectiveorgans. Even in worldly transactions, this appears to be areasonable suggestion. In all the religious instructionsoffered, the removal of sins appears as the condition precedent to the attainment of real knowledge. Accumulationof more sins is never found mentioned anywhers, although,that is more or less what is being done on the plea ofVedantisin. If the modern civilized gentleman is howeverconvinced that he has no sius to atone for, he can very wellafford to ignore these teachings as superstitious and unscientific. But to the poor sinner, they are valuable asmeans to escape from the rigorous laws of Karma.

8. Most philosophical and practical reasons areassigned for the necessity of Upasana or worship in theabove quotations and various reasonable and suitablemethods are prescribed for the benefit of mankind in general.The expiation of the sum total of sins voluntarily accumulated in the various births, is an unavoidable preliminarystep which cannot be got over by tricks or humbug. Quotation IV clearly defines the geography of Ayodhya asbeyond the regions of mundane existence. Several otherfamiliar names of places, persons and objects are similarlydescribed there. More of this shall be treated in their respective sections.

We have by this time sufficiently investigate the significance of Bharata-varsha, now known only as the continentof India; and have clearly understood that it unequivocally

refers to the process of Upasana or worship performed inaccordance with the instructions obtained from the Vedas.We may now proceed with our enquiry regarding the application of terms now understood as denoting countries, townsan l holy centres within the boan laries of Bharata-Varsha.Wehave alreaty seen what Ayodhya mans. ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ. The invulnerable or not easily attainable stage.‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ The seat of Gods is Ayodhya.

For the main purpose of this little essay, the situationof Ayodhya detailed above will have to be particularlyremembered, with a view to understand the capital of thesovereigns of the Surya-vamsa or solar dynasty who aresaid to have ruled over Bharata-Varsha or so-called India.The next important place for the same reason, is Kurukshetram, Hastinapura or Delhi, the capital of the sovereigns ofthe Soma-vamsaor Lunar Dynasty. Bat there is a sort ofgeographical confusion in the description of Kurukshetromand the sacred Benares. Both of them will therefore haveto be treated together.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§™‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≤‡•á‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. II.

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡••

‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No.III.

‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§É ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§≠‡•É‡§û‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ñ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. IV.

‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§§‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. V.

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•á‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§π‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§É‡•§
