‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. I

** **‚ÄúVasishta said, ‘Oking’, I shall describe to you the mental Thirthas or holybaths, by bathingwell in which, man attains emartcipation.Truthfulness is & Thittha, so is

forgiveness, control of the senses, mercy, straightforwardness, charity, contentment, Dhyana, devotion to Siva etc.The highest among the Thirthas is purity of mind, becausesimple dipping of the body in water is not recognised as aholy bath.A cruel, haughty, sensual, miserly wretch,never gets purified by bathing in all the sacred rivers orother baths. He is still a dirty sinner as before. Theaquatic animals born and dying in water, do not on thataccount get their minds purified or obtain salvation. Intensedesire for worldly pleasures is known as mental impurity;its removal is mental purification. The place in which amentally purified person resides, is really the Nimisa, Pushkara and Kuru-kshetra. The mental Thirtha is filled withthe water of Dhyana, purified by gnana and capable of
washing away the dirt of desire, anger etc. He who bathesin this Thirtha is sure to obtain liberation”.

Q. No. II.

Snana or religious bath means removal of mentalimpurity and soucha or cleanliness means controlling thesenses. Merely washing the body with water and clay isbut the worldly bath. The dirt of egoism sticking on allover the body should be washed away by the water and clay,of gnana or knowledge, and vyragya or freedom frompassion. The meditation of the Tatwas is the highest, studyof the Sastras ranks next and that of Manthras is thelast. The mania for the external holy baths is the lowest.”

Q. No. III.

“The internal Thirthas are more important than theexternal ones. Atma-thirtha is the highest, all the rest areuseless. Bathing in the external Thirthas with an evil mindinside, never procures purity. A pot containing toddy neverbecomes pure by any amount of washing outside”.

Thirtha generally means a remedy, means or expedient.In religion, it especially refers to all the processes of purification prescribed. The term is applied therefore to both internal and external purifications The modern mistakelies in interpreting it as dealing with the external purifications alone. From the above quotations, we have seen thatthe external processes as such, are of no avail, unless accompanied by internal purifications. The texts speak veryclearly on the point, and the modern interpreters thereforeboldly explain otherwise.

** 12.**The extreme importance of moral rectitude, charity and sincere religious devotion is established by theabove passages as opposed to hypocracy and mere externalcleanliness. In spite of the very strong language used inthese quotations, it is however a very interesting point tonote, how the idea of baths in holy centres as a religioussubstitute for, or a supplement to, the canons enunciatedabove, struck the ancients, in the interest of the lower ordersof society. The subjoined quotations assign simple reasons,sufficiently scientific and convincing, so as to induce everyreasonable person to appreciate the necessity and advantageof resorting to these Thirthas.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§≤‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. I.

“Water is by nature pure and purifying. It is the life-giving food for all created things. All the Vedas say thatwater is the form of Narayana”,

Q. No. II.

‚ÄúBathing in water accelerates digestion, increases strength and rernoves itch, dirt, sweat, laziness, thirst, heat andsin".

The use of water as an external purifier is vividly explained here. No other element could possibly be substituted for the purpose, and hence water and bath constitutethe chief items in external purification.

Q No. III.

“I shall narrate to you the reasons assigned for thesacredness of the holy centres established in the various parts of the country. In the human body itself, some partsare considered good and others not so. Similarly some portions of the earth are good and others bad. The Thirthasare established in consideration of this important fact.Some places are healthy by nature and sometimes possessrare and convenient situations and contain excellent water,

Combined with these, there must be another essentialcondition, namely, the recognition by the great Rishis.All such Thirthas are sacred and should be visited. But themental Thirthas already enumerated must always be attended to. One who takes to both the Thirthas will attainsalvation”.

** 13**. The above passages deserve and demand themost patient and careful scrutiny; and it must be emphatically affirmed that they do not confirm or even corroboratethe current interpretations, assigning historical importanceto the Holy centres in India and connecting them with specific descriptions found in the Puranas and Itihasas, takingthem as representing places of historical incidents. In theface of the so-called geography examined already, it is unnecessary at this stage to reiterate the arguments for theconviction of any reasonable being as to the absurdity andirrelevancy of the modern views. The only point for useful enquiry here would be to trace the causes that led to thesemistakes.

We have seen all along, that the procedure adopted inour sacred literature was to descend step by step from thehighest philosophical truths to suit the varying intellectualcapacities of man, without at the same time losing sight ofthe main goal. The Puranas and Itihasas took up theVedas and served as their commentaries, treating the purely philosophical truths, in accordance with certain definiteformulas prescribed in the Vedas themselves, and consistentlyfollowed throughout.The abstract ideas were to someextent concretised and narrated in the garb of Divine histories and geographies. The subsequent pages of this book,will it is hoped make this clearer still. In the meantime,something must be said at this stage regarding the identification of certain places in India with the names found in

the literature. For the very commencement of religiouspractice, the purification of mind and body was found anecessary preliminary step, owing to the degeneracy of manas he is at present, and the two distinct processes above detailed were formulated. As regards the means for externalpurification, the efficacy of good water, none can deny. Theinfluence of healthy forests, fresh air and enchanting scenerycombined with beautiful temples situated in the adjoininglocalities, where abundance of fresh water is procurable inthe shape of falls and running rivers, will certainly be admitted by all, as not only exhilerating to the physical bodybut also soothing and ennobling to the worry-ridden mind.This is exactly the sum and substance of the quotationsreproduced above. Any further twisting of their meaningis unwarranted by the texts and therefore unauthorised.The application of certain terms from the literature, asnames to places or persons, cannot certainly be an exeuse fortheir misinterpretation. The names of Gods invariablyfound applied to all the Hindus, will not justify their stylingthemselves as Gods in comparison with the human beingselsewhere. No more serious argument is required to establish the mistakes in the confounding of earthy spots inIndia with the ideas conveyed by certain religious andphilosophical terms, especially when their meanings are unknown and unsought for. It is equally absurd and insultingto be told that religious centres and holy baths exist only inIndia and all outside is unholy. On the contrary, if westick on to the current interpretations, the passages hithertoreproduced will clearly prove that everything outside Indiais bliss and happiness and everything within is ephemeraland miserable. The eternal and blissful region is describedas lying to the north and beyond the Himalayas. VideMaha Bharatom Santi-parva.

‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

Hundreds of cases like this may be quoted if necessaryillustrating the absurdity of the modern interpretation. Infact, the localities, their dimensions and other descriptionsgiven in the texts, seldom correspond, and are never meantto correspond, with the modern attempted identifications.The river Saraswathy mentioned in the Puranas had certainly no physical existence at all, but it is now explainedas Antar-vahiny or running underground unseen at Allahabad. The impossible junction of Kaveri in Deccan andNarbuda in Central Provinces, as also the situation of Dwaraka described as on the banks of the Jumna and within theboundaries of Indraprasta or Delhi, found mentioned in thesubjoined quotation will certainly take our Pandits by surprise.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡••

‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The subsequent applications of these terms as names tocommon objects might have been for the purpose of familiarising the public with their usage and set them athinking,at least in their leisurely moments. It is no doubt aningenious method of spreading the higher philosophicaltruths among the ordinary people to give them a sort ofcurrency and permanency which could never be expected by

mere publication of books or even by preaching. The stories often utilized as models for religious and moralinstructions tend to keep them in memory as they haveactually done. The majority knows them only in thismanner, but a very limited minority might have heard thePuranas read and explained on religious and festive occasions.Somehow, a great portion of the literature has become incourse of time, the household property of every Hindufamily. The highest gratitude of every pious Hindu is therefore due to the wise and venerable sages for the great boonthus rendered. But the Pandit who stands in the way offurther progress, which the far-seeing Rishis certainly hadin view, is liable for his uncalled for interference and unprivileged forwardness in thrusting in, his misinterpretations.

The new alien creed styled Theosophy which is generally misunderstood as supporting Hindu religion, is equallyresponsible for voluntarily propogating mistaken theories inthe land pertaining to the contents of our sacred literature.It is certainly too late now for its disciples to conceal ignorance with occultisms and secret doctrines. The mistakescommitted with regard to the point in question are exactlysteriotyped repetitions of our local Pandits, and do not even exhibit an atom of originality in them, in spite of theirstrenuous efforts to give them a scientific shape. The usualmistakes lie at the bottorn and are irremediable at the topFor the purpose of offering convincing and conclusive proofof this fact, it will suffice at this juncture to illustrate oneserious and important blunder exhibited by Theosophicalignorance of the so-called geography in our sacred literature.

The subjoined quotation from Mrs. Besant’s Sanathana Dharma, page 234, will bear ample testimony to thetruth of the above remarks, Many a repeated identificationof Bharata Varsha with India by Mrs. Besant, within he

small para itself here reproduced, is verily the oldest rottenmistake of our local wise acres.

“In the ancient days Jivatma was prepared for entranceinto each caste through a long preliminary stage outsideIndia; then he was born into India and passed into eachcaste to receive its definite lessons; then was born away from India to practise these lessons; usually returning toIndia to the highest of them, in the final stages of hisevolution”.

It is however desirable to find out if possible whetherthere are any cogent reasons for describing in the sacredtexts, certain philosophical ideas in the form of cities, mountains and rivers and giving thern an appearance of geographical treatment. It must be clearly remembered that they areinvariably mentioned as divine and not earthly as we havealready seen. Their venerable authors are not thereforeresponsible for the modern confusion of these with terrestrialobjects. High abstract truths which will not permit ofbeing easily expressed in human language had to be somehow explained.

‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

“There is no scope for question or answer in the languageof Adwitom. The language of Dwitom is the only availablemedium for such purpose”. The material world is thereforethe last resort for their analogical illustrations. Thus,certain religious and philosophical ideas were treated asGods, especially those representing the spiritual or efficientcauses in the philosophical analysis of creation and evolution.For the same reason the transformations of Prakriti ormaterial cause or the Tatwas as they are styled, had to be

described as the region of Gods, in the form of divinecities, divine mountains and divine rivers &c. Again, themain difficulty was not completely overcome. The forms
of Gods are yet unknown and they were represented in thebest imaginable form of man, with necessary alterations,additions and paraphernalia, the details of which shall betreated in the subsequent section III of this chapter. In thesame manner, the devine cities, hilis and rivers could onlyresemble the earthly ones, with necessary alterations in size,colour and material &c. In the Yoga sastras, the nervouscentres which form the physiological bases for the aboveTatwas were often described as mountains and Peattas orseats, and the never ending currents of Vasanas, thoughts orbreath were naturally represented as ever-coursing rivers,
carrying with them everything they catch on their way totheir ultimate destination. We have already seen thatGanga, Yamuna and Saraswati represent, Ida, Pingala andSushumna Nadis, and that the water in the Viraja river is made up of the sweat of religious devotion.

‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡••

‡§ó‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

“The hollow through the spinal column is the BramhaNadi called Sushumna lying between Ida and Pingala. Thesun, moon, fire, Eswara, elements, Lokas, Dwipas, oceans,mountains, all lie within this Nadi; also the Vedas. Sastras,Puranas, Manthras &c. Its roots are above and the branchesare below. Out of the seventy-two thousand Nadis in thehuman body through which air courses, the Sushumna aloneis the Sakti of Siva, the rest are useless”.

The current mistakes could not however have arisen fromthis unavoidable method of treatment. The subsequenterection of temples and location of Bhowmathirthas, withthe terms in question applied to them as names, have givenan opportunity for confusion of facts, virtually for puttingthe cart before the horse. Neither the cart nor the horsewas a mistaken factor, but the mistake occurred in their misplacement. As matters are now interpreted, they have cometo mean that Vishnu originated after the temple at Srirangomwas constructed and Siva after that of Benares andnot the temples after them. The Sthala-puranas of suchplaces are also now completely misinterpreted and are exactlyabused and ill-treated like the Puranas themselves. Noneof them I dare say narrate any absurd and irrelevant storiesas now generally explained, but they very reasonably andingeniously furnish clues to the exact meanings of certaindefinite facts and formulas hitherto detailed. The Thirthasas a class invariably refer to Varana and Asi as in Benares.

The same story is repeated with slightly altered descriptionsto suit the differences of local conditions and necessities. Theproof of all this fact is but a simple matter of unbiased andsympathetic investigation; and I must entirely leave it tothe judgment of those who are sincerely interested in thesubject. In consideration of the limited scope of this littleessay, I cannot help ending the present section here. Hadit not been for the immense amount of irremediable confusionproduced by the mistaken interpretations of this religiousand philosophical geography, I would certainly have stoppedmuch earlier.

————————————

SECTION II.

ON TIME.

1. The main divisions of Time represented in oursacred literature are; Parardhas, Kalpas, Manwantaras,Yugas and the cycle of 60 years commencing with Prabhava. A more general classification of it is into Sthula and Sukshma, gross and subtle. This latter classification will have tobe first examined, as it is the foundation for the varied descriptions given, in accordance with the usual formulas
always followed for the purpose of expressing abstractmatters in more concrete terms. It is simply the ignoranceof these formulas that has led to the present confusions. Itmust however be admitted that such restrictions and limitations in the meanings of terms used in the treatment of anyscientific subject, are unavoidable even in the material sphere,and the necessity and plea for such a procedure is thereforegreater in the spiritual sciences. It is probable that theexistence itself of such a distinction in the calculations of

time might surprise our learned Pandits, but nevertheless, itis a bare fact in reference to the literature in question withwhich they are not perhaps sufficiently acquainted, owing tofalse dignity or for other serious reasons.

The following quotations denote the necessary methodfor understanding some of the given descriptions whichappear as pertaining to Time.

Quotation No. I.

‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∂‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç
‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q No. III.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. IV.

‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§≠‡•å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•å ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Quotation. No. I.

“The currents of breath may be controlled by the forceof mind. The breath ordinarily passes alternately throughthe left and right nostrils for three Nadikas at a time; andthe Yogi should base upon this fact, his internal calculationsof time regarding day and night, fortnight, month andAyanas”.

This Upanishad here is very clear in its postulation ofa formula for the Yogis, to calculate their own time as different from that of the ordinary man. The Pandit might particularly take note of the fact here, that the ancient Rishiswhose favourite residence was the forest, had more than onecloth to wear, but that in spite of his living in the town, hehas only one, with nothing to spare.

Q. No. II.

“The Ida or current of breath through the left nostril istechnically called the Moon, and Pingala on the right isknown as the Sun. The passing of breath from the rightto the left is also technically known among philosophersas Uttarayana. The reverse is Dekshinayana. The junctionof Ida and Pingala is Amavasya or new moon. When thelife breath reaches Muladhar, it is Vishuva or the New Year’sday. Inspiration and exhalation are beginnings of months.When the life-breath passes to Kundalini through Ida, it isLunar Eclipse, and through Pingala it is Solar Eclipse. Inthese specified holy times, such as Vishuva, Ayana, Eclipse&c., if one bathes in the similarly specified centres in thebody, such as Varanasi etc, he is sure to be purified”.

The above is indeed a double bombardument upon themodern interpretations of our religious times and places. Ifthe ignorant and impudent interpreters hope to escape fromthis, more shall be soon kept ready for them.

Q. No. III.

“That which creates time itself, which is the realcause of the creation and destruction of the Devas and othercreatures, is here known as time. When such time is preserved, creations and destructions vanish. Some create withthis time, others get entangled in it. There are two kindsof time, the Sthula and the Sukshma, the former is meantfor the worldly and the latter for the Yogis. The Sthulais again calculated in two ways; by the lunar rotations forman and by the solar for the Devas. The calculation fromthe Prithivi Tatwa to Siva Tatwa is known as Satwa kalaor time, pertaining to the gradual involutions of the Tatwasnamely of, Eswara, Atma, Sadasiva, Nadanta and Sakti upto Siva Tatwa. Three Sukshma breaths make one SukshmaPrana, and six such Pranas make oue Sukshma Ghatika,and sixty such Ghatikas make one Sukshma day. Furthercalculations of Pakshas, months and years go by the samemultiples ordinarily used for Sthula time. The involutionof the Devas and Bramha is calculated in Sukshma time, asalso the work of the Gnanis and Yogis”.

The divine energy that creates time itself is known asTime here. Three distinct varieties of this Time are hereelearly explained as the Sthula, the Sukshina and the Satwa.The Satwa refers to the involutions of the religious Tatwaswhich are entirely unknown factors to the modern interpreters of our sacred religion. The Sukshma is mentioned aspertaining exclusively to the Devas, Bramha, Gnanis andYogis. The modern Pandit and critic who belong to noneof these specified classes, ignorantly misapply the Sukshma

time to their own Sthula variety, which alone they haveevidently heard of hitherto. They are therefore entirelymistaken at the very foundation, and their ignorant presumption that all our religious and philosophical texts describeonly their householl affairs, certainly displays the most idiotic impertinence that one can imagine.

Q No. IV.

“Thus the Yoga of meditation has to be continued,until the ultimate Bramhan is reached. The two pathsprescribed for this Yoga should be followed, the one which
takes to the highest stage through the Sukshma Nadi isknown as Uttarayana and the human body is known asSamvatsara or year.”

The significance of our religious time is evidently becoming more and more irksome to the Pandit and hiscolleagues. The human body is here explained as the year.‘‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É’. Samvatsara or year is Prajapathy." ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§É" That withinwhich everything resides is Samvatsara. These are surelyquotations which are more than the modern Pandit couldbear. The only conception of the Samvatsara he is capableof, is the occurrence of the anniversaries in his house and the prospect of filling the stomach with bread and cake on theoccassions.The sacred religious literature bequeathed to usby our ancient sages, is so voluminous and so full of usefulinstructions conveyed in the simplest and clearest possiblelanguage, that it is indeed a pity that the Pandit with allhis Sanskrit learning is not destined to swallow and digest asingle useful drop out of it, so as to save himself from endless perdition.

‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡•à‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•É‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡•á
‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡§ï‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§É‡••

** 2.** It is evident from the above quotations that thecalculation of time found detailed in the sacred texts clearlyrefer to its Sukshma form and represent the functions ofthought and breath as regulated by Yogic processes. Thegeneral terms of measurement however are retained as thesame in the treatment of both Sthula and Sukshma varieties,and a sort of analogical comparison is maintained with a viewto utilise the Sthula form for the practical benefit of theless qualified classes. The concretised forms and the ritualistic ceremonies of the Karma-kanda are based upon theseanalogical formulas and are consciously prescribed for thepurpose of attaining certain definite aims in the gradualprogress of religious practice. They are certainly not theaimless outcome of the whims and caprices of our venerablesages, nor are they useless and unscientific superstitions asthey are so lightly and conveniently pronounced in moderndays. The mere fancy or even respect for material sciencecannot form an excuse for off-hand criticisms of any facts ortheories without proper scientific investigations, and suchcriticisms in themselves are no signs of originality or respectable intelligence. ‘Critics all are ready made,’ and no bodyneed therefore care for them. The following passages enumerate the different divisions of time as described in the texts.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§≤‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∂‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§ö‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•à‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≤‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡•§
‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡§É‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡§≤‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ú‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§®‡•Ä ‡§â‡§≠‡•á I
‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•§
‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§®‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∂‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§É I
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•§

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡•§

‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•§

‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∂‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ ‡§ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§∑ ‡§¶‡•à‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç ‡§®‡•É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡•§

‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§ü‡•ã‡§™ ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑ ‡§â‡§™‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§õ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡••

‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

Quotation. No. I.

“Nimesha is the time taken to open and close the eyesin the normal condition. 1/4 of this is a Tuti; 2 Tutis make1 Lava; 2 Lavas make 1 Nimesha; 15 Nimeshas,. 1 Kashta;30 Kashtas, 1 Kala; 1/2 Kala, 1 Kshena; 2 Kshenas, 1 Muhurtha; 1/2 Muhurtha, 1 Ghatika by which everything ismeasured. 3¬æ Ghatikas make 1 Sandhi; 2 Sandhis, 1Yama; 4 Yamas, the day time”.

The scale of time for the divisions of the day time startswith Nimesha or the twink-ling of the eye, one-fourth ofwhich is called Tuti, the lowest in the scale equal to about13 seconds. This is the scale for the ordinary calculation ofhuman time.

Q. No. II.

“The ultimate Bramhan is doubtless without form, without change, without attributes. The conception of thesmallest atoms or Paramanus as originating from this Bramhan is only a deductive inference. Both the Sthula and theSukshma forms of time are thus inferred. The smallestamount of time that pervades over a Paramanu is also calledParamanu. 2 Anus make 1 Paramanu and 3 Anus 1 Tresarenu which is the smallest atom that could be perceived inthe ray of sun’s light passing through a window. The timethat pervades over 3 Tresarenus is known as a Truti, 1/10of it is 1 Vedha; 3 Trutis, make 1 Lava; 3 Lavas, 1 Nimesha; 3 Nimeshas, 1 Kshena; 5 Kshenas, 1 Kashta; 15Kshenas, 1 Leghuta; 15 Leghutas, 1 Nadika; 2 Nadikas,1 Muhurta; 6 or 7 Nadikas, 1 Yama; 4 Yamas a day and4 Yamas one night. A Yama is measured by the flow ofone Presta of water through a small hole in a vessel. 15days make 1 Paksha, 2 Pakshas, 1 month or the day andnight of the Pitris. 2 months make 1 Rethu. 6 monthsmake 1 Ayana and 2 Ayanas, the Dekshina and Uttara37

make 1 year, the day and night of the Devas. 100 years isthe longivity of man. The universe including the planets,stars &c., is thus made up of Paramanus. Samvathsara,Parivatsara, Idavatsara, Anuvatsara and Vatsara are thevarieties of the year”.

“Vidura said‚Äî You have now described to me the divisions of time pertaining to man, Pitris and Devas. Kindlytell me the nature and method of calculation of time asapplying to others, who by their Yogic knowledge keep outof its limitations as just explained.

Mytreya said ‚Äî The Yugas named Krita, Treta, Dwapara and Kali made up of 12,000 divine years apply to them.The Yugas consist of 4, 3, 2 and 1 thousand years, respectively, excluding 2000 years allowed for their mutual junctures Leaving the period for such junctions, the intervalsin which Dharma rules, is recognised by the wise as Yugas.This Dharma is complete in the Krita Yuga and diminishesby 1, 2 and 3 quarters respectively in the remaining Yugas.A thousand cycles of these four Yugas make one day forBramha, outside the first three Lokas. The same periodextends over his night. During the day time 14 Manus rulefor about 71 Chatur-yugas. each, during which Rishis andDevas are born. This is the daily creation by Bramha extending to the three Lokas. At the end of each day the threeLokas are burned down by the fire of Samkarshana andcovered by the ocean, agitated by the air. The Bhrigus andothers, at the time remove themselves from Mahar to Jenoloka. The days and nights of Bramha are thus calculatedup to 100 years as if his age is limited by that period.Half of his age is known as a Parardha. The first half ispassed which is called Bramha-kalpa when Bramha is knownas Sabda-bramhan. The second and the current half iscalled Padma-kalpa, owing to the lotus-earth that sprang

from Hari’s naval and is also known as Varaha-kalpa because Hari incarnated as a boar. These two Parardhas areafter all, in reality only a Nimesha of the Lord who is beginningless, endless and formless. The exhibition of his gloryextending from Paramanu to the two Parardhas, no mortalman given up to worldly desires can possibly comprehend”.

Q. No. III.

“The Bramha’s day and night are known as Kalpas. 366such days make one year for him and a hundred years socalculated make two Parardhas.”

The above quotations themselves tell more than theordinary story now prevailing about the divisions of Time asdetailed in our ancient literature. The calculation starts withthe smallest scientific atom which is multiplied and increasedin extent up to Parardhom. The atom virtually is a pointwithout dimensions and it creates only an idea of space. Theidea of Time is generated by calculating the time required forthought to pass from one point to another; and hence it isexactly the modern philosophical explanations of space andtime as co-existence and succession. From the Anu or atomat the bottom of the scale the calculation rises to the topmostfigure the Parardom, two of which makes a hundred years’life-time of Bramah the creator. There are Manwantarasand Yugas intervening, which are made up of years.The year is practically the highest figure that can becognised by its component parts, and it does not createany confusion so far, except perhaps in the application ofAyanas and Pakshas, the half-year and half-month as daysof Gods and Pitris respectively. We must however beginfrom the top of the scale, namely, Parardhom, to discover theclues for the correct interpretations of these uncommon andunknown terms in the calculation of time mentioned in thetexts.

In quotation 3, Vidura enquires of Mytreya regardingthe special kind of time, different from the human calculationjust explained, applicable to the working of those indifferentto worldly affairs, like the Yogis. The Yugas are then mentioned as referring to such time, in which the quantity ofDharna, is ascertained as their essential characteristics.

‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

The Yugas according to the root meaning naturally applyto the work of the Yogis and fall under the Sukshma varietyof time. These Yugas have been already noticed in theprevious section as found only in the Bharata-varsha, thedevotional sphere of action for the religious man. The general significance of Yugas is thus clear at least so far as toits inapplicability to the years and centuries in A. D. or B.C.The error in the current interpretation of the Yugas, willbecome more evident from the special quotations, to followon the point. The difference between the first Parardha andthe second, the Bramha-kalpa and the Padma-kalpa shall beexplained in the next section on Personalities. We mayhowever safely note here that none of the modern interpreters have yet taken the trouble to enquire what a Parardhasignifies and whether any definition for the term is furnishedin our religious literature. How are they going to excusethemselves for this culpable mistake evidently caused byignorant pride and irresponsible prejudice? If they evercared to look into the sacred texts, they would not haveventured to play with our ancient religion in the mannerthey have done. The Pandit by his ignorant and irrelevantinterpretations, has unconsciously allowed more than sufficient room for the foreign critic to attack the acknowledgedworth of the literature from all its sides. In spite of theseunfortunate mistakes from two different quarters, the facttacitly remains that the majority of the educated and un-

educated Hindus are never satisfied with the Pandit’s explanations and are immensely annoyed at heart with the currentdestructive criticisms. That neither of these elucidations therefore contain anything sensible, useful or acceptable is virtually proved.

‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§É ‡§∂‡§™‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

The following quotations explain the import of Parardha in the plainest language possible.

Quotation No. I.

‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§æ I
‡§Ö‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§à‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§• ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. II.

‡§Ö‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡•§

‡§â‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡••

‡§è‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§π ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§î‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§• ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. IV.

‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¢‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§É‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å‡•§
‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑ ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. V.

‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VI.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ω‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•å ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•àI
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Quotation. No. I.

“When the three gunas maintain their equilibrium, itis called Prakriti-laya or dissolution of Prakriti; and it ishere described as the night of Bramha. His day refers tothe divine creation here narrated. In reality, he has neithernight nor day. The annihilation of the material world isspoken of as Pratisanchara or re-absorption back into Prakriti. The destruction from the Mahat to the gross elements is called Pratisarga. Final and complete destructionor involution is secured only through gnana. The elaboratedescriptions given in the religious texts refer to the Varaha-kalya. Several such Kalpas pertaining to Vishnu, Rudraand Bramha are also mentioned in the Puranas by the Rishisin their treatment of Time. In the Satwic Kalpas, theglories of Vishnu are predominant, in the Rajasic, Bramha’sand in the Tamasic, Rudra’s. The current Varaha-kalpa isSatwic”.

It is plainly stated here that the division of time intothe days and nights of Bramha, alludes simply to his glories.The Prathisarga or secondary creation here mentioned refersdirectly to the involutionary processes by the annihilation ofmateriality.

‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡••

The term refers to one of the five requirements of a Puranahardly understood by the Pandit.

‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Under the present state of ignorance, one need not evenbe astonished to hear some Pandits explaining Sarga andPratisarga as Chapters and Sections in a Purana. Thecurrent interpretation of Pratisarga as applying to materialcreation is therefore not only varying from truth, but diametrically opposed to it. However willingly and respectfully we may view the modern opinions, it is absolutelyhopeless to obtain even an atom of useful and correct information from them regarding the contents of our sacred texts.

Q. No. II.

“The creation described refers to his day and the dissolution to his night. Understand that he has neither nightnor day. They are so described in a complementary stylefor conveying the instruction to the religious public. Athousand Kalpas make 1 Abda of Bramha ; 8,000 Abdas,1 Yuga; 1,000 Yugas, 1 Savana; 6,000 Savanas representhis longivity. Koti into Koti into one thousand make oneParardha. Two Parardhas make one Parom. The seventeenth figure in the Arithmetical notation known as Parardhais mentioned as representing half the age of Bramha. Thehighest Arithmetical figure is here given only in accordancewith the Puranic method of description. A Parardha should therefore be properly interpreted as Aparardha or no Parardha, meaning infinity thereby”.

It is clearly explained here that a Paradha is the seventeenth and the highest figure in the Arithmetical Notationby multiples of one hundred, and that its application to theage of Bramha is in accordance with the Puranic formula.It is also stated as in the previous quotation that the daysand nights of Bramha are mere complementary descriptions.It is naturally feared that these facts would prove startlingnews to our enlightened interpreters.

Q. No. III.

“The creation by Bramha during the day and the dissolution in the night are only described in a complementarystyle. His age is specified as extending to two Parardhas. Whatever is created during the day dissolves when nightfalls. The four Lokas, Bhu, Bhuva, Swar and Mahar aredissolved at night, others above them are not affected. In thenight, when everything is covered by the ocean, Bramhasleeps in the waters, and then he is known as Narayana‚Äù.

This is a repetition of the facts already explained in thepreceding quotations. No Cr√¨tic need now ingeniously devisespecious apologies for his sweeping remarks constantly made,as to the existence of contradictory statements in the religious texts. He has hardly seen for himself any statementsin their true light to enable him to judge of their contradictions or conformities. His traffic has all along beencarried on with the bankrupt of a Pandit and he could therefore show nothing to his own credit at present. He haspitiably failed in one of the fundamental requirements ofmerchandise, and it is now too late for him to brood over it.We have already noticed in the previous section that Bhuloka is stated to be far above this material earth, and wefind here that the creation and destruction attributed toBramha’s work apply only to the first four Lokas, from

Bhu to Mahar and therefore do not include this earthy globe.The ocean in which these four Lokas lie submerged duringthe night of Bramha, does not also form part of any of theoceans, seas or gulfs mentioned in our modern geography.Bramhas’ sleeping in the waters of this ocean is explained ashimself being converted into Narayana or Vishnu. This iscertainly an unbecoming statement to the delicate and keenear of the modern interpreters, but there is no help for it asit is so stated in the text. This point however will be explained in detail in the subsequent section on Personalities.

*** Q. No. IV.***

“Seventeen figures in the Arithmetical Notation, bymultiples of one hundred, are named by the Rishis as follows,Unit, hundred, ten thousand, Ayuta, Prayuta, Arbuda,Nyarbuda, Kharbuda, Kharva, Nikharva, Samku, Padma,Samudra, Antya, Madhya and Parardha. Two Parardhas make one Parom, thus there are eighteen figures. Two Parardhas are calculated for the two Kalpas or day and night ofBramah. The Parardha mentioned here denotes the higheststate imaginable, with regard to his power, longivity, tapas,Sakti, Dharma, knowledge, stability, Bramhatwa, gnanaand Iswarya. He is the highest and the noblest among thehigh and the noble. The Arithmetical finite figure given is in accordance with the Puranic method of description andsignifies infinity. The Parardha here actually means Aparardha or no Parardha and should be interpreted as beyondeven such an ultimate figure. His real nature is determinedby Eswaras with their pure and divine eyes. From this wemust understand that Gnana is the real foundation foreverything”.

Parardha is clearly explained here, as the highest figurein the Arithmetical notation by multiples of one hundred,and as denoting infinity in its application to the age of

Bramha. Both of these facts, the modern interpreters, haveprobably to learn now for the first time in their life. But without a study of the texts they knew for a long time, by,virtue of their own intellectual superiority, that Parardhaapplied to some early period in B. C. when Bramha was bornsomewhere in Tibet, and created India and their forefathersfor the propogation of the irrelevant and incoherent historyof the two dynasties that ruled over Oudh and Delhi. Whatan insolent and objectionable presumption concerning a subject, where one ought to tremble, before he makes bold tolay his hands upon ? Is there any evidence of intelligence,of religious spirit, of propriety or even of common sense inthis vandalic effort ?

‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ü‡•ã‡§™‡•à‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§ò‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

*** Q. No. V.***

“The Saktis or energies of creation &c., in Bramha,denote his innate nature, and are described as originated, only as a matter of complement. They can however beunderstood only by Gnana. His one hundred years of age,extending to Parom, and its half representing a Parardhaare only postulated, as a suggestion from man’s ownlongivity’.

The explanations here furnished are too plain andsimple to demand any commentaries. The age of Bramhaand his creations here described are thus religious conceptions, whose real signficance could be understood by theacquirement of Gnana. There is however not the slightestdoubt as to their inapplicability to any historical incidents taking place on the surface of this material earth.

*** Q. No. VI.***

“In the Arithmetical notation, eighteen places are namedby multiples of one hundred. The two Parardhas together

signify the Prakriti-laya, the involuion or merging of all theVyaktas into the Avyakta. This constitutes the day time ofVishnu, and when the Prakriti itself merges into the Purusha,it is the night of Vishnu. The eternal Vishnu however, has
neither night nor day. All this is simply stated in a complementary style. In this manner, the involutionary religiousprocesses up to Prakriti-laya are described”.

It is evident from this quotation that the two Parardhasof Bramha combined, complete the Prakriti-laya or the annihilation of finite conceptions. Here, Bramha’s jurisdictionends and Vishnu’s begins. The merging of Prakriti itselfinto the Purusha, is described as the night of Vishnu.These Puranic narrations in the texts are repeatedly assuredto be complementary descriptions, to avoid chances of misinterpretation.

‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É‡••

Has the Critic, Pandit or Theosophist ever looked into theseexplanatory passages before they ventured to convert thecontents of the sacred religious texts into an insignificanthistory of the mortal man? For aught we know, the foreignCritic is sincere in his curiosity to understand the contents ofIndian religious literature. But the microscopic minorityof apish imitators among the educated Hindus are completely wanting in the sincerety and the curiosity of the Critic,when they volunteer to confirm and strengthen the Critic’sviews by their authoritative opinions as Hindus. It ispractically deception and misleading, when such confirmations are based upon entire ignorance of and culpable indifference to the subject. An educated Hindu of this typehas however the least claim to style himself a representativeof the religious and learned Hindus in the land. He isdoubtless responsible for his misleading the foreign patron

and betraying his own sacred religion in false colours to thediscredit of his fellowmen, besides subjecting himself to hisown religious deterioration. It is a pitiable truth that theso-called religious reformers of the modern day are mostly tobe found among this class. It is also a wonder how suchmen shamelessly take a pride in calling themselves benefactors of their countrymen, when they by their ignominious conduct only succeed in displaying their moral andintellectual weakness, religious indifference and want ofcharacter and self-respect. Whatever might be the apparenttemporary benefits acquired personally, the attempt as awhole being entirely a deviation from the right path, isinevitably doomed to fail in the long run, and it would betoo late then, to rue for the mistakes consciously committed.

‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç
‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§ñ‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É‡••

** 3**. The above quotations conclusively prove that thewhole affair is a simple rendering of the Infinite in thelanguage of the Finite, the abstract fact in the form of theconcrete Arithmetic for the express purpose of showing theimmensity and magnitude of the object described. TheParardhom is the 17th and the last figure in the Arithmetical Notation reckoned by multiples of one hundred, insteadof ten. Parom means great and Ardhom position. Thus,the highest state of existence to be attained is explained bythe height, the present low, degraded and mortal man has to ascend by strenuous efforts and religious devotion. Thehundred years making up a Bramha’s period are clearlystated in Quotaion V, as having been predicted in accordance with the longivity of man himself. This period is divided

into two exact halves consisting of 50 years each. Thecurrent time is represented as the beginning of the latterhalf. The applications of these divisions and variations ofTime could be easily understood when references to the’Personalities’ are examined in the subsequent section. Itmay however be noted here that the former half points tothe Gnana and Upasana processes and the latter to the Yogaand Karma processes.

‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É II

The Vedas are represented by Bramah and they prescribethe above two methods conforming to the capacities of manfor the attainment of salvation. Next to Parardhom, theManwantaras and Yugas have to be examined. The day ofBramha which covers all ideas of religious creation and existence is divided into 14 Manwantaras consisting of 1,000Chatur-yugas or cycles of four Yugas, each Manwantara extending to about 71 Chatur-yugas. The interval of timeelapsing between two Manus is called a Manwantara and itcan be better explained while treating of Manus themselves.Besides, the examination of the meanings of Yugas will alsothrow some light upon the calculation of a Manwantara. Asearching enquiry may therefore be first made with regardto the Yugas. The subjoined quotaions are I fear likely tofrighten our self-constituted interpreters out of their wits.

Quotation. No. 1.

‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•å‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡•§

‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. IV.

‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§ï‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∂‡•Ä‡•§
‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§É ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡§∂‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. V.

‡§π‡§®‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•§

‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
