‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§™‡•à‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§´‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡••

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•É‡§ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á I
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§à‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡••

Q. No. VI.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á I
‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•§

Q. No. VII.

‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§É ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VIII.

‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ß‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Quotation. No. I.

‚ÄúIn & treatinent of the history of the Yugas, Krita isSatwa; Treta is Reja; Dwapara is a combination of Rejaand Tama; and Kali is Tama. In the Krita, there is noaction of any kind, good or bad, all that has to be done inthe Lokas having been already done. There are also nodivisions of castesandAsramas, and no intermixtures”.

The Pundit, in his usual style, is sure to rush in here,with his thoughtless interpretations. If theYugas refer tosome ancient periods in the history of man, as he, the Criticand the Theosophistwould wish to establish, will they tellus how man could exist in the Krita, as described here,without actions of any kind? If again the Critic and Theosophist want to prove the non-existence of castes and Asramas in ancient days like the Krita, will they explain whythe absence of admixture is specially noticed ? The actionsgood or bad, said to have been already accomplished in Krita,are those pertaining to the various religious Lokas, whoselist has been already found to exclude this material earth.

‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

It is therefore certain that neither the transactions of theworldly man, nor the distinctions of Indian castes, nor againthe utility and urgency of destroying them, by interdiningand intermarrying, are here spoken of. Every layman ofordinary common sense can easily infer from every word inthis quotation, that both the current interpretations, andcriticisms, proceed from sheer ignorance of the subject andfrom an unbecoming spirit of unnecessary interference. Thesubsequent quotations are sure to exhibit this fact in strongerlight. The modern methods of explaining the subject for theenlightenment of the religious public are therefore extremelydistressing and ruinous.

‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§É
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§´‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡••

Q. No. II.

“The wise say that there are four Yugas in the Bharata-varsha and that they are nowhere else. Dhyana and tapasin the Krita; Gnana in the Treta; Yegna in the Dwaparaand Dana alone in the Kali are specified. In the first Krita,Dharma exists, it is manifested in Treta, it is distracted inDwapara and destroyed in Kali”.

The Pandit here is extremely happy to note that noneof the Yugas get out of Bharata-varsha.He preservesthem within the boundaries of his India. The Theosophistof course is prepared to go over this spot for his use of theYugas. The foreign Critic will surely get bewildered here.If Yugas allude to the periods of human history, why shouldother nations outside India be deprived of their benefit? Probably other nations in the world, were never affected by

the trammels of time, in ancient days. Different states ofDharma are stated to be the distinguishing characteristics ofthe Yugas. In the Krita however, this Dharma is not evenmanifested, it remains latent. Is there any modern interpretation available to make this statement intelligible? As times advance, why is this Dharma said to deteriorate anddwindle to nothing especially in these modern days of civilization and progress? Perhaps it is so described in uncivilized times. Will the Pandit at least tell us why Dyana,tapas, gnana and Yegna are uncourteously excluded from
Kali, when so many of his learned colleagues are found allover India? What is the harm if the present generation inKali take to any of these religious processes, and could the Pandit assure that no one in India is violating this rule?

My good God ! it is indeed a wonder why no answersare forthcoming for any of these pertinent questions, fromany of the quarters from which we had so much noisehitherto.

‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•å‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•§
‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

Q. No. III.

“There are four Yugas in the Bharata-varsha, namely,Krita, Treta, Dwapara and Tishya. The longivity isreckoned as 4,000 years in Krita, 3,000 in Treta and 2,000in Dwapara. In the Tishya, it is uncertain, death occurringsometimes in the womb or soon after birth’.

Why is the much despised Kali called Tishya heremeaning auspicious or fortunate? In this quotation also, thefour Yugas are mentioned as found only in Bharata-varshaIf, in the current Kali, even the chances of living are so pre-

carious, as described here, why not the Pandit get out of his India to be free from its clutches? Again, does he believe that his forefathers lived for four, three and two thousand years respectively in the three previous Yugas, as described here, and if he does, has he any sort of proof to establish the same? On the other hand, will the Critic or Theosophist accept this description, and if not why? These are surely natural questions arising from the modern interpretation of the passage here quoted. If no reasonable answers are available from any of these so-called interpreters, how are we bound to accept their interpretation, while they invariably bring with them unmerited disrepute to the sacred texts as well as to their venerable authors? The interpretations of these self-made authorities are certainly not more valuable to us than the religious texts, and themselves not so venerable as the ancient Rishis.

‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§øII

Q. No. IV.

“The advent of exaltation is also like the coming in of deterioration. When Dharma is well attained, the Krita Yuga is clearly seen. Goodness is the ruling principle in the Krita, it is lost in the Kashaya or Kali. Time is unchanging like the moon, which when veiled by darkness is Kali and when unveiled is Krita. The inseparable and unknowable Parom-bramhan is the Arthavada or object in view in the Vedas. The approved and valid process for obtaining it, is Tapas, and that is confirmed here. Cessation of Karmas is attained by meritorious virtues, which in themselves are purified by Karmas”.

It is clearly stated here, that the realisation of Bramhan is the chief aim of the teachings in the Vedas, and that the

proper process for it is Tapas. The absence of Tapas isspecified as Kali, Kashaya or confusion. The removal ofthis confusion, Tama or Agnana produces Krita. The important scope and extent of Tapas, and its different stages ofattainment are here established by the division of the Sukshma and religious time into four Yugas. It is repeatedlyassured that these Yugas are not found outside the limits ofBharata-varsha. This is an additional corroboration for thefact that Bharata-varsha refers to the devotional sphere ofreligious Karmas and that the Yugas explain the degrees ofperfection attained therein. The devotional sphere is therefore described as space in the Puranic style and the Yugasas time.

Q. No. V.

“Krita is the greatest of the Yugas, where eternalDharma is complete, having no more to be done. In theKrita, there are no Devas, Danavas, Yekshas, Rakshasas andPannagas; there is no buying no selling; no difference ofVedas and no human action. The Dharma is Sanyasa.Pertaining to this Yuga, there is no disease, no weakness ofthe senses, no laziness, no pride, no prejudice, no fear, nogrief, no quarrel. The highest Bramhan is the ultimateattainment for the Yogis in this Yuga. The Atman is inthe form of Narayana, pure and white, and Atma-yoga isthe distinguishing characteristic of this Yuga. The threegunas are here absent and Dharma has its four quarterscomplete. In the Treta, Vishnu becomes red and a quarterof Dharƒ±na is lost. Tapas, Dana, Satya, Yegna, Swadharma and religious Karma remain firm in Treta. In theDwapara half the Dharma is lost and Vishnu becomes brown.On account of the ignorance of the single Veda, it is dividedinto four, some taking to three, some to two or one andsome to none of them. Some fall from Satya or truth and

consequently diseases and misfortunes result. Dharma greatlydeteriorates and Yegnas are performed to obtain Swargaand to satisfy worldly desires. In the Kali, only one quarterof Dharma remains and Vishnu becomes dark. Dharma,Yegna and Achara dwindle to nothing. Diseases, misfortunes, sorrows, anger, laziness &c. arise. As the Yugasrevert, Dharma also reverts with the Lokas. The Lokasappear by meditation and when the Lokas disappear, everything deteriorates and spoils”.

The Yugas are here distinguished by the different degrees of Dharma prevailing. In the Krita it is completelyfinished, nothing more having to be done. It is clearlystated here that in the form of human action there is absolutely nothing in this Yuga, ‘‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä’IAtma-yoga is said to be the distinguishing characteristic of theKrita Yuga.

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡••

These are extremely plain and unambiguous statementswhich will not in the least permit of the modern interpretation, as alluding to the historical periods of Hiudu, Mahamaden or European soverigns in India. The Pandit’s interpretation here displays his utter ignorance of the subjectand utter lack of common sense. It might perhaps suggest,by the laws of association, the funny slokas in Sanskritknown as Anterlapika.

‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É‡••

If the Pandit is still anxious to understand the Yugas ashistorical periods, he may have the consolation of knowingthat the Krita Yuga refers to the history of every Yogi

practising Atma-yoga in which all human affairs now worrying the Pandit’s brain are entirley annihilated. The practice of the lower forms of Yoga is described as representingthe three remaining Yugas. It is a noteworthy fact herethat the single Veda has to be divided into four by theadvent of Dwapara. Again another important fact noticedin this quotation is that meditation brings on the Lokas andthat when the Lokas are gone everything deteriorates.

‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡••

Have the modern interpreters any explanation to offer herefor our enlightenment? There is no poetical fancy nor anyexaggeration here. These are the only two expressionsyet known to them to cover their ignorance. They mustconfess here that the description is entirely unmeaning. Itcannot but be so, as the whole subject is misunderstood fromits very commencement. It is also a vain belief that theyhave understood anything before or after this passage. Thosewho understand the real nature of the subject can clearlyunderstand that every line in the text is completely misunderstood at present. Every school boy knows that arithmetic is not geography. The Pandit evidently knows neitherarithmetic nor geography and it is no wonder therefore thathe confounds the two together in his presumptuous attemptto explain an unknown subject.

Q. No. VI.

“You need not foster the least doubt as to whether thenature of time depends upon the character of the Raja, orthe character of the Raja depends upon the nature of time.The nature of time is entirely shaped by the character of theRaja. The four Yugas named Krita, Treta, Dwapara andKali allude to the history of the Raja; in fact, the Raja ishimself the Yuga. When the Raja enforces Denda-niti orjustice completely, it is called Krita the best of the Yugas.

Dharma is unabated and Yoga is safe in Krita. Voice,colour and mind are then highly developed. When three-quarters of justice are enforced, the Treta is originated. Whentwo-quarters of justice are enforced, the Dwapara is originated. When no justice at all is enforced, Kali is originated.Then, there is no Dharma and no safety for Yoga. Thecastes get intermixed. The Raja is actually the creator ofKrita, Treta, Dwapara and Kali. By creating Krita, heobtains the highest heaven and by creating Kali, he obtainsthe deepest hell. By the creation of the other two Yugas,he obtains the proportionate happiness. Mahadeva, the godof the gods, created from his own Atma, the Denda, for thepurpose of sustaining the Lokas and for preventing their admixture. From the quarters of Dharma he created alsothe goddess Saraswati called Niti. She directs the Dendalike punishment towards offenders and is therefore knownas Danda-niti”.

Now, let us look into the gist of the whole description.The different Yugas are said to take their names accordingto the amount of Denda-niti or justice enforced by the Raja.The Raja is independent of time, but time is entirely dependent on him. This directly contradicts the modern interpretations of Yugas even as Sthula time. That almost throughout the religious texts Sukshma time is dealt with as alreadyexplained here, is probably a new lesson to these interpreters. The Raja and Denda-niti are of course technical termshere used. The Denda and Niti are mentioned as creationsof Mahadeva. Have the Pandit, Critic or Theosophist anything to say against this quotation from the Maha-bharata,which undoubtedly puts them all to complete shame? Wehave already found that there is no human action in theKrita-yuga. If therefore Denda-niti means criminal justicein accordance with the modern interpretation, there is absolutely no relevancy in describing its complete enforcement.

in the Krita Yuga. Either Krita is not Krita, or Dendaniti is not criminal justice. These are then the two horns ofthe dilemma, in which the self-made authorities and Critics have inevitably landed themselves. The pretended knowledge and the assumed competency to interpret or criticise,could not be possibly concealed, when unexpectedly theproper time arrives for their naked exposure.

‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø
‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ‡••

Q. Nos. VII & VIII.

“The four quarters of Dharma are Gnana, Dhyana,Sama and Dema. Gnana is the knowledge of the Atman.Dhyana is the meditation of Atman. Sama is stability ofmind and Dema is control of the senses. When Dharmaincreases, longivity increases. Dharma in the form of a bull,with its sound four legs roams about protecting the Lokas-Adoration to that holy form ! The four limbs of Dharmaare the perfect states of truth, kindness, peace of mind andharmlessness. The attainment of an atom of such Dharmasaves us from the greatest fears, exactly as addiction to alittle of Adharma is productive of much fear”.

The four quarters of Dharma are here stated to be thestandards by which the Yugas are determined and they areexplained as consisting of Dyana, Gnana, Sama and Dema.Dharma is generally described as a Vrisha or bull. Vrishaitself means Dharma in the Sanskrit language. Pada inthe same way means one fourth as well as a foot or leg inSanskrit and in the Indian vernaculars. The Pundit feelshighly elated at the opportunities here offered in the description of Dharma. He would have his Dharma in the form

of an actual bull the biggest and fairest obtainable in Indiaand would like to establish that, that is the correct and onlymeaning for the Puranic description. In the same way, hemust establish that the Yugas have their distinguishingfeatures in some concrete form and that they should be confined within the boundaries of India. Time as ordinarilyunderstood by human beings is an abstract idea whichcannot be dealt with as the Pandit handles it. It isclearly stated here that the names of Yugas signify thenature of the work done by the pious and the religious inin the field of Dharma, and the Pandit simply exhibits hisperverse obstinacy and lamentable ignorance in his interpretation of the subject. Gnana, Dhyana, Sama, Dema,truthfulness, control of the senses &c. are not certainly thequalities of time. He is however most anxious to establishthat the venerable authors of the sacred texts are not muchwiser than the wise-acres of his type.

‡§µ‡•Ä‡§£‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡••

** 4.** The words Yuga and Yoga are almost synonymous. To couple, to unite, or join the Jivathma with theParamatma, the lower self with the higher self is the ideapervading all these descriptions. The degrees of perfectionattained in this direction are explained with reference to thedefinite processes prescribed for the purpose. The KritaYuga expresses the stage of completion as the word Kritaclearly denotes. The appellations Kali, Thishya, Kashayaand Thamasa for the last Yuga are equally significant of theentire absence of religious merit. It is called the currentYuga as the instructions in the texts are naturally supposedto be always addressed to the ignorant and irreligious populace in general and are meant for their benefit. The following passages already quoted in Chaper I specifying the first

day of Kali as the date on which Sri Krishna quitted theearth, are indicative also of the loss of belief even in thetheory of the existence of a God consequent on therampantmaterialism prevailing all over the world, apart from theirtechnicalreference.

‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The main points of distinction in the four Yugas lie in theamount of Dharma prevailing, none being found in Kali.There is no ‘Yogakshema’ or prosperity for Yoga nor Yogaitself in Kali. It stands aloof from the rest as the worst inthe list and lowest in the scale of religious advancement.Half the quantity of Dharma prevails in Dwapara Yugaand three-fourths in Treta Yugs, as the words Dwapara andTreta themselves signify. Quotation VII clearly enumeratesthe four parts of Dharma as consisting of Gnana, Dhyana,Sama and Dema. Quotation VI, explains that the reckoning of the Yugas entirely depends upon the proportionateenforcement of criminal justice, Denda-niti. In fact thehistory of the Raja is said to be the specification of the Yuga.This is the Puranic method of description. The Raja, as
stated in the preceding pages, is the Atma or self seated inthe car or body. The horses are the senses, mind the reinsand intellect the charioteer.

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡•§
‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§π‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••

The Danda-niti or criminal justice requires some explanation. It refers to the Yogic process prescribed for annihilating the external Vasanas. The Danda is the spinal cord with its plexes for meditation, as we have already noticed.

The most important item in the description determiningthe characteristic differences of the Yugas is the duration oftime detailed for each of them. A careful examination ofthe formulas and a correct calculation in accordance withthem, will, 1 confidently hope easily convince every readerthat the gist of the whole matter is far removed from thecommon interpretations as well as from those attempted bythe help of modern material sciences. The Sukshma andSthula classifications of time should be distinctly kept in the calculation, the former technically applying to the experiences and attainments of the Yogic processes and the latter tothe ordinary reckoning of days, months and years. In therendering of the Sukshma into the Sthula the formulas aregiven in the passages already quoted.

‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•à‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§É‡••

Three breaths make one Prana and six Pranas make oneSukshma Ghatika. Further calculations go by the samenumbers both for Sukshma and Sthula. 60 Sthula-Ghatikasmake 1 Sthula day; similarly 60 Suksma Ghatikas make1 Sukshma day. Again,

‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

The passing of breath from right to left, that is inhalingthrough the right nostril and exhaling through the left is

technically known amongst Yogis as Uttarayana, and viceversa as Dekshinayana, both of them together making aSukshma year.

Further,

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡§™‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Breath passes alternately through the right and left nostrils,through the force of Prana and Apana, and it repeats theprocess 21,600 times in a day. Meditation on this byYogis is Known as Ajapa-Mantra which is very efficaciousfor the destruction of sins. Taking the three above passages together, the question regarding the length of periodgiven for Kali Kuga namely; 1, 200 Divine years including200 years of Sandhi or 4,32,000 hunan years, may be easilyworked out.

3 x 6 = 18 Swasas make 1 Sukshma Ghatika.
18 √ó 60 = 1030 Swasas make 1 Sukshma day.

A Sthula day consists of 21600 Swasas probably calculatedfrom the normal condition observed in sleep. At othertimes, although respiration is an involuntary action itsnatural speed and duration will be constantly altered bychanges of external as well as internal conditions. Theproportion for conversion of a Sukshma day, month or yearinto a Sthula day, month or year is therefore 21600 √∑ 1080 = 20.

that is 1 to 20, is the proportion. Uttarayana and Dekshinayana together is one year and is tantamount to 1 Swasa,which is made up of both. The year here is Sukshma andit is therefore 20 Sthula years. 21,600 Swasas thereforemake up 432,000 Sthula years, which is exactly the numbergiven for the duration of Kali Yuga. We thus clearly seethat the purport of the whole affair is the Yogic account ofa single day of man. The doubling, trebling and quadrupling of this period for Dwapara, Treta and Krita Yugas,are consequent on the regulation of breaths by the processesprescribed in the Yoga-sastras with which we are not directly concerned at present. For instance, to obtain the numberof years given for Dwapara namely 864,000; a single Sthuladay whose account is practically the gist of the matter,being always a constant factor, the proportion in the rendering of the Sukshma to the Sthula, will have to be doubledby a corresponding reduction in the number of Swasas or breaths making up a Sukshma Ghatika. Instead of 18Swasas comprising a Sukshina Ghatika they should be reducedto 9, then the proportion will be21,600= 40.9 √ó 60 TheSthula years per day’s account, will then amount to 21,600 x 40= 864,000. Similarly, the necessary reduction of Swasas byYogic processes will give the figures for Treta and KritaYuagas. We thus clearly see that the figures given in thetexts are mathematically exact and not approximations, orexaggerations or even poetical fancies. It is however sufficient for our present purpose to know what a Yuga means,at least what it does not mean. The mere knowledge of itwill remove a good deal of misconception and further consequent errors, created by the ignorant people as well as bythe so-called scientific expositors like the Theosophists. We

have already seen how the latter are completely ignorant ofthe true significance of the geographical descriptions.Equally ignorant are they with regard to the question of timespecified. Their calling to aid geological discoveries in theelucidation of our sacred literature is more a mockery thananything else. Madam Blavadski’s explanation in her"Secret Doctrines”, of the duration of Dwapara Yuga namely864,000 years, as nearly approaching the earliest date discovered by modern Geology, is perhaps accepted by herdisciples and some others as a eulogistic observation in favorof Hindu Religion. What then about the duration of theTreta and Krita Yugas? We have perhaps to wait untilanother Geological discovery is available. What if the durations given for each of the four Yugas are pronounced to bediscovered immediately by Geology or any other materialsciences? The Yugas mentioned in our religious texts applyonly to Bharata Varsha (vide Q. 2) and not to the Theosophical India nor to any other locality outside the same onthe surface of this earthy sphere. Taking even the Theosophical interpretation (which is but a borrowing in toto fromthe local Pandits) of Bharata varsha as representing India,and the Yugas as referring to the ordinary calculation oftime, it must logically lead to the ridiculous but unavoidable
conclusion, that there is no ‘Time’ in America and perhapsno ‘space’ in Europe, both being outside Bharata-varsha. Itis high time that those who are really interested in our hoaryand sacred religion either religiously or even scientifically,should soon get over this deplorable ignorance and open theireyes. It is indeed a shame that we should have deterioratedto this depth to allow ourselves to be treated in this childishfashion both by our ignorant Pandits and the misleadingforeigners. It is certainly too late in these boasted days ofcivilization to console ourselves by excuses like want of time

or means, when side by side with us, the enlightened foreigners seek useful and valuable information in the interest ofscience from all corners of the world at the cost of immensewealth and convenience and even at the risk of personal life.It is utterly useless to be simply proud of our ancient civilization and religious supremacy.Standing still in the daysof progress, is positive retrogression and there is not theslightest doubt that we have fallen down thousands ofdegrees in our religious sphere.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡§§‡§É
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡•§
‡§ó‡§æ‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å‡••

5. The Manus and Manwantaras are matters ofvital importance in our Religion. They refer to certain definitePsychological and Physiological principles advantageouslyutilized in the religious practices prescribed. The subject isparticularly technical and perhaps peculiar to the Hindureligion. The facts expressed by the enumeration of the 14 Manus and of the durations of time intervening betweeneach of them are closely connected with the description ofthe Yugas and deal with scientific and technical matters, adetailed description of which is not possible to be attemptedhere. References will however have to be made occasionallywhere the necessary and available informations may be furnished. Regulation of breath called Prana-yama is the chiefprocess prescribed for Yoga. But it has to be supplementedby meditation accompanied by Manthras to make it effective.

‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡••

A scientific treatment of the physiology of sound styledSiksha is well-known to every student of Sanskrit Grammar,as forming an important portion of the subject. But it has

seldom been studied as a practical science, nor its specialapplication to the religious literature carefully noticed.Siksha has already been explained in Chapter II as one ofthe six Vedangas. It is thus one of the necessary items tobe first understood in the correct elucidation of religiousfacts and formulas. The natural relation or associationbetween thought and sound or language, the fact of theirinseparable coexistence and the consequent effects of theirmutual actions are all minutely and scientifically treated and,practically utilized for the practice of Yoga and religiousdevotion.

A science like the physiology of sound may perhapssound strange to a modern scientist, but nevertheless it isone of the oldest one known to our ancients and its possibility itself cannot be deniedwithout a proper enquiry. TheManthras are all composed in strict adherance to the principlesof this science. They are not valued for their meaning asgenerally supposed. The various Sahasranamas or thousandnames in praise of Vishnu or other Gods are not all of themrecognised as fit to be repeated as Manthras. Besides, thereare several single letters which ordinarily convey no meaning except a peculiar sound and do not permit of translationin any language but are particularly recognised as Manthraslike Hrim, Klim &c. Thus, the idea of translating theManthras in any language is a useless and unscientific task in as much as they lose their significance and effects even in aparaphrase in the Sanskrit language itself. It is but awell-known fact, that every poetical composition in anylanguage is not necessarily suited to be sung in every tunein music, unless the laws of composition for such purposesare strictly adhered to.

The word Manu ordinarily means mental faculty orthought as well as a Manthra. No great change is made

from this common interpretation, in its application in thetexts. But it is used in a somewhat restricted sense according to the requirements of the technical subject. The following quotations are subjoined with the hope of corroboratingthe interpretation here given, and I dare say it would beprofitless to criticise it as new or farfetched, without readingthe passages quoted, or to condemn them all, as unauthenticinterpolations. The texts containing these passages aresufficiently recognised as genuine for our present purposeand the passages themselves have not yet been marked outby modern critics and proclaimed as interpolations. Theonly probability is that they have not been properly noticedor understood in a searching or sympathetic spirit.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ·≥∂‡§ï·≥∂‡§™‡•å‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•åI
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§Ö‡§• ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É‡•§

‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. IV.

‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. V.

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VI

‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ÉI
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∑‡§°‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§∞‡•å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§∂‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VII.

‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ó‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§π‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ó‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡•à‡§•‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. VIII.

‡§∂‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q No. IX.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡••

‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. X.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§É‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡•ã ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ò‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No. XI.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. XII.

‡§∏‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•å‡•§
‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§ì‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§

‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§É‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡§≠‡•å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ê‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ì‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ì‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§î‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡••

                      **‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••**
  • Q. No. XIII.*

‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§®‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§è‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§õ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡•ã‡§• ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï ‡§ì‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••

** ** ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••

Q. No. XIV.

‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§

‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§É ‡§î‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡••

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••

** ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••**

Q. No. XV.

‡§ì‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ì‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§ì‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ö‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ß‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§â‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ ‡§â‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•¶‡§™‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É‡••

** ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••**

Q. No. XVI.

‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§É‡§≤‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§®‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§•‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§¶‡§≤‡•á ‡§¶‡§≤‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡••

** ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••**

256 ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§É = 1 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ 8 ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§É = ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç.
128do= ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É 4 do=‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É
64 do=‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç 2 do= ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ.
32 do = ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä. 1 do = ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ.
16 do = ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç. ¬Ω do = ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ.

‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ‡•§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ‡•§‡§§‡§¶‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ‡•§‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§ö‡§ü‡§§‡§™‡§Ø‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§µ‡§ï‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•à‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡•§‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§

‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•å ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•å‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•å‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•å‡••

‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É‡••

‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É - ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡••

‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. XVII.
