‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡•ã ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§ú ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§™‡§ü‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§® ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§Ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ú‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§

‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§õ‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§õ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§õ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ó‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§£‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§É‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡•à‡§ú‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡••

‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. XII.

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§ï‡§ò‡§® ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π ‡§â‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. XIII.

‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. XIV.

‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••

Q. No. XV.

‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§¨‡§π‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡§ß‡•§
‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•å ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§≠‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•å‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•å‡•§
‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ú‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ö‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡••

‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§É‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•§
‡§®‡•à‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§ï‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§æ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç - ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡••

Before translating these lengthy quotations gathered from various sacred texts, it may be desirable to know and remember that the descriptions touching on the same points detailed in each of them, are given under different circumstances and to differently qualified persons. The varieties of their treatment should not therefore be misunderstood as irrelevancies or contradictions on that account. On the

contrary, if the real purport of the instructions be kept in view, much skill could be easily discovered as having been displayed in explaining the same matter in various ways, without in the least slipping out of the mark. The most important and dangerous mistake to be avoided here is the prevailing idea that the dealings of Bramha, Vishnu and Siva detailed in the texts, allude to the worldly affairs of man and that their conceptions are therefore connected with the same. It must clearly be understood that they are explained as pertaining to the region of pure Satwic Maya, the religious sphere represented in the Sastras, and that therefore they have absolutely nothing to do with the worthless glories and pomp of man in this earthy sphere, technically described as the products of Avidya. (Vide Q. 14)

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

Thus, the main subject here dealt with is so serious and the existing ignorance of its real nature is so great, that in the interest of its renovation, few of the quotations could possibly be omitted and no careless misinterpretations according to the mere fancy, whim, caprice or indifference, could here be tolerated. The only qualifications demanded for the correct understanding of the whole, are earnestness, sympathy and more especially absense of bias. Even the mere spirit of appreciation of the literary skill and beauty that could not be missed in the passages quoted here, will give ample scope for their intellectual enjoyment. But, if unfortunately, none of these requisites are forth-coming, no

religion, philosophy or language, however grand,could afford to till such impervious soil, and it would be no uncharitable work of the plough or the ploughman to abandon it as a hopeless task.

‡§Ö‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§µ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§¨‡•ç‡§ú‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§õ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã
‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§É‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡••

*** Quotation No. I.***

“Narayana is the Hari of hundred heads. He is the lord and soul of the Universe or Viswa. He is the eternal, blissful and bright Atma and Purusha. In Him is constituted all that is seen or heard, external or internal”.

This is one of the descriptions of Vishnu as all-pervading, the general idea conveyed by the name. The technical significance of Vishnu as the Lord of Viswa, will however have to be specially noticed. Viswa as used here does not refer to this material world as ordinarily understood. It alludes to Prana or the all-pervading life principle. Vishnu does not represent a human emperor ruling over the five continents of modern geography, as the Pandit surely believes.

Q. No. II.

“Maya is the Prakriti and Mayina or Brahman is Maheswara from whom everything has originated. His name itself being glory or renown, he has no form”. Here, Maya or pure Satwic condition is specially mentioned and Maheswara as its Lord without form. Maheswara however, is a technical term, but is commonly understood as a synonym for Siva.

*** Q. No. III.***

“The name Rudra signifies, that he is not easily know able except by the pious Rishis. The name Esana denotes that He rules over all the Devas by his Saktis. The name Bhagavan Maheswara alludes to his blessing the devotees and to his holding the high position by the force of Yoga and knowledge of Atma. This is the history of Rudra”.

The terms Bhagavan and Maheswara are particularly technical as referring to Yoga, but to the learned Pandit, every technical term in the texts conveys only his single crude idea without any distinctions specified in our religious literature which he ever ventures to interpret without its study. The two terms noticed will be clearly explained subsequently in this section.

*** Q. No. IV.***

“All the Devas enter into him, he is therefore called Vishnu. Everything is grown and expanded by him and therefore known as Bramha. In all the internal meditations, he shines like a light and therefore called Prakasa. Amidst all sorts of internal meditations, he appears as a flash of lightning in the form of Om, and breaking through them pervades all the Lokas,and therefore known as Mahadeva”.

The functions of the three Gods are explained here and it may be easily noticed that the definitions given allude to varieties of internal meditations and not to external affairs. The Pandit is likely to get confused here as he hears these facts probably for the first time in his life.

Q. No. V.

“Rudra comprises all the Devas and the Devas are of his nature. On the right side of Rudra are, the Sun, Bramha and Fire. On his left side are, Uma, Vishnu and Soma or Moon. Uma is really Vishnu himself and Vishnu

is the Moon. The seed originates from Rudra and the soil is Vishnu. Rudra is Bramha himself and Bramha is Fire itself. Bramha and Vishnu make up Rudra and the Jagat is composed of Fire and Moon. All that is masculine is Rudra and feminine, Uma. The Universe is made up of both. The manifested is Uma and the unmanifested is Rudra, and the combination of both is Vishnu. Vishnu is the Atma, Bramha is Anter-Atma andMaheswara is Parama-Atma. Maheswara is the cause, Bramha, the act or process and Vishnu is the effect, all the three being only different aspects of Rudra. Rudra is Dharma, Bramha is the knowledge and Vishnu is the Jagat. Rudra is male and Uma female,Rudra is Bramha and Uma Saraswati. Rudra thenefore is the totality of Devas,and uttering his name saves mankind from all their sins. For the tree made up of the three Lokas, the top, middle and bottom represent Vishnu, Bramha and Rudra”.

This is an interesting and instructive quotation. Rudra, Bramha and Agni go together, so also Uma, Vishnu and Soma. The Jagat described is made up of both these sets. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§ Again, Dharma and cause represent Rudra, Kriya and Gnana represent Bramha, Jagat and effect represent Vishnu. There are so many combinations of terms and ideas here. Will any of our modern interpreters kindly enlighten us on any of these points ? Will the learned Pandit tell us how the Jagat which he interprets as the geographical earth is composed of Agni and Soma ? Vishnu is also described as a compound of Uma and Sankara. Has he any explanation to offer for it?

‡§â‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

Q. No. VI.

(a) “The lotus that sprang from Vishnu’s naval became the golden egg and Vishnu himself became Bramha of his

own accord, by the quality of Rejas, for the purpose of creating the Jegat in every Yuga, as long as doubt and settlement continue”.

Here Bramha is described as identical with Vishnu differing only in quality. The creation of Jegat is said to continue only as long as doubt and settlement continue. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡•• Could Bramha himself be in doubt at times? If the man’s state of mind is referred to as the passage naturally suggests, what does the Jegat signify? These natural questions have probably never struck the modern interpreters hitherto. The Jegat specified in the text as created by Bramha, is certainly not this earthy globe and these interpreters have surely no other idea of the Jegat. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§ Where everything goes to ultimately is the spot specified. The learned authorities have therefore no correct idea of Bramha, Jegat or its creation.

(b) “The whole of the Jegat is pervaded by me in the form of Avyakta or unmanifested, and I am therefore called Vishnu by the Munis. In the same way, I am called Vasudeva because the Bhutas or elements live in me and I am in them as their Lord. I am known as Samkarshana by my devotees, because I take them at the end to Avyakta.I am known as Predyumna by those devotees who wish for progeny, because I take different and various forms according to their desire. In this Loka, I am alone independent, excepting Hari and Hara, and I am therefore known as Anirudha”.

It is clear that the Jegat and the Loka here specified do not allude to the earthy globe of the Pandit, and that the workings of Vishnu detailed here, as Vishnu, Samkarshana, Predyumna and Anirudha refer to something Avyakta or unmanifest ed which the modern interpreters have not yet dreamt of".

(c) “O ! Parvati, the meaning of the Manthra consisting of eight letters and relating to Narayana should be properly understood, in order to be effctive by its repetition. Nara, denotes the totality of Atmas, of men or of the universe. It also refers to the Tatwas. He who is the basis of all of them is known as Narayana. Like the silk-worm, he creates and swallows the Jegat. At the time of the involution, he destroys Bramha, Indra, Rudra, Yema and Varuna, and floats on Maya described as the banian leaf.He is therefore called Hari. The Sakalom Jegat or the Jegat with form, comprising of everything commencing with Bramha, is dependent on Narayana. With a clear knowledge of this fact, the Manthra referred to should be repeated; otherwise there will be no effect. The first letter Om forms part of this Manthra, unlike others where it is added to the Manthras. Na and Ma are the next two letters and Narayanaya the last five letters. The Prenava Om is the seat of Bramha and represents the three Vedas. The letter A represents Vishnu, U represents Sri and M represents Jiva or individual soul, the twenty-fifth Tatwom. The consonants beginning with Ka represents the elements, those commencing with Ta and Tha the senses, Pa refers to the mind and Pha to Ahamkara Ba and Bha to Mahat and Prakriti. Ma the twenty-fifth letter represents Atma and Ahamkara. As everything depends upon the mercy of Eswara, this Ahamkara should be destroyed by adding Na the negative to Ma making Nama. Depending on the Lord of Sri, all Karmas should therefore be performed”.

Here Vishnu is described as the creator and destroyer of the Jegat which is said to include all forms commencing with Bramha. Thus the form of Bramha is the highest specified in the Jagat and everything downwards must be of some similar form in that region. The whole of the con-

tents of this Jegat is therefore naturally unknown to ordinary mankind. But our learned Pandit is somehow acquainted with Bramha and his subordinates, as if his village is within this Jegat and is one adjoining to that in which Bramha is put up. Again, Narayana is described as the Lord of all and the word ‘Nama’ meaning worship,used in the Manthra in question, is explained as signifying the necessity to annihilate egoism. Thus, every line in the quotation is pregnant with instructive and philosophical ideas, and there is no doubt that the Pandit will run over the passage with one sweep of his dirty broom and proclaim to the world that the whole of it describes some unreasonable and incoherent material affairs. It has almost become an established fact now that no delicate or sensible ideas could penetrate through his congealed brains.

‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡••

Q. No. VII.

“Maheswara, the first created, is known as Soma being combined with Uma. From his right side he created Bramha for further creation and gave him the Vedas and Puranas. From his left side, he created Vasudeva for preservation, and from his heart Kala-Rudra for destruction. In himself he is Siva without Gunas and is the object of meditation for the Yogis. The Viswa is originated at his pleasure and is preserved and destroyed likewise. The seed, of the nature of Predhana and Purusha, which developed itself is called Mahat or Budhi Tatwa. In that egg of Prakriti, the Kshetragna is called Bramha or Purusha or Prejapatis being the first creation with form. He is the first creator of the Bhutas or elements. When the Gunas lose their equilibrium by force of time, it is

called creation, and when they are at equipoise, it is Laya or destruction. The Bramhanda is the Kshetra or seat of this Bramha. When a duration of time extending to one hundred Paras pass away, all the elements merge in Prakriti. In course of time the Triads also merge in Prakriti and again spring forth. It is stated in the Vedas that the basis of Time here specified is Bhagavan Mahadeva. The five subtle elements, the Sun, Moon and Dikshit are his eight forms.The Viswa and Jegat are pervaded by these forms and hence he is called Visweswara.The blissful and eternal Avyakta, beyond Tamas or darkness,is known as Linga and the eternal light within it, is called Mahadeva”.

The eight forms of Mahadeva here described comprise Viswa and the Jegat. It is thus clear that Linga and Avyakta are their synonyms. The Pandit may now be safely assured that the poor authors of these religious texts have never dared to trespass upon his dearest property the earthy sphere. The religious evolution they described starts with Mahat or Budhi Tatwom succeeded by Bramha, and Bramha creates only the Bhutas or subtle elements.

‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡••

The Pandit might here insist upon his interpretation of Bhutas as applying to all the created objects in his material world, as if he is able to explain all else in the quotation consistently. Does Linga or Avyakta, mentioned here, represent the earth on which the Pandits’ Bhutas reside ? What is the harm if Bhutas are explained as Devils, that also being a common meaning in Sanskrit?He may, for ought we know, one fine morning begin to explain the word as such too; there is no guarrantee as to what he will not attempt, because the criterion upon which he bases his interpretations is unknown to himself. His inability all

along, to explain reasonably two lines combined from quotations of this kind, ought to have ere this convinced him of his mistaken procedure, if only he possessed a grain of common sense in him. He may here be informed once for all, that in spite of his objectionable efforts to reduce the great Bramha and his Jegat to earthy stuff, they would still remain as sacred and important items in our hoary religion, to those who care for their use.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡••

Q. No. VIII.

“From this, the great seed of the nature of Prad hana and Purusha originated known by the names, Mahan, Atma, Mati, Bramha, Prabudhi, khyati, Eswara, Pregna, Dhriti, Smriti and Samvit. The blissful eternal light called Avyakta is known as Linga, and the vedas say that Maheswara is Linga. Avyakta denotes Siva and Linga is the Paramom or Saguna body of Bramhan. Avyakta itself is the Parmom or Saguna-bramhan called, Ananta, because it is infinite.Maheswara is beyond this Avyakta and the great egg came out of this Avyakta. Bramha came out of this egg and created the Jegat. The Triads are the three forms of Rudra. Tamas is Agni or fire, Rejas is Bramha and Satwa is Vishnu. The wife of Rudra of whom you spoke is his own essence the eternal Vishnu with a single sringa or horn whose body is the water of Maya. The region of Dhruva or Polar star is higher than that of the Rishis. Vishnu resides there in the form of Dharma. Satya-loka is six koti Yojanas above the region of Prajapati. It is known as Bramha-loka where there is no mortality. It is the path for

the yogis. In that Bramha’s city is the Vishnu-loka reaching which none has to return. Above this Bramha’s abode is the bright region of Hara surrounded by fire. From the midst of Purusha and Avyakta, Mahatwom or greatness occurred. It is known as Ahamkara and Mahan. Purusha is Vishnu named also Siva. Avyakta is Uma named also Sri. By their combination Ahamkara originated named Guha the commander-in-chief. The Purusha inside the body known as Kshetregna the life principle, is himself the Soma described here. Vishnu is the Paramatma that pervades over all the Devas. The Vishnu who is described as single and sometimes as ten, is Aditya or Sun possessing all the glories of Yoga. The Veda is Bramha who is adored daily by Bramha-yegna. In these, the Para-Bramhan is referred to by the names Narayana, Siva, Vishnu, Sankara and Purushottama. The eleven Adityas who have come down to the earth are the products of Prakriti called Virajas, the twelth is of my nature named Vishnu.”

In going through valuable quotations like the above, overwhelming with clear and detail explanations of religious technicalities, the temptation is irresistible to condemn in the strongest terms, the ignorant perversity and the insolent intrusion of the modern Pandit in his unauthorised and unqualified attempt to soil the sacred texts with his irrelevant and low type of interpretations. The philosophical ideas here expressed are so prominent and unmistakable that even the blind can feel their distinct forms and character. It is not difficult to notice in this quotation that the terms, Uma, Sri, Linga, Prakriti and Avyakta are synonymously used, as also Purusha, Vishnu and Siva, the former set referring to the material causes or Upadana-karana and the latter to the efficient or Nimitha-karana. The most misleading fact

underlying the mistakes of current interpretations is, as already explained, the conception that the Avyakta or Prakriti here described is the same as that understood in the ordinary philosophical analysis of the material world. Although the same terms are often used, a serious religious distinction is philosophically maintained in the religious literature. All the items specified have two opposite tendencies, to evolve and to involve, the former being defined as of the nature of Avidya and the latter of pure Maya with which alone religion deals. The Avyakta here described does not represent the ignorance or darkness denoted by Avidya to which the origin of the material world is traced. The religious Avyakta and Prakriti point distinctly to the bright region of light devoid of individualities and restrictions of finiteness. They allude to the endless infinity known as Ananta.

‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The terms Rishi, Dhruva, Aditya, Soma, Sringa &c, are highly philosophical and purely technical, and the Pandit in his generous mood is probably anxious to convert them into some practically useful objects with which he is familiar, and to publish his made-easy series for the benefit of his fellow country-men, without himself looking into the original literature. But in this process of his transformation of religious subjects into historical and geographical text books for school children, he could only get hold of low material ideas which his intellect is capable of grasping. The foreign critic and his indigenous imitator base their arguments for modern enlightened criticisms, upon the stuff furnished by the Pandit and they have by nature, formed for themselves a preconceived opinion as to the real contents of the texts without a look into the original. The main object of their

labours being merely critical without a personal interest for religious enquiry, nothing more than the apparent defects, now made so much of in modern critical reviews, could be perceived by their self-prejudiced eyes.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É
‡§ï‡•å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡••

*** Q. No. IX.***

“In the treatment of a change, Avyakta is described as Kshethra and Bramha as Kshetregna, in their mutual relation as the container and the contained.This creation of Prakriti directed by Kshetragna, originated at first like a flash of lightning, without the work of Budhi. He who correctly understands this birth of Hiranyagarbha will obtain all happiness;and in his practice of involutionary process he will secure emancipation. Bramha’s day is known as creation and night as destruction. Of course he has neither night nor day, they are so explained simply for the instruction of man. Pradhana is Tama and Purusha is Satwa.When they are in their sameness of nature, it is called Laya. When Pradhana is agitated, Rejas originates, and in the disturbed state of the gunas creation begins. Thus the Triad springs up. Rejas is Bramha that creates, Tamas is Agni in the form of Time, and Satwa is Vishnu who is neutral. They represent the three fires and the three Vedas. They are mutually dependant and never separated from each other. Purusha is Para and Prakriti is Paraa. He is named Purusha on account of his residing in Puri or body. Being the first and unoriginated, he is called Swayombhu; being fit object for worship, he is Yegna; being omniscient, he is Kavi; being the first Agni known as the Sun, he is

Kapila. He is pregnant with hiranyom, wealth or brightness, or he produces the same and hence known as Hiranyagerbha in the Puranas. Directed by Eswara, Pradhana acts at the time of creation, and Bramha and Budhi simultaneously originate. He is called Triguna because of the three divisions, and Chatur-vyuha on account of four divisions. He is named Atma on account of his capacity to take any form he siezes. He pervades everything and therefore he is Rishi,he enters into everything and therefore he is Vishnu, he protects everyone and therefore Prejapati, he is the god of the gods and therefore Mahadeva”.

Several important terms are clearly explained here such as, Kshetragna, Hiranyagerbha, Swayambhu, Yegna, Kavi, Kapila, Atma, Rishi, Prejapati, Vishnu and Mahadeva. Most of these names probably convey no important meanings yet to the Pandit. Kapila especially is described as the first Agni or fire called Aditya or Sun.

‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••

The critic always wants to establish that Kapila of the Puranas is only an author of books who flourished in India in some century A. D. Has he any other sensible meaning to apply here? To him everything is mythology and to the Pandit, everything is anthropology. Thus, from both of them there is no apology even for their mistakes. It is highly desirable at this stage to form some definite idea of Bramha or Hiranyagerbha. The Puranic descriptions are generally explained in the commentaries as follows.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡••

It is indeed a pity that neither the original texts nor their commentaries conform to the enlightened views of the

modern interpreters. The application of the term Budhi as used here, is limited to that particular tendency of the Intellect to turn back inwards to the direction of Bramhan, No other display of the Intellect is recognised as Budhi in our religious literature. The conception of the totality of such Budhis is known as Bramha, Hiranyagerbha, Mahan and Atma.The modern interpreters are thus quite safe from the clutches of this Bramha. Their superior intellects are too strong for the poor old Bramha to bear.

Bramha could, under the circumstances, hardly find at any time in his life, a large number of poor intellects as specified here, falling within his sway,

‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§É
‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ñ‡§≤‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡••

Q. No. X.

“Bramha is Rejas, Vishnu and Siva are Satwic. Krishna of Go-lokais beyond Prakriti and devoid of qualities. The ignorant people alone talk of Siva as Tamasic. The five Pranas or vital airs constitue Vishnu. Mind represents Bramha and Prejapathi Bramhan is the eternal light meditated upon by the Yogis and Prakriti is its power or Sakti. The Bramhan viewed as inclined to crcate is known as Purusha, as inclined to materiality, is called Vishayi. Parvati and Durga represent Budhi, Bramha denotes Manas, Krishna denotes Dharma, Maheswara denotes Gnana and the Devas represent the senses. They dwell within all the creatures witnessing their deeds. The name Narayana is explained thus. Nara means Mukti called Sarupya and Ayanom is path. Nara means sins committed and Ayanom is going. Narom is liberation and Ayanom is

Gnana. The endless or infinite as described in the Vedas, Puranas, Sastras and Yogas, is Ananta. Mukunda means, he who grants Bhakti, also emancipation. Madhusudana is explained by the wise as the destroyer of Madhu the Asura, but in the Vedas it is explained somewhat differently. It alludes to the refuge for Karmas as well as for the devotees. It also means the destroyer of all desires towards transient pleasures. Kesava means lying in water or residing in all the bodies. Kamsari means the destroyer of Kamsa, or of sins, of disease, of obstruction or of grief. Hari means destroyer of even the Viswa in the form of Rudra. Sleep and other tendencies are the Kalas of Prakriti. Ahamkara, avarice &c. belong to Adharma. Siva is the light of Gnana and I am Atma without Gunas. When I enter into the Prakriti, I am Saguna or with Guna. Dharma, Sesha, Surya, Soma, Munis, Manus, Devas, Jivan-muktas and devotees, all pertain to my Kala which destroys worldly miseries”.

A number of technical terms are here defined, explaining their real significance as used in the religious literature and there is no doubt that all of them invariably allude to certain definite ideas diametrically opposed to the views of the Pandit and the Critic. Bramha, Vishnu and Siva clearly represent the conceptions of totalities or the general religious bases denoting God’s glories. Bramha has been explained already as alluding to the totality of Budhi or the determination to involve. As all the religious advancement has to start with this turn of mind, it is described as Bramha’s creation. The work of maintaining and developing this Budhi points to Vishnu and preservation. Rudra as destroyer has two functions here. He has to destroy the worldly desires of man before Bramha could create the Budhi which turns back to the Bramhan. He has also to destroy the good effects of Bramha’s and Vishnu’s workings before final

emancipation could be secured. Thus the three gods here specified are not virtually distinct and separate, and they cannot possibly continue to exist as such. Vide quotation 9.

‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§® ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

In the conceptions of Bramha,Vishnu and Siva, the following important points have therefore to be ever kept before our view to avoid doubt and confusion.

(1) The region of the Triad is the sphere of Satwic Maya, and not of Avidya, which is exactly the jurisdiction of the modern interpreters.

(2) The very nature of the functions of the Triad is involutionary. The creation of Bramha or evolution virtually means the destruction of all the worldly desires and
the consequent rising of a devotional tendency in man.

(3) Vishnu preserves and developes the Budhi created by Bramha and does not preserve any other absurdities.

(4) Siva is primarily the cause of Bramha’s creation by his destroying the worldly desires, and lastly he is the cause of final liberation by annihilating the good effects of religious devotion and practice.

(5) Bramha, Vishnu and Siva as explained above, exhaust the religious requirements for the final emancipation of man. It is certainly most unfortunate that these highly philosophical, scientific and religious instructions conveyed through the sacred texts by the ancient venerable sages, are now shamelessly interpreted by the indigenous Pandit himself as cock and bull stories, and sneeringly reviewed by the foreign critic as old-world simplicties and ignorant superstitions. It is equally pitiable that they are explained by the Theosophists as visions in the narcotic plains and the workings of the hobgoblins. Under the present state of

affairs, it is one of the most difficult and hopeless task to convince the modern commentators of ancient religious texts, if they will not condescend to look into the original. Off-hand criticisms on imaginary originals volunteered without the least interest or reverence for the sacredness of the subject could not possibly be met by any known methods of argumentation.

‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§®
‡§Ö‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡••

Q. No. XI.

“Siva is Alinga without Gunas and Linga is Avyakta or Prakriti. Rudra is pure and holy and is therefore named Siva in the Puranas. Bramha is Paramatma being eternal Intelligence. When everything is dissolved at night, he sleeps in the waters of the ocean and hence called Narayana. Viswara, Mahan, Pregna, Manas, Bramha, Chiti, Smriti, Khyati, Samvit, Eswara and Mati are the synonyms for this great Intelligence, whose favour is obtained by Prana-yama. Viswara means dislike for materialities. Mahan means the greatest among the Tatwas, Pregna is the seat of knowledge, Manas is mental faculty and Bramha is the power of expansion and progress. Chiti is understanding power, Smriti is memory, Samvit is the spot from which every thing is obtained. Khyati is what is declared as gnana. The omniscient at the head of all Tatwas is Eswara,the thinking or reflecting faculty is Mati. That which cognises and points out the knowledge is Budhi. The all-pervading Parameswara, is known as Sarva as the basis of Bramhanda, as Bhava in the waters, as Rudra in the fire, as Ugra in the air, as Bhima in the earth, as Maheswara in egoism and as Esa in Budhi. Everything from Bramha downwards is
styled Pasu or cattle, being bound by the cords of materiality. Rudra, their ruler is Pasu-pati. The 24 Tatwas

constitute the bondage which is destroyed by worshipping Siva. His worship is called Bhakti which is of three kinds, by thought word and deed. Meditating his forms as the material cause is mental worship. The repetition of Manthras is worship by word, and Prana-yama and similar acts are worship by deed. Avidya is divided into five classes, Tama, Moha, Mahamoha, Tamisra, and Andha-tamisra. Avidya itself is Tama or ignorance. Moha is egoism. Mahamoha is desire. Tamisra is anger. Andha-Tamisra is clinging to life and false knowledge. Artha, the signified object is Siva, and its name is called Gowri or Parvati. Everything is included in Linga or Avyakta and it should be worshipped for obtaining liberation. Siva has eight forms or Tatwas which refer to the bases of the items comprising the body of man. Sarva refers to the earthy portion, Bhava to water, Pasu-pati to fire, Esa to air, Bhima to Akasa, Mahadeva to mind, Ugra to individual Atma. The eighth is the Atma pervading everywhere whose worship procures liberation. Siva as the material and efficient causes of the Universe has five forms called Pancha-bramha. The first is Kshetragna, the enjoyer of everything coming under Prakriti. The second is Tatpurusha representing Prakriti itself. The third is Aghora representing Budhi as developed by the eight Angas of Yoga. The fourth is Vamadeva referring to the all-pervading Ahamkara. The fifth is Sadyojata referring to the mind. Siva is the internal lord of all, in the forms of Pragna, Tyjasa and Viswa, the bases for the three states of sleeping, dreaming and waking. He is described as of four forms, namely, Pramata, Pramana, Prameya and Pramiti, also as the Karta or doer, Kriya or act, Karya or effect, and Karana or instrument”,

This lengthy quotation is no doubt full of technical details disclosing strange news to the Pandit. Being him-

self a stranger to the religious texts, it is nothing surprising that their contents appear brand-new to him. The only matter for regret however is, that in spite of the numerous passages reproduced, he could hardly find a single line in them corroborating the crude and unreasonable views he has long formed presumptuously,without a study of the subject.The various forms of Bramhan here enumerated refer to its glories in the sphere of Satwic Maya or Prakriti, explained as Tatwas for the religious advancement of the pious devotees. The sphere of modern interpreters is also clearly defined and classified in the language of the Puranas and is reproduced below from the above quotation. A complete and earnest study of its geography will surely benefit them to a great extent, and might also save the poor religious Hindus in the land from their further unnecessary interference.

‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡••

All the grand historical and geographical explanations hitherto propogated by the modern interpreters, logicallyf all under this classification of Avidya, a region which they are naturally unwilling to quit. It is clearly described in the above passage as the field of human passions and desires for material objects which no man can ever hope to satisfy during his short period of existence.

‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç
‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§§‡•ç
‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•á ‡§ú‡•É‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡••

*** Q. No. XII.***

“The Eswara full of purity and blissfulness is named Siva. Rudra signifies removal of grief. When Siva pervades everywhere, he is called Vishnu. Siva viewed as the material cause or originator of every form, he is called PitaMaha or Bramha. When Siva annihilates all ideas of materiality and removes the miseries of Samsara, like a doctor curing diseases, he is called Samsara-vydya. As Siva remains unaltered under all conditions, he is called Sada-Siva. As he secures knowledge without effort, he is called Sarvagna. When Siva is associated with all the above glories and viewed as separate from Para-Bramhan, he is called Parama·π≠ma”.

Here Siva is described as taking the forms and doing the works of Bramha, Vishnu and Rudra. It is hoped that the explanations already furnished will suffice to enable us to understand this description correctly. The three gods are said to be distinguished only by their functions, which in themselves cannot be distinctly demarcated as they depend upon each other. Siva meaning auspicious, as used here is a general name for all the functions of the three gods together.

*** Q. No. XIII.***

“Hiranyagerbha is known as representing Budhi. In the Sankhya philosophy, he is called Mahan, Virinchi &c, and he is also marked by a single letter”.

The synonymous terms for Bramha are here, given, which have been already noticed in the previous quotatious. We may however note that there are no contradictions in the explanations and definitions furnished by the different Puranas on any points hitherto examined.

Q. No. XIV.

“From the Satwic guna of the subtle elements the Gnana-saktis originated. From their totality, mind arose as an instrument, the guiding principle of which is Bramha known as Hiranyagerbha. Again from the Rajasic guna of the subtle elements, the Kriti-saktis originated. From their totality Prana arose, the guiding principle of which is Vishnu known as Sutratma. Maheswara is seated in both the varieties of Saktis known as Anter-yami in the Vedas. Sankara is the witness and the underlying principle of everything in the Jegat. Siva himself is the Linga and Linga is Gameka or a suggestion. Siva comprehends everything but nothing comprehends him. Therefore he is described as Sat, Chit and Ananda. Siva himself is the Linga, but he has no Linga. Bramha, Vishnu and Rudra explained separately belong to the department of Paramatma and they never belong to that of Jiva.Jiva is the reflection in Avidya and not in Maya. The names Bramha, Vishnu and Rudra allude to one and the same object, as the terms sower, cultivator and reaper apply to a single farmer in his dfferent capacities.”

This quotation entirely removes all possible doubts regarding the most vital points. Bramha, Vishnu and Rudra are stated to be only different names of Bramhan, viewed in different aspects. The Triads are declared to belong to the department of Maya and not to that of Avidya. Linga or Avyakta belongs to Siva and is a suggestion through which Siva may be discovered. Such unambiguous definitions and explanations are furnished throughout the religious literature, but they are not capable of being understood without even reading them. The modern Pandit of course is an exception to this ordinary rule. He is gifted with the powers of divine vision especially in religious matters. As

a matter of fact, he has no ordinary eyes even, at present, to see the serious consequences of his suicidal stubbornness. His own status and respect once depended entirely upon his correct knowledge of the subject and his capacity to enlighten others. But he is now virtually trying his utmost to destroy the very life and importance of the literature itself.

‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ-
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡§™‡§æ‡§•‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§•‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§É
‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§®‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡••

Q. No. XV.

“In the Vedas, Puranas, Upanishads and in the Sastras on Astrology, Sankhya, Yoga, Medicine &c., I am called by several names which owe their origin, to my attributes and workings. I shall explain to you the meanings of such terms in accordance with Nirukta. My Prakriti is Satwic and consists of 18 gunas. She is the eternal, true and in vulnerable Atma. From her everything good originates such as Tapas and Yegna. The Purana-purusha, Virat known as Anirudha, the creator and destroyer of the Lokas, originates from her. After the Bramhic night, a bright lotus originated in which Bramha was born, from the pleasure of Anirudha. At the end of the Bramhic day, Rudra was similarly born from his anger. The functions of these two gods are creation and destruction showing the two methods of religious progress for the benefit of mankind. Rudra is an austere Yogi, wearing matted hair. He is fond of cremation grounds and is the destroyer of the Tripuras. He is of the nature of Narayana and appears in every Yuga. If therefore, he is worshipped, Narayana is greatly pleased. Dharma is involutionary in nature and it leads to prosperity. I am the single and eternal refuge for mankind. Dharma

is known as Vrisha or bull. I am therefore Vrisha in accordance with dictionary meaning. Kapi or monkey, Varaha or boar, Sreshta or great and Vrisha or bull are the terms used to represent Dharma. Kasyapa Prajapati therefore called me by the name of Vrisha-kapi”.

This quotation like the previous ones explains that different names are used in the religious texts to describe the attributes and workings of Apara or Sabda Bramhan, and that they should not be taken to denote different and separate entities. Bramha and Rudra as well as their functions, creation and destruction described here are clearly mentioned as referring to two necessary processes prescribed for the religious advancement of man.

‡§è‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§≠‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•å‡••

By devotion and Tapas, one has therefore to transform himself into all these holy deities, as instructed in detail by the Puranic descriptions of their various functions. This is the real import of the classification and description of the Triads in our religious literature. The subject in its entirety as well as in its parts is therefore extremely serious and sacred. It is hoped that there is no necessity at this stage of the essay to repeat the warning against the silly tendency of the modern day to treat such matters as allegories and mythologies. We have by this time completely proved the entire absurdity of such a blasphemous attitude. No impure heart, tongue or hand of man shall therefore dare to meddle with it with impunity.

‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•å ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•å
‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡••

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1699280904Screenshot(40"/>.png)Practically ample quotations are here noted for the easy comprehension of the real significance of the three terms explained above, if only there be the will to catch their correct meaning without any bias or prejudice. The difficulty ordinarily experienced by many is owing to their having been previously prepared with their own commentaries without ever dreaming of the original texts. In 99 cases out of 100 especially in religious matters, judgement before trial is exactly the state of affairs; and everybody is allowed with impunity to exercise the privilege of offering their own views even while umasked. It is the mistaken interpretation that is virtually circulated among the people, by the so-called Pundit authorities and taken for the real contents of the texts. An enquiry as to how such mistaken notions have gradually taken root in the minds of the public, might perhaps be an interesting and useful topic for the historian, but it would be out of place here, and certainly unnecessary, as a direct examination of the texts themselves is the avowed object of this little volume. When the true gist of the matter is understood, it may however be possible to discover, how these high philosophical ideas and facts have deteriorated to their present condition owing to the ignorance of the fundamental principles and formulas, which undoubtedly demand for their correct understanding, higher culture, deeper thought and greater interest than are available in the average worldly-wise man.

It is not very difficult to make out clearly from the various passages quoted above, that the Tri-murtis are the three different phases and conditions of one and the only entity. They are always mutually connected with and mutually dependent on each other. It must also be particularly observed that all of them stand above the level of the phenomenal and material existence which is but the product

of Avidya (vide Q. 14) Apart from this general description, their special functions are compared to those of a farmer performing himself the work of sowing, growing and reaping. Bramha is described as representing Manas or Budhi in its purest condition giving rise to Gnana or real knowledge. Vishnu represents Dharma (which comprises Gnana, Dhyana, Sama and Dama) fostering and maintaining the knowledge obtained. Rudra destroys sorrow and misery and extracts pure knowledge like the reaper who cuts off the straw and secures the crop. The root meanings of these terms are in themselves sufficiently significant. From Brimh, to develop or increase, Bramah denotes developed Intelligence. From Vis to pervade, Vishnu refers to the developed Intelligence pervading everywhere and understanding everything in its true and philosophical light. From Rud and Dra to destroy pain, Rudra denotes the annihilation of all obstacles to the permanent securing of the Gnana that has been originated and fostered already. Vishnu and Rudra are thus dependent on Bramah to start with Gnana and Bramah cannot continue to be useful without the help of Vishnu and Rudra. Their relative superiority is thus an irrelevant and illogical question for discussion. But the religious disputes frequently arising among ordinary people are based on the mistaken supposition that their functions are simply and directly connected with the creation, preservation and destruction of this material world, glorious as it is with all its miseries and wickedness. A little thought and reading will convince us of the absurdity of the supposition. As clearly explained in the preceding pages, the mundane affairs are the products of Avidya enforcing the eternal laws of Karma, the enactment of Easwara. Otherwise, taking even the popular view of the matter, it would virtually result in holding the Legislative Councils and the High

Courts responsible for all the offences perpetrated in the world. The Tri-Murtis are however meant only for those few who are wise enough and bold enough to step out of the beaten path of worldly wisdom. Thus, the majority of sectarian quarrels now taking place, is based upon ignorance combined with Egoism and pride and is often caused by lucrative considerations relating to rich temples and religious Mutts. The divine and sacred ideas are dragged down for the purpose of satisfying mean and selfish ends and such attempts deserve to be treated only as acts of irreligion and blasphemy.

In the very passages here quoted, we find several synonymous terms used to denote each of the Tri-murtis as noted below. Similar free use of words will be found all over the religious texts. But it must be noted that there might be shades of difference in their meanings depending upon the occasions on which they are applied.

(1) Mahan, Kshetragna, Virinchi, Pitamaha etc., for Bramah.

(2) Hari, Vasudeva, Narayana, Vrisha-kapi etc., for Vishnu.

(3) Easwara, Mahadeva, Visweswara, Siva, Hara etc., for Rudra.

Some of these words are almost interchangeable and the Sahasranamas contain several words used in praise of all the three without any distinction. The Puranas whose titles point to their being Vaishnavite in character, often extol the greatness of Siva and vice versa. All these clearly show that no difference is meant to be observed among the status of the Tri-murtis.

‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡••
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡••

‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡••

These passages are neither contradictions, nor even compromises, but are correct explanations of the true signi- ficance of the Tri-murtis as treated in the religious texts.Unfortunately, they cannot but be inconsistent in accordance with the current unauthorised misinterpretations. Neither the venerable authors of the sacred texts nor those who will not stoop to deliver judgment without a trial, could ever hope to satisfy these Panditasters. I fear, time has sufficiently advanced, that self-made commentaries on imaginary originals are more than we could bear any longer.

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1699283337Screenshot(41"/>.png)Like the Tri-murtis just noticed, who are treated as primary Gods in the religious literature, there are Goddesses described as their respective consorts and others to whom different functions are assigned. They refer to the Saktis or active principles underlying the processes of religious evolution and involution detailed in the texts. It is confidently hoped that an examination of the original passages referring to them will furnish us with a correct and clear idea of their significance too.

Quotation No. I.

‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•å‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

Q. No II.

‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•à‡§µ ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§É‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•à‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú ‡§µ‡§®‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡••

** ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••**

*** Q. No. III.***

‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§æ‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

** * Q. No. IV.***

‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•á ‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡•à ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§¶‡§ø‡•§
‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§á‡§π ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

** Q. No. V.**

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§É‡•§

‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•å ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§• ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡•§
‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å‡•§
