‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§§‡§É
‡§∏‡•ã‡§¢‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡§π‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡§™‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

**5. **The passages quoted here referring to the Gods are somewhat simple and explicit. In quotation 1, thirty-

three Devas are enumerated and their multiples by hundreds and thousands making up 33 crores, den te only their glories or the immense varieties of functions each is capable of. A crore or koti ordinarily points to the highest number. In quotation 4, eleven Davas or Vykarikas are mentioned, representing the 10 senses and the mind. The first 3 quotations place the position and status of Indra beyond doubt. He is the same as Kshetregna or Individual soul often noticed in the preceding pages. The Yekshas, Rakshasas, Danavas, Gendharvas mentioned in quotations 4 and 5, refer to the glories of Indra as viewed in different aspects, and virtually represent the characteristic tendencies in man. Quotation 6 locates all of them in the various parts of the human body and refers to the deities presiding over the Vasanas, meaning thereby the respective energies or enforcing laws of the the Eswara, which remain as the bases for the formation and work of the Vasanas. The Vasauas formed being generally good or bad in accordance with the nature of the individual’s Karmas, their tendencies are classified as Dyva or sura, leading to salvation and perdition respectively. The enumeration given in quotation 1, from 33 crores downwards reducing the number to one at last, clearly explains the gist of the whole matter, without the least scope for doubt, ambiguity or reasonable possibility of extraneous interpretations. The Dyvi and the Asuri tendencies in man, explained in the last quotation from the Bhagavat-Gita include the Rakshasi according to recognised commentaries. The Asuri refers only to the evil tendencies originating from selfish desires, but the Rakshasi specifies the inclinations to acts of cruelty in man. In quotation 4, we find the root meaning of the word Asura explained. Asu means Prana or life; thus denoting the tendency to seek after material comforts in the interest of the physical body. Besides these

general descriptions of human tendencies, the technical terms used such as, Yekshas, Gendhervas, Pisachas &c., refer to the glories of Indra as already noticed, and are explained clearly at the end of quotation 4, as representing the eight divine stages resulting from Yoga practice. They correspond to the eight Sidhis, such as, Anima, Mahima &c., which bestow control over the eight Prakritis respectively. Thus far the descriptions given are no doubt clear enough. If only the method of treatment of the subject, as followed in the religious literature, is not misunderstood, it is not at all difficult to make out the descriptions given, as exactly pertaining to the Psychological and physiological sciences. The ignorance of this method of treatment so evident in the popular misinterpretations, is nevertheless not so surprising or dangerous as the learned absurdities of the Theosophical elucidations. The attempt of that creed to explain away Eastern religion by Western commentaries favourably or otherwise, is entirely futile and unnecessarily misleading. Seriously considered, their main object as generally propogated, appears to be prima-facie objectionable, especially in a religious light. It is ordinarily supposed that the Theosophists are trying only to pick up the best portions of every existing religion and combine the whole with the most valuable discoveries of modern science for the benefit of all man-kind. It is not however certain whether this would prove useful to the public in any manner, even if it were ever practicable, but at any rate, it might have been wiser and less harmful, if they started a new religion of their own, as it would be liable to stand or fall on its own merits without affecting the others. The process in question doubtless implies, at the very commencement, an undesirable disrespectful and unmeritted insinuation upon the disinterested efforts of the most venerable originators of every religion,

who are naturally and reasonably understood as having been persons of immense wisdom, sympathy aud religious devotion, and are acknowledged as fit and competent mediators between God and man, in the interest of the latter. That their earnest productions called religions should be so freely and so easily taken to contain 99 per cent of worthless stuff and consequently requiring to pick up the remaining valuable portions, if any, from their midst, is, I daresay in itself a sure sign of ignorance, insolence and irreligion. It is extremely doubtful whether a single member could be found in this new creed, fit to come forward boldly as having acquired a thorough and correct knowledge of any one religion, much less of all religions or all sciences even. The process adopted for surveying in one glance all the existingreligions in the world and for extracting their essences as one chemical product, must necessarily remain a divine secret for ever. Nor is it sufficiently intelligible how the results of modern material sciences, could have retrospective effect upon ancient spiritual religions, and why the latter should ever care for or depend upon the help of the former.

With reference to the Yekshas, Danavas, Rakshasas, Genthervas &c., so clearly explained in soveral of the passages just quoted, it is impossible to pass over without noticing that the description offered in the Theosophical fashion noted below, will unhesitatingly prove how completely it is wrong and how far away it is, from the truth.

‘Sanathana-Dharma’ by Mrs. Besant, page 87 Chapter II ‘On the Many’.

“To this brief sketch of the world process it should be added that the early human races preceding the Aryan are often referred to under the names of Danavas and Daityas, huge beings of enormous strength and energy, who carried

on many a struggle with the Devas themselves. The Rakshasas were another race, more brutal in nature, usually malformed, huge, cruel, powerful, cannibals, the terror of milder races. They possessed moreover, many magical secrets of a dark kind, which they used for terrorising and oppressing. All these have long entirely disappeared from the earth”.

I humbly trust that the irrelevancy and the absurdity of the above elucidation are self-evident; and there is no doubt that many or most of the important items in our sacred religion are dealt with in this off-hand and ridiculous manner. The very nature of the commencement of this special and curious kind of work strikes one clearly as an unnecessary, profitless and pernicious effort, inevitably doomed.

“Begun in folly ended in disgrace
Fit consummation of an earthly race”.

‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡••

6. The significance of the Pitris may be enquired into next, as they are often found apparently confounded with the Devas just noticed. They however deserve a closer examination for the reason that they are commonly understood to be directly connected with and sometimes even representing our own departed ancestors. Besides, they are considered to be more in touch with the human race than the Devas or other Gods.

** Quotation No. I.**

‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§

‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Q. No. II.

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ω‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡••

‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡§∑‡§°‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. III.

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§• ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ó‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ú‡•à‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§™‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡••

‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•á‡•§

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡•§
‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. IV.

‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡••

‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•É‡§õ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§É‡•§

‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§õ‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§• ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§• ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§π‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. V.

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•§

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡§∑‡§°‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡•å ‡§∞‡§∏‡•å ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•å ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•å ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡•å‡•§
‡§®‡§≠‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§á‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§∏‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•à‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•å‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∑‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§

‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§ã‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ê‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§É‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§≠‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§≠‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•á ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§¶‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§π‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡•å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•§

‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡§µ‡§£‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•å‡§∑‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡••

‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§
‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡•§
‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á‡••

‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ü‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡•§
‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§π‡•§
‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á !
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡••

‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Quotation. No. I.

“Bramha concentrated his mind and brought out of it the Tan-mathras or subtle elements. He meditated upon the forms of everything and these elements originated from his body in smoky colour. Bramha saw them seated in the organic world and looking upwards. He said that they shall be the Pitris or fathers of all the Griha-imedhins. Those that looked up were specially named Nandi-mukhas. Bramha also prescribed a path for the Pitris called Dekshinayana”.

The Pitris are here clearly defined as representing the subtle elements, originating from Bramha, seated in the organic world and looking upwards. They are however saidto be the Pitris only of Griha-medhins or intelligent and pure people. The elements in themselves are naturally the fathers, originators or the material cause for all existing things. But the term Pitris is here restricted to their conception as pure and leading upwards, all the material associations leading downwards being entirely eliminated. We will see more of this in the subsequent quotations.

** Q. No II.**

“The subtle elements are known as Tan-mathras, because they remain pure and unmixed. They are also called Aviseshas, because they are not perceptible and are devoid of the three qualities known as Santa, Ghora and Mudha. The creation by the subtle elements is by their intermixture, producing the gross elements known as Visesha and perceptible by the senses, each element possessing its own quality as well as the qualities of the elements preceding. Bramha created the Pitris from both of his sides, at the interval between day and night. Bramba’s form in the middle of day and night is thus more glorious, and the Rishis, Devas, Asuras and Manus therefore worship that form with great devotion. The Devas were created in the

day time and the Asuras at night. The day is Satwic, the night is Tamasic and the interval is Sandya when a great light proceeded from Bramha. The Pitris grant the boon of knowledge and are therefore worshipped by Sradhas. The Pitris by their Yoga then please the Soma, the protector of the three Lokas. In the Sradha ceremonies therefore, Yogis should be procured as far as possible, because the strength of the Pitris depends on their Yoga which produces Soma. Here Soma represents the ocean of Akasa which is the basis for all the elements and the Devas. All the Lowkik water proceeds from this Akasic Soma which supports the universe. This is the real fact. The six seasons of the year called Ritus are explained in the Sastras as Pitris and Devas. Among the Pitris, the Agni-hotris or worshippers of fire are known as Berhishads, those who do not so worship are Agnishwathas and those who perform Somayegna are Somapithis”.

The Pitris have been already explained as representing the subtle elements. Yoga is here said to be their distinguishing feature. They are created at Sandhya or between the day and night of Bramha which refer to the creations of Devas and Asuras. This Puranic narration distinctly explains the significance of the Pitris. The creation of the Pitris thus points out the transition stage from the Asuri to the Dyvi nature, from materiality to the religious and philosophical. The Yoga pertaining to Tan-mathras and leading to the higher states of philosophical meditation is here enunciated. By satisfying the Pitris, Soma is said to be pleased. The technical Soma is an entirely misunderstood and highly abused term, among the Sanskrit Pandits and the so-called Vydiks at present. The Yegnas or devotional acts misinterpreted as prescribing the killing of sheep and drinking of liquor, originate chiefly from the ignorance of the meaning

of the term Soma. We have noticed its real significance already in several places and it is here defined particularly in connection with the very Sradha ceremonies, leaving no scope for misunderstanding.

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Soma here represents the Chit-Akasa, a stage superior to the Tan-mathras or Pitris, alluding to a perfectly pure, devotional and tranquil state of mind. This Soma can never be pleased by acts of cruelty or ignorance, actuated by avarice, greed, hatred and all other associates of the modern interpretation of Yeguss. ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É \‡•§ Devotion to Vishnu or Vishnu himself is Yegna according to the Vedas. This sacred religious precept has now unfortunately deteriorated so far as to signify the abominable ceremonies of a butcher and a drunkard.

‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§õ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

** Q. No. III.**

“In the heavens, there are seven classes of Pitris, three of them are formless, but four of them have forms. The formless classes belong to the Virat, they are worshipped by the Devas and are known as Vyrajas. The class of Pitris who secure liberation only at the end of Bramha’s day owing to their incomplete Yoga, has & mind-born daughter named Mena, the wife of Himavat. Minaka is his son and Krowncha his son, from whom the name Krowncha-dwipa originated. Mens gave birth to three daughters, all Yoginis, named Uma, Ekaparna and Aparna, married to Rudra,

Bhrigu and Jygishavya respectively. The Lokas of the Pitris are called Somapatha, or the path to Soma. The Pitris named Agnishwathas and Yejwanas, the sons of Maricha or light, reside in these Lokas, and they are worshipped by the Devas. A similar class of Pitris belonging to the same family, sons of Angira called Havishmanthas, reside in the Sun They are very kind and loving towards their devotees. The chief among them is the Sun. The Sradha ceremony is of three kinds, Nithya or daily, Nymithika or occasional, and Kamya or optional. Among the Bramhins, when the father dies, the sons should perform the Sradha known as Ekodhishta, extending to ten days, at the end of which, the deceased attains to the position of a fourth class Pitri, and afterwards obtains immortality among the three classes of Pitris. The Vedas say that the father takes the form of Vasus, the grandfather that of Rudras and the great-grand-father, that of Adityas”.

We could easily see from this quotation that the varieties of Pitris enumerated, allude to certain religious and philosophical facts, and that the Sradha ceremonies prescribed are meant for taking the deceased ancestors to the positions √•ssigned to the Pitris. We shall soon see more of this in detail.

** Q. No. IV.**

“The Pitris are the sons of the original Devas, and they are adored by the Devas, Dana vas, men, Yekshas, Rakshasas, Gendharvas, Kinnaras and Mahoragas. When the Pitris are pleased, they please all by bestowing blessings; therefore Bramha ordered all people to perform Sradhas to the Pitris. When the Devas were created by Bramha, theywere asked to worship him. Disobeying this order, the Devas looked after their own interest. They were therefore cursed by Bramha to become ignorant. Then they begged

for pardon. Bramha asked them to go to Pitris and get enlightened. The Devas did accordingly and when they left the Pitris, the latter addressed the Devas as sons. The Devas returned and informed Bramha of all this, and Bramha replied that the Devas are not bestowers of Gnana but only of rebirths and that they shall therefore be reckoned as sons of the Pitris. Thus the Pitris and the Devas became mutually sons and fathers. When the Pitris are pleased by Sradhas, Soma is pleased and Soma pleases the Lokas. The Pitris being everywhere, in the ocean, in the hills, in the movable and in the immovable, wherever the three balls of rice are offered at the Sradha, saying the name and gotra of the deceased ancestors, the Pitris grant their blessings. The Pitris sholud be worshipped invariably before the Devas”

The paradox in the mutual parentage of the Devas and the Pitris shall be explained shortly. But we must not fail to notice that the Pandit is acquainted with the cake and the bread alone in the Sradhas here described. The Soma perhaps makes up the necessary drink. The gift of a few coins at the end will perfectly complete the Sradha ceremony.

** Q. No. V.**

“In the Swayambhuva Manwantara, Devas, Asuras and men originated from the body of Bramha. From both his sides, the Pitris originated who respected Bramha as their father. The Vedas and Sastras say that the Rithus or the six seasons in the year are the Devas and Pitris. The Pitris are of three classes, Agnishwathas, Somapithis and Berhishadas. The Rithus are six in number each consisting of two months, named, Sisira, Vasanta, Grishma, Varsha, Sarad and Hima. They are known as the sons of Nimi. They signify the guiding and controlling power of Bramh a in conducting the seasons and not the seasons them‚Äì

selves. They are so named as they are recognised only by the working of these seasons. Nimisha, kala, kashta, Muhurta, day, night and month are divisions of time. Two months make one Rithu, three Rithus one Ayana and two Ayanas one year. The sons of Rithus are the five Arthavas referring to the productive seasons of all created things. They are known as Pitris or fathers and the year as grand-father and Prejapathi. The terms used refer only to the power of conducting the seasons. Agni or fire, the son of Samvatsara is called Rita. From Rita, the Ritavas originated and from them the five Arthavas. There are different kinds of Pitris like the Agnishwathas and Berhishadas. Two daughters, both Yoginis and philosophers, named Mena and Dharani were born from the minds of Agnishwathas and Berhishadas respectively. Mena married Himavat and gave birth to Mynaka as well as Ganga the wife of the ocean. Krowncha is the son of Mynaka from whom Krowncha-dwipa took its naine. Dharani married Meru and brought forth Mandara and three daughters named, Vela, Niyati and Ayati. Ayati married Dhata and Niyati, Vidhata. I shall next narrate to you the Pitris to whom monthly sradhas are offered. They are known as Anu-deva-pitris. It is difficult to know even with great tapas the conditions of the deceased, more so with human eyes. By a mere analogical correspondence in the karmas of the religious people, they are also styled after death, Agnishwathas, Somapas and Berhishadas, but they are not the real Pitris signified by the terms. Those who lead a very honourable life until their death, practising the prescribed devotional acts, join the Pitris and the Devas in heaven, and they are propitiated by monthly Sradhas like the real Pitris. But for those who were wicked and irreligious all their life, and now keep running about as Pretas in the Hell undergoing punishment, three balls of rice should be placed on the ground over the Derbha grass.

There are others who have taken after death, the bodies of lower animals or of vegetables. The rice offered in the Sradha reaches them in the special forins of their food by the force of Manthra as a calf naturally finds out its cow. This is assure 1 by the Rishi named Sanat-kumara who is gifted with divine eyes. These Pitris are known as Bahlikas, Ushiapas and Divakirtis. The dark fortnight is their day-time and the bright fortnight their night. Thus, the Pitris, the Devas, Rithus, Arthavas, half-months and months are mutually considered Pitris. When the Pitris, the Devas and Manushya-pitris are pleased by Sradhas, they bestow all blessings on man”.

The various classifications of the Pitris here furnished are po doubt highly technical and philosophical. The Pandit will of course reduce the whole description to the history of his deceased ancestors whose life is distinctly stated to be different from that of the real Pitris. The Pitris are said to have their children and grand-children. Mena and Dharani are their mind-born daughters, and Vela, Niyati, Ayati,. Uma, Ekaparna, Aparna aud Ganga are grand-daughters. The mountains named Mynaka, Mindara and Krowncha are grand and great grand-children. How could deceased ancestors produce daughters and how these daughters again bring forth mountains, rivers and girls? If the description on the whole is meaningless, why should the Pandit attempt to explain it ?

‡§™‡•á‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§ü‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ü‡§æ
‡§∂‡§æ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï ‡§ò‡•ã‡§ü‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§ü‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡§æ
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

**7.**The passages quote l above furnish varieties of descriptions for the Pitris demanding special explanations

and particularly some sort of reconciliations amongst themselves. There is indeed a commingling of philosophical formulas and facts with the practical ethics concerning the display of veneration towards our personal ancestors. How nicely the grandest facts in religious philosophy are gratually brought down to the discharge of duties to our deceased parents, and how the comin only accepted moral necessity on the subject is taken advantage of to explain the higher and more serious matters, are excellently illustrated in the descriptions furnished.

The respect due to our beloved parents and the cermonies called Sradhas to propitiate them after their death are matters of immediate concern which we could not afford to treat with any indifference. A correct. understanding of the application of the religious rites ordained is therefore of vital importance.

Quotations 1 & 2 vividly detail the distinctions between the senses and the Tan-nathras or subtle elements, the former being known as the Devas and the latter as Pitris. The Puranic narration in quotation 4, of the story leading to the settlement of their parentage mutually, paradoxical as it appears, is but a statement of an important philosophical fact. The existence of the five subtle elements as the source or fathers of all creation, could not be conceived or inferred without using the fanctions of the senses, nor could the formations of the senses be explained without the help of the elements. They are thus mutual originators and therefore styled fathers mutually. But a characteristic difference is noted between them. The natural tendency of the senses as such is to proceed outwards cognising external objects. The conception of the Taumathras beyond the sphere of the senses virtually creates a process of involution by Yogic exercises leading to Guana or true knowledge. The

following lines in the above quotations furnish sufficiently explicit clues to enable us to avoid all possibilities of is-m understanding.

Quotation. No. I.

‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Q. No. II.

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§

Q. No. IV.

‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§® ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§• ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

Q. No. V.

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡••

Thus far, the philosophical relationship and the characteristic differences between the senses and the elements, the original Gods and the Pitris are distinctly represented. The Elements are named Pitris by the fact of their acknowledging and respecting Bramha the creator as their father. Their characteristic tealency ofnature is stated to be Yogaand they are therefore capable of giving Gani. Wartas, the Gods ofsenses have aa opposite tealency in spiceof

their being objects of veneration for mankind. Therefore the Pitris com:nand greater respect and the ceremonies to propitiate them have to be perforined before those prescribed for adoring the Gods. Several classifications of the original Pitris or Elements are noticed in the passages quoted above. Quotation 3 enumerates 7 sets of Pitris in the Heavens, 3 Murthas and 4 Anurthas. Quotation 5 divides the Pitris into Agnishwathas (those who do not worship fire) and Bharhishadas (those who worship fire, fire or Agni generally pointing to Gnana or knowledge. Again, the 6 tithus or bi-monthly periods in the year are called Pitris and are reckoned as Bramha’s sons, meaning thereby the energy or law of Eswara which works by time. The subjoined lines in the quotation state this clearly.

‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

Thus far the original Pitris or subtle-Elements are described. The human Pitris known as the Anudeva. Pitris are also classified as Agnishwatas. and Barhishadas as an imitation of the original Pitris owing to some external correspondence of Karms, but are entirely different from those noticed in the higher sense of the term.

Q. No. V.

‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§É‡••

Among these human Pitris, 3 distinct varieties are mentioned. The deceased ancestors who have attained the Swarga-loka by virtuous life in this world rank first and they are venerated like the real original Pitris explained above, and are styled Manushya Pitris (Q. 5).

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡•§

There are two more sets among the deceased ancestors to be enquired into.

The majority of mankind who have left this earth having probably lived not very honourable lives, it would certainly be unfair and unjust to class then among the Manushya-Pitris just described. These are divided into two sets, one undergoing punishments in the Hell as Pretas and ever hankering after food, drink and rest, and the other being born in the lower scales of creation in the animal and vegetable kingdoms.

Different kinds of Sradhas are prescribed for the Original Pitris and the varieties of Manushya-Pitris, and the food offered for the benefit of the latter are expected to meet them in the special forms of nourishinents required by them, by the virtue of Manthras and the purity of action, as a calf is capable of finding out its mother in the midst of a herd of COWS. This fact has been assured by Sinatkumara-Rishi, who is said to be gifted with the knowledge of the Pretas, by his Yogic development. What this assurance means could be easily made out when the significance of the said Rishi is known from the pages following.

In noticing again in this connection, the Theosophical explanation of the Pitris and Sradhas, the following extract from Sanathana-Dharma is significant in its own way.

Page 202. “The full meaning of descent from the Pitris is ascertainable only by study of Occult science”.

It can be easily understood by a careful reading of the passages already quoted from the sacred texts, that there are no mysteries represented with regard to the Pitris so far. The real and philosophical interpretation is first given and afterwards a secondary meaning in imitation of the same is furnished, in the usual Puranic style, with a view

to enforce the Ethical necessity of veneration towards the decensel ancestors. More than this nothing mysterious or confounding is discovered, nor even required in the interest of mankind either for worldly or religious purposes. I earnestly wish here to be clearly understood that it is far from my intentionor object to criticise the Theosophists for the work they have done in India, but on the contrary, I am gladly prepared to give them the most charitable considerations and thank the most heartily for having created a spirit of enquiry amongst some of us at least, especially at a time when we have almost reached a stage of utter indifference and disrespect for the contents of our sacred texts. In spite of this fact, I must be excused for what is being statel here, candidly and in plain terms, whenever the real interest of the sacred religion for which we have every legal and moral right, is seriously at stake.

We have unfortunately suffered enough already, by the innocent ignorance of our Pandits, whom we looked upon all along as our unerring guide; and they have practically reduced our religion to something insipid, unscientific and superstitious. We could therefore ill-afford to keep gazing hereafter at further interference in the present fashion. The Pandit’s process of deterioration, being an indigenous one, is capable of easy rectification, as it might be possible to diagnose the local disease without much difficulty. Bat the mistiken procedure of an entirely foreign type, might probably land us in greater confusion and hopelessly place us in irreneliable predicaments. We could however easily discera how the Theosophists have taken to a mistaken course in the present state of affairs, and could fully sympathise with themfor the sun, so far as the interpretations of our ancient literature are coacerned. They were compelled to collect second-hand informations from local Pandits as no

other source was virtually open to them. What was thus obtained could not help appearing absurd on its very face to a western civilized people under the circumstances so often explained. But we are bound to thank the creed for a charitable view they have somehow forined as to the likelihood of our sacred texts containing some sorts of useful and valuable informations. Explanations were therefore attempted naturally by the Western methods of enquiry which unfortunately did not and could not answer the purpose. Theresult of the two mistakes put together was the production of something ridiculous and certainly objectionable as the subject handled was an alien and a most sacred and hoary religion. With reference to the point at issue here the idea of Occultism put forth in the passage quoted from SanathanaDharma, is entirely irrelevant. If the English word ‘Occultism’ used, simply means pure ignorance, we have nothing to complain. Everything unknown and unsaught is of course Occult in that sense, but if it refers to any mystery not found explained in the sacred texts and therefore requiring to be learned from Theosophy, there is no other help than to denounce it as extraneous. There is no doubt that the Occultism here introduced refers to some mysterious powers recognised in Theosophy to find out the deceased ancestors and to keep communion with them or to explain the origin of mankind from the Monads in the Planets. Their peculiar theory, and probably the occultism in question here, as to the Pitris residing in the Moon and their taking birth on the earth as human beings, is as much unwarranted by the contents of our sacred texts as it is by common sense, That our deceased ancestors for whom we perform the Sradha ceremony should be interpreted as our future successors on the arth desce ling from the moon, caunot surely be believed to be the product of a sound brain. The mistake however,

has certainly originated as usual from sheer ignorance of the technical meanings of the words Soma and Soma-loka as used in the texts. They are simply taken to mean the moon as taught by our venerable Pandits. The application of the terms is clearly defined in quotation 2 as everywhere else in the religious literature, as referring to the Akasa.

‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§á‡§∏‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡••

With regard to the deceased ancestors, we have the view taken by the sacred texts distinctly stated in quotation 5,

**‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡•• **

‚ÄõThe ways of the deceased are undiscernible even by great Yogic powers, m ich less by flashy mortal eyes.’ Besides, the Yogic development detailed in the texts is not certainly meant for satisfying the curiosities of this transient material world. The most astonishing facts in this direction will not in the least create feelings of admiration in a Jivan-mukta or a real Yogi.

‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•á‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•å‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ä‡••

‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

“A Jivanmukta is not astonished even if the sun is made to emit cold rays and the moon hot rays, or if the fire is made to burn downwards”.

But even the powers of a Yogi recognised by the texts could not be soirresponsibly utilized for explaining away irrelevant or unwarranted facts. The texts strictly limit their scope, extent and use, and the acquirement of any such powers is not such an easy or light task as is made to appear, nor everybody in India is a baby ready to swallow

all that is spoken about them. The powers if possessed are not matters for oration but for action, without the least desire for display or fame; and the tests for their real attainment, as understood from the texts, are sufficiently explicit so as to prevent belief in deception. The eight Angas or component parts of Yoga such as Saina, Dama &c., are the preparatory processes necessary for the attainment of Yogic results and each Anga consists of the practice of several moral and religious virtues. Out of these large number of requisites, the very first virtue inculcated in Saina to commence with, is ‘Ahimsa’ or harmlessness. The test for having completely secured this first virtue, is recognised as consisting in the prevention of mutual harm among animals naturally inimical. Animals like lions and tigers, which are by the very nature of their creation, enemies and destroyers of milder animals, such as cows, sheep and deer, are said to behave friendly with them in the presence of the Yogi who has accomplished this single virtue. In the Puranic descriptions of the residences or Asramas of Rishis, this fact can be observed frequently noticed. The existence and non-existence of the Yogic powers claimed in accordance with our Sastras by any member of Theosophy, are thus easily ascertainable. A tiger and a cow let loose before him will immediately solve the problem satisfactorily, and under the existing state of affairs, there is no doubt that the tiger will alone remain to decide the question at issue. The Puranic description of the Pitris is virtually a treatment of Karm-Yoga, a serious and scientific subject in which no pretensions could be of any avail.

‡§Ö‡§®‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡•É‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

8. We have now to some extent examined the significance of the Devas and the Pitris, two important

personages constantly introduced in the religious texts. The Asuras, though often occurring in them are only mentioned for the purpose of being avoided. Before taking up the next important figures known as the Rishis, it may be desirable to examine particularly the nature of the Asuras named Mandehas, who are said to obstruct the path of the sun every day, and for the removal of whose obstruction the Hindus are strictly ordained to perform the Sandhya-vandana both morning and evening. The following passage from Vishnu-Purana clearly explains the whole subject.

‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•§
‡§∑‡§°‡•á‡§µ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§â‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§â‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡•§
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§ì‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ì‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§ì‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§• ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ò‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É‡••

“In the half year known as Uttarayana and in that known as Dekshinayana, the durations of day and night differ. This difference is not owing to any variation in the rate of sun’s speed. The twelve Rasis or constellations or signs of the Zodiac, six of which extend to the day and six to the night cause this difference of duration. Usha means night, Vyushti is day and the intervening time is Sandhya. At this terrible Sandhya, the Rakshasas named Mandehas attempt to devour the sun by furiously fighting with him. By the curse of Prejapathi, they ever retain their body, but they die every day. The Bramhins at this time pour water muttering Om combined with Gayathri. This water turns into a diamond weapon and destroys the Rakshasas. The first offering of rice in the Agnihotra then adds lustre to the sun. Here Om refers to Vishnu the God of words, and the sun represents the Para-Bramhan the eternal and internal light. The Rakshasas allude to the sins of man. Therefore none shall violate the ordinance to perform this Sandhya, as he would ortherwise be doing harm to the sun”.

The sandhya here explained is regarded as an important religious ceremony to be daily perforined by the Hindus,

and it has now virtually become a meaningless ritual seldom cared for by the younger generation among the educatedHindus. This is indeed a deplorable state of fact for which somebody must be held responsible. Surely, the fault could not be attributed to modern education which undoubtedly improves the intellectual capacities of its sincere votaries. The real difficulty here is, that when education naturally demanded a reasonable explanation for the ceremony under reference, the Pandit authorities owing to their utter want of religious education were unable to furnish necessary explanations, The Sandhya being one of the simplest daily ceremonies ordained by religion, it is indeed a pity that everyone is groping in the dark at present with regard to its real significance. In the interest of our sacred religion and in that of the modern Hindu public, it is highly necessary that a better source of information should be immediately sought for than the misleading and ignorant Pandit authorities. The above quotation clearly proves that the ceremony ordained is no superstitious absurdity, nor mysterious occultism. The worship of the Sun at the Sandhya is plainly explained as referring to the adoration of the internal Atma.

**‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• **

The Rakshasas named Mandehas are said to reprresent the sins of man obstructing the acquirement of real knowledge of the Atma.

‡§¶‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡••

The process prescribed for the destruction of these Rakshasas or sins is the meditation of the Atma accompanied by the ordained Manthra.

‡§ì‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The term Mandeha itself gives the necessary clue here for the Puranic description. It points to the variation of time in the day. Of course this is perceptible only at the Sandhyas, and the Rakshasas are described as appearing at those times. The Sun being the greatest and the grandest light-giver to this material world, the analogical representation of Atma is most appropriate, and the application of the analogy itself is plainly stated in all the religious texts.

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Å‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§É‡••

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ì‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡••

“The Sun represents the Atma common to all the movables and immovables. The Sun outside is the objective Atma and Prana is the internal Atina. The workings of the one are compared to those of the other. Therefore meditate upon the Sun as Om and apply it to the Atma”.

There is no doubt that there is ample practical sense in this ordina ce on a psychological point of view. Besides, we could easily infer from these analogical prescriptions of religious ceremonies, that the ancient Rishis, who were masters of their own science, were not unmindful of the collateral effects accruing from external advantages utilized for the purpose of helping on the lower orders of society. These are ordinary observations which could not possibly miss the eye of an earnest and sincere enquirer of truth, more especially in the field of religion in which he is personally interested. There is also nothing surprising in the fact that indifference, incapacity, bias, pride or prejudice fails to perceive correctly and fully even the plainest matters, on account of these very natural defects. And it is equallyno wonder, that those subject to such unfortunate drawbacks, are generally prone to criticise. bare truth and plain

sense, as something derogatory to the dignity of mankind, guaged as they are by the low and vicious standard of their own.

‡§ú‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•å ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡•å ‡§ï‡•à‡§§‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç
‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡•É‡§£‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡•á
**‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•• **

Like Mahisha and the Mandehas already noticed among the Asuras, there are two well-known brothers named Madhu and Kytabha who are said to have originated from the ears of Vishnu during his sleep. These powerful Asuras once attacked Bramha who had to seek the help of Vishnu to be freed from their molestation. Vishnu destroyed them after a long and terrible fight, and from their Medas, marrow or fat the earthy globe originated called Medini.

‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡•à‡§ü‡§≠‡•å‡•§
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤‡•å ‡§ö ‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡§≤‡•á‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤‡•å‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•§
‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§ú‡§ò‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•å ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•å ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡•à‡§ü‡§≠‡•å‡•§

‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡••

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The earth being thus made up of the fat of these terrible Asuras is said to have become un-edible. The Pandit evidently has nothing to enlighten us here. He understands nothing out of this story. The description given will doubtless prevent the critic from cooking up any Indian historical incident. Tthe birth and death of these Asuras are said to have taken place in the waters of the ocean which covered the three Lokas, and the earth itself originated from their fat afer their death. Although they were killed by Vishnu at last, their original aim was to attack Bramha. The modern Pandit who has certainly not studied the subject, is under the impression that such stories are meaningless and are left unexplained in the literature. The following gives a clear and sensible explanation of the description.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•à‡§ü‡§≠‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•å ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤‡•å‡••

‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡•à‡§ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡••

‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡•§
‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡•å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡••

‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

“The obstruction originating from Tamas is Madhu and from Rejas is Kytabha.
